PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That the following government business orders of the day be considered not later than 2 pm today:
No. 2— Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997 and 2 related bills, second reading.
No. 3— Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1996‐97 and 2 associated bills, second reading.
No. 5— Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2) second reading.

DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1997 RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we last discussed the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996, I was coming to my final comments. I think it is appropriate to put on record the summary effect of the bill. Firstly, it affects a group of workers who in large numbers do not and will not qualify for superannuation, and hence cannot and will not be able to avail themselves of the new world of choice that is inherent in the RSA proposition. Secondly, it affects a group of employees with multiple accounts with successive employers. However, this group already has the option of account amalgamation. Thirdly, there is an alleged problem for those nearing retirement. The easier and simpler solution to allow funds to offer a capital guarantee investment mix is appealing. If there is sufficient demand, the market will force development of this product. With that summary, I close my comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996 and cognate bills seek to put into legislation the government's election commitment to expand the choice of superannuation vehicles by allowing financial institutions to offer retirement savings accounts. The government's intentions are made quite clear in the explanatory memorandum, which says that RSAs will be a simple, low cost, low risk product especially suited to those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant and casual workers.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative structure does not impose the requirement on financial institutions offering RSAs to put in place a trustee structure as superannuation funds have. Rather, the bill sets up a two‐tiered supervisory regime with prudential supervision of the soundness of institutions continuing through the Reserve Bank and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission and state authorities, with functional supervision of the conditions of RSAs being undertaken by the ISC.

The bill contains details of the approval of RSA providers, the disclosure regime for RSA accounts, the powers of the ISC, the taxation of RSAs and the duties and responsibilities of RSA providers. I state at the outset that the Democrats support the notion of retirement savings accounts but only with significant safeguards in place. We agree with the government that there is a role for low risk, low fee, low balance products which may suit itinerant workers and workers nearing retirement. But we see major restrictions on the benefits of RSAs on any widespread scale. This is because RSAs, by their very nature, are likely to offer very low rates of return when compared with superannuation funds. This point was illustrated by the Australian Consumers Association, which showed that over a 40-year lifetime workers whose superannuation was kept in an RSA would end up with a payout as much as 60 per cent less than a worker in a normal superannuation fund.

BREAK.PARA: In the past year the industry superannuation funds scored investment returns for their members of around 13 per cent, according to Industry Funds Services. By contrast, the banks are paying interest rates of just 6.4 per cent on long-term, large, fixed deposits and rates of just 2.1 per cent on deposits of up to $10,000 held in investment accounts, according to the Reserve Bank. All parties concede that workers with larger super balances would be better off in a super fund than an RSA. I believe we must ensure that any legislation the Senator passes ensures that workers are adequately protected.

The importance of ensuring the legislation is robust enough to protect workers is made doubly important because RSAs will be offered on a commercial basis. There will be no trustees governing the super accounts required by law to act in the best interests of the member. Rather, institutions holding RSAs will be governed by directors required by law to act in the best interests of shareholders subject only to the conditions in this legislation. Parliament must ensure that the rights of account holders are adequately protected. Sadly, I believe the legislation presented by the government fails to achieve this.

The legislation does not ensure that employees are adequately informed of the weaknesses of RSAs. Indeed, the legislation does not even ensure that the employee will be the person who chooses to place the funds into an RSA, allowing the employer instead to do so. Survey after survey has shown that Australian workers have a low level of understanding of superannuation and of finance. The likelihood of being able to make informed choices within the narrow information regime and time frames presented by this bill is most unlikely.

The Democrats are particularly concerned that the bill will allow employers to enter into arrangements with financial institutions to transfer large numbers of employees into RSAs, offering much lower investment returns than industry funds, with the onus being on the member to transfer back. These transfers could occur in a background of financial institutions offering substantial benefits to employers for delivering to their workers, such as access to finance, commission and so on.

The Australian Consumers Association, in evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, expressed the concern that the Trade Practices Act, particularly section 47, is inadequate to defeat such practices. I will be moving amendments in the committee stage to ensure that entering RSAs is about the employee's assessment of the benefit, not the employer's benefit. The Democrats will also be moving amendments to ensure that employees are fully informed about the investment performance of RSA products and superannuation funds before they sign up for RSAs. We will be moving amendments to prevent employers from signing up RSAs on behalf of the employee, except in the limited case where an employee was provided with the information and failed to support a superannuation fund within 28 days.

The government has argued that the employer nomination rights mirror the rights of employers under the SIS legislation, in that an employer can nominate a superannuation fund on behalf of an employee. The argument is that this act sets up a level playing field, but it is not level. I am prepared to accept employees being forced to join a particular superannuation fund because the law requires the trustees of superannuation funds to act in the interests of the members. RSA providers have no such legal duty. These are low return products and there should be no compulsion driven by the employer of the RSA provider for anyone to join.
It should also be pointed out that the coalition's election promise to introduce RSAs was very much about providing additional freedom of choice. The policy made that quite clear. It said:

The coalition's intention is not to replace existing superannuation funds, but to complement current arrangements by expanding the range of options open to consumers . . . RSAs provide Australians with greater freedom of choice.

But this bill will fall well short of this idea. If a worker freely chooses to place their superannuation funds outside the trustee structure into a low return RSA product, that is their choice. But the choice must be free; the choice must be between an RSA and some other product. The government says that these issues will be dealt with in its freedom of choice legislation. We have not yet seen that legislation and we may never see the legislation. Yet the issue of choice and RSAs are inexorably linked in the government's own policy statement.

Therefore, I will be moving amendments to make it a condition that RSA providers cannot open an RSA account unless the employee has been offered a choice between joining the RSA or the relevant industry fund or, if there is no industry fund, between the RSA and some other superannuation fund. I will also be moving amendments to ensure employees are warned that when the RSA reaches a large level at, say, $5,000 and again at $10,000, they would be better off, in terms of long‐term investment returns, transferring their funds to a managed superannuation fund. This does not mean that they cannot keep their RSA open if they wish. But when the account reaches $10,000, the continuing of the large balance of the RSA should require a positive election by the member. If they do not elect, the amount should be switched into a managed fund approved by the ISC.

I will also be moving to ban fees being charged on RSAs. The credit unions, in evidence to the committee, said that RSAs could be offered on a no fee basis. Given that deposits will be regular and infrequent, maybe quarterly, and given that withdrawals will only be to close the account or on retirement, the cost of running these accounts will be minimal. RSAs will provide financial institutions with access to fairly low cost finance. The current five‐year term deposit rate is a maximum of 6.4 per cent, the business lending rate is 9.75 per cent and the home loan rate is temporarily around 7.55 per cent, so there is substantial profit margin there for the banks.

Failing making RSAs fee free, we will be seeking to strengthen the powers of the ISC to require RSA providers to abide by standards of low fees. The amendments I am proposing to move will bring the RSA legislative package close to the recommendations of the majority—the coalition and Democrat members of the superannuation committee in its 15th report in 1995 on the small amounts problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that in the register of interests I declared that my sister‐in‐law was a director of a major superannuation fund. I draw the attention of the Senate to that fact again. Whilst it does not impact on this particular debate, some people may infer that it does.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first entered this chamber and made my first speech, I referred to three aspects of dignity—in youth, work and retirement. The Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996 and cognate bills touch on the last issue—dignity in retirement. I believe that dignity in retirement is of fundamental importance to people in this day and age. The aged pension has not necessarily afforded people that dignity over a long period, whereas superannuation has given people access to at least an element of dignity which otherwise would not have been provided by the pension.

For many years the average worker was condemned simply to the aged pension. In previous times many people felt no real security in retirement, and superannuation itself was the province of executives. This ensured those executives a reasonably comfortable retirement, well above the level of pensions, and there was a major breakthrough when award superannuation and the SGC came into existence. This changed the nature and the perspective of superannuation as far as the average worker was concerned. I must agree with what Senator Allison said: the average worker does not have a great deal of understanding of what superannuation is really about.

We must approach the legislation that is before this Senate this afternoon with caution. One must be very wary that the product that is being made available is a product that will in the long term benefit and add dignity to those people in their retirement. When award superannuation and the SGC came in, they did go part of the way to ensuring the dignity in retirement of the average worker. But it must be remembered that their aim was to give a real and tangible long‐term benefit to the average worker. Of course, one must hold some reservations about whether RSAs—I am sure that this is a real concern that would be shared by many of my colleagues—will deliver a real and long-term tangible benefit to the average worker.

Looking at what happened with award superannuation, it can be seen that on that occasion it was an attempt by the employers to hijack the funds that were created and so use them for their own purpose. But, alas, they found this not to be the purpose for the establishment of those superannuation funds.

What I am getting at is that the purpose of the establishment of the superannuation funds was purely and simply to deliver a long-term benefit to the worker. It was not for any other ancillary or subsidiary purpose; it was purely and simply to deliver something by way of a tangible benefit to the workers themselves. I think my colleagues Senator Bishop and Senator Sherry in their speeches on this particular matter alluded to this also. In the award superannuation situation we found that the insurance companies tried to coopt employers to direct their employees into a particular insurance company sponsored scheme. This was a `you scratch my back, I'll scratch your back' type of operation for which the measure was never designed or meant to operate.

On the other side of the fence though, we had union-employer jointly sponsored industry funds. These became the target of every form of castigation possible by the employers and the insurance industry alike. The aim of the industry funds was to be representative of their members and to do the best that it was reasonably possible to do for their members. So that major difference between the those with the industry funds and those who had some sort of insurance or superannuation company sponsorship was fundamental in the early days of award superannuation and drove quite a wedge between them out there in the real industrial world.

One of the things that stood industry funds aside from the insurance company sponsored schemes was the matter of administrative charges. Many of the insurance company sponsored schemes had a relatively high administrative charge structure. This, in the longer term, diminished the return that was to be given to the worker whose money was being placed in these schemes—and, of course, that money was to be of vital importance to these people when they finally reached retirement.

Invariably though, industry funds were able to charge and did charge less than insurance company schemes because their primary focus was the people they were representing and, of course, the affinity that many of the people on the boards of those industry superannuation funds had with the people they represented. Industry funds did work for the best interests of the workers; whereas one would clearly question whether, in the longer term, RSAs will serve this purpose. I think the reservations of people already expressed in this chamber clearly indicate there are doubts that RSAs will be the product they should be for many people in the longer term.

With the industry superannuation schemes there was supposed to be a choice for employees as to what fund their contributions would go into under the award system. However, this never really happened in many instances. That is one of my primary concerns when we look at RSAs—that people will not have a genuine option to choose which fund their funds will be placed into; and that is regardless of the advisability of the product itself.

Turning to page 54 of the report on retirement savings account legislation, the 22nd report of the Senate select committee, my colleagues who were on this committee put forward a number of recommendations. Just briefly I will address some of those recommendations because I think they go to the nub of the concerns that many people who are average workers out there in the community—the battlers—would have.

I turn firstly to the recommendation of my colleagues that the employer should show the consent of the employee to the opening up of an RSA account. I think that is very important. It should not be something whereby the employee is dragooned into a particular RSA. I think it is of fundamental importance to the person that they have a choice—and that it is transparent—to go into that product or, as Senator Allison, into an industry fund even which will undoubtedly afford a higher return than the RSA would be able to provide.

The second thing in the recommendations of my colleagues is that any commercial relationship between the employer and the RSA provider should be clearly disclosed. Again, this is for transparency so that there are no behind the scenes deals being done and that everything is aboveboard.

Another of the recommendations of my colleagues is on the matter of disclosure—that, before the RSA is opened, there needs to be up-front disclosure on matters such as fees and charges, the interest rate, the commercial relationship between the employer and the RSA provider, the fact that it is low growth and the fact that it is low return. This seems an eminently sensible approach to take when people are going into these low return and low growth investments—a product which is described as a health warning in my colleagues' report which was tabled in the major report of the committee.

I think that the disclosure up front supports what Senator Allison said before me: that there is this ignorance of superannuation, this general lack of understanding of what superannuation is. Those who are in contact with superannuation on a day‐to‐day basis generally and invariably have no problem in dealing with this type of product, but to many people it is a mystery. Of course, if the employer has employees in a situation where they are dragooned into a particular fund, then they have no idea of what is happening—it is a matter of, `Sign on the dotted line.' Employees find themselves in a totally disadvantaged position.

One of the other recommendations that my colleagues came up with was that there should be a prohibition on the issue of third line forcing. One might ask the question: how is this done? I do not necessarily have all the answers, nor do I necessarily know how one will find the proof. I am leaving that to Senator Conroy, who signed that section of the report. There is no doubt, though, that this comes again to the transparency of the relationship. If a deal done between the employer and the RSA provider has an advantage for the employer because of some commercial advantage to the RSA provider in signing all the people into a particular RSA fund, then that is quite clearly a breach of trust on the part of the employer, and should be prohibited under all circumstances.

I am not referring to all the points raised by my colleagues, but there are two others which I think are important at this stage. The first is `that the definition of the capital guarantee be amended to reflect the sentiment that accounts cannot be diminished by fees and charges'. There is nothing worse than seeing a person's savings diminished by fees and charges. The second—last, but not least—is education. If we are going to have a low growth and a low return package, then education of those people out there who will be subject to this package is terribly important indeed. You just cannot say, `Buyer beware,' because in many instances people are not aware of what the products are, as I said earlier. Of course, some of them are migrant workers. Some itinerant workers have poor English‐speaking backgrounds, therefore an education process to overcome the difficulties that these people may face is terribly important indeed.

I have always supported the concept of super for ordinary workers; I believe it is fundamental. I do not know whether this product before us by way of retirement savings accounts will deliver what superannuation should deliver. I trust that the government will look favourably upon the opposition's amendments to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a superannuation system that has received much praise around the world. It is not a perfect system, but one which has been built on a recognition by all parties that it is in the national interest, as well as in the individual's interest, to introduce the SGC and the regulatory system which accompanies it. This legislation is the beginning of the end of a bipartisan policy on superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP's objectives are twofold: firstly, at a macro‐economic level, to improve our national savings to help address our chronic balance of payments problem and, secondly, at a micro‐economic level, to provide security for all Australians when they retire. The ALP responded to changing circumstances throughout its time in government by refining and improving the system, but always with those two goals in mind. What we are seeing today is the assertion of narrow sectional interests and a political pay‐off. The government has made claims about this bill. I quote from the Treasurer's press release of 20 August 1996:

. . . RSAs will be a simple, low cost, low risk product especially suited to those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant and casual workers, those wishing to amalgamate several small superannuation accounts and those nearing retirement (wishing to minimise risk). Their introduction will complement existing arrangements by increasing competition and choice in the superannuation industry, thereby putting downward pressure on fees and charges, and encouraging better standards of service.
When introducing the bill in the other place, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, the Hon. Chris Miles, said:

. . . Retirement Savings Accounts—or RSAs for short—have a central role to play in the Government's strategy for increasing choice and competition in the superannuation sector. Choice gives employees greater scope to control the management of their superannuation savings.

I believe that an examination of the detail of the bill shows that the bill fails even the government's stated objectives Further, if you test this bill against the previously stated objectives of the ALP, which presumably had coalition support, it becomes clear that the bill must be amended before passing the Senate.

Let us examine each of the government's claimed objectives. Firstly, `simple, low cost, low risk'. It is true that the RSA product will be low risk. However, the flip side to low risk is low return. I will return to this shortly. Secondly, `low cost'. The Treasurer makes the assertion that RSAs will be low cost but, when he gets the opportunity to guarantee this by legislating on this critical issue, we have a blank sheet and a promise. Where is the clause that protects against a reduction in the capital amount through fees and charges? There is not one. When pressed on this issue, the Australian Bankers Association agreed it was possible for fees and charges to erode the capital amount.

There is no protection for balances under $1,000, as was introduced under the ALP's legislation. This was introduced as a specific measure to guard against the erosion of an account. The average industry fund charges between $25 and $35 a year to administrate a member's account.

Whilst I welcomed the suggestion of a number of organisations, which presented submissions to the committee, that their members would not charge any fees for an RSA, the banks have made no such promise. In fact, if you take the evidence given before many inquiries into banks and their fee structures, the banks make it clear that their obligation is not to the customer but to the shareholder. They have increased their fees and charges on all their small depositors in an effort to increase their profit margins. This has caused significant hardship for many thousands of ordinary Australians. Now the banks would have you believe that they want to offer a service to the worker with small accounts.

The key to this issue is that the current superannuation funds work within a trustee structure, which means that profits generated are returned to members' accounts, not to a third party. That is the shareholders in the case of banks. There is a financial incentive to minimise costs to members. This is not just empty rhetoric. This has been proven as the competition from industry funds has slashed costs in the superannuation and life assurance industry—from the many thousands of dollars previously to below $100 a year in most cases.

The government claims that this bill will allow an employee to consolidate several superannuation accounts into one RSA account—the implication being that this is desirable. Yet submissions to the committee acknowledge that it is, in fact, likely that a casual or itinerant worker can be forced into the identical situation of multiple RSA accounts. The legislation ignores this. The single greatest furphy being put forward by the government to support this legislation is that RSAs will increase choice and give employees greater control of their money. That is important.

Despite the government's commitment to allow super funds to offer RSAs in its March 1996 election campaign statement, and the initial cabinet submission from Treasury which was leaked, the legislation has dropped this promise. Why? That question has to be asked. If we want choice, why exclude super funds from offering RSAs? The smell of a political pay-off grows, but even this does not give the game away. It is not until you examine clause 51 that this government is exposed for rank hypocrisy. This clause is where the employer is allowed to open an account on behalf of an employee without the consent of the employee. That is right, senators—without the consent of the employee.

There was much discussion of this by the committee, and some attempts were made by officers of the ISC to suggest that this is current practice. We in the opposition are neither convinced that it is standard behaviour in the industry nor, more importantly, that the opportunity for abuse that now exists is a comparable situation to what has been the case.

The bill provides that, irrespective of an employee already belonging to a fund and not seeking to change the arrangement, the following can occur: an employer can take the initiative in opening up an RSA on behalf of an employee; RSAs can be opened for employees without prior consent; contributions can cease to an existing fund, unless protected by an award provision; contributions can be forwarded to the RSA prior to the employee receiving any information from the RSA provider; contributions can be forwarded to the RSA prior to the employee consenting to have the RSA as his or her superannuation vehicle, consenting to that particular RSA provider. The ACTU summed up this issue before the committee as follows:

. . . choice of funds should not rest with the employer—such a practice denies employees ownership of their superannuation benefits and is contrary to the government's stated objective of promoting greater consumer choice . . . Employers have no direct interest in ensuring employees' superannuation contributions are paid into low cost and efficient superannuation saving vehicles which meet both the retirement needs and employment patterns of their work force. Employers have no direct interest in ensuring that superannuation contributions are placed in a superannuation vehicle which has an investment program which meets the risk profile and aspirations of their employees.

It is there that the bill fails the last of the government's objectives. This legislation creates a product with a brand name, excludes competitors from using the brand name and then mandates a reduction in individual choice by removing the owner of the money from the decision.

Almost all super funds in Australia are moving towards a system called member choice; that is, each member can choose the investment pattern within the fund that they would prefer. This allows true choice to control the management of superannuation savings. Will RSAs be required to allow options on investment patterns? Of course not. Clearly, this bill fails on all of the government's objectives.

What is going to be the outcome of this legislation? There are three grounds on which I believe this bill, unamended, should be rejected. These are that they reduce national savings; they reduce the individual's retirement income; and, critically, they will lead to corruption of the relationship between banks and employers. This is referred to as third line forcing. This practice is illegal under section 47 part IV of the Trade Practices Act.

What is going to occur is that banks will approach their existing corporate clients and offer to establish and administer RSAs for their employees. Why is this different from a fund offering to do this? A fund will not offer to reduce the interest rates on the employer's overdraft rate in return. That is right: banks will offer a financial incentive to the employer to hand over his employees' money to the banks. From where I stand, this is nothing more than a bribe. Yet this is not specifically made illegal in the bill and potentially falls outside the Trade Practices Act. Where is the clause that stops this, Senator Kemp? Where?
Now the abuse is out in the open. This is even admitted by the banks. When put to the ABA—before the committee—that this would occur, this was their response:

BREAK.PARA: I cannot see that it is a conflict of interest. I really wouldn't want to speculate on the nature of the incentives, or the qualification of those incentives, but the notion of incentives is part of any business relationship. It is part and parcel of normal business. As long as it is not improper, as long as people are comfortable with those arrangements, then so be it.

That is the banks. Improper, they say! This is a commercial arrangement between the bank and the employer over an employee's money. The banks do not even believe they should have to reveal the nature of any inducement to the employees who will be losing their money into these accounts. So banks believe that this will be a normal business practice. And what about the government—who are not even here? Where are the safeguards? Where the penalties for breaching them? Again, silence. An absence.

What are the consequences of this bill on national savings? The government's own actuaries have calculated that there will be a significant reduction in the pool of national savings. This report was released last year with almost no fanfare. Some industry assessments have suggested that this reduction could be in the order of $21 billion.

What are the consequences for an individual who is placed in an inappropriate RSA? The Australian Consumers Association have profiled a number of examples which give a clear indication of how much an individual can lose if they are trapped in an RSA. To quote them, `The cost of a low long‐term return is enormous.' They calculate that the loss can be as high as $200,000 in a final payout. That is twice the pension rate that exists today if it is taken in the form of a pension. This will mean that individuals who previously have had little or no need of a pension from the government will now be forced to rely on the government in their retirement. And remember that an employee may be forced into an RSA because a bank has offered a bribe to an employer.

How, then, can this bill be improved to protect the interests of the worker and his or her money? It is obvious that education is critical. This legislation should mandate the information to be provided. The most critical is the health warning, which should be given at the outset. The initial information should include all fees, charges and commissions; a clear explanation of risk; historical and possible future returns; the importance of the cooling off period; and any financial gain to the employer if the employee purchases the RSA.

The legislation should have an automatic opt‐out clause, not a default that leaves an individual in an RSA. An individual should make the choice to remain long term in an RSA, not be automatically defaulted into it.

There is a need, as Senator Hogg earlier indicated, for a substantial education campaign by the ISC and government to complement this legislation. Yet there is no commitment in the legislation to provide that education.

In closing, I repeat: this legislation fails all tests—government's and opposition's. It reduces national savings; it reduces an individual's retirement income; it is not guaranteed low cost; it will not reduce the number of accounts; and it does not increase choice. This is nothing more than a pay‐off to the banks who bankrolled the coalition in the last election campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the only education campaign that needs to be conducted is here in the Senate—and particularly for the government members—because the fact that they brought this legislation into this parliament at all is an indication that there is a massive education campaign required. We should not even be debating it, let alone voting for or against it. It is the most ridiculous piece of legislation that you could ever want to see, in terms of providing anything that it claims or even pretends that it might provide at the end of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand, the government says it is about freedom of choice. We have heard from a number of speakers that there is no freedom of choice. Indeed, even in today's superannuation world, there are enough problems with regard to the provision of freedom of choice. Some employers—and, thankfully, this is not a standard practice—who may have their insurance with a particular company will seek to force their employees to take out superannuation benefits with that company. And they do so on the basis of possibly getting their insurance costs reduced. The fact that you are going to move to an RSA with banks and credit unions and the like will only exacerbate that problem. If we had a deal with superannuation, we ought to be about trying to fix up the problems, not creating them.

The other major problem with this is that superannuation or retirement savings accounts ought to be about—if you had them—providing funds for people in their retirement. The very purpose of superannuation is that. And I think to a large degree, superannuation funds—and we introduced compulsory superannuation and the levy—have been significantly successful. There has been a huge increase in the number of people who are covered by superannuation. So if we look at RSAs from that point of view and what is proposed with them, they are not going to pay anywhere near the level of interest or attract anywhere near the level of interest rate that will bring them even within the ballpark of interest rates that are paid on superannuation funds—nowhere near it.

And while we are talking about freedom of choice, the other major factor ought to be the consumer benefit. Yes, consumers may want freedom of choice, but I know that in terms of superannuation benefit and retirement benefit, they want a return. They want a proper benefit. The legislation provides for no ability for there to be any guarantee on return. I was curious about the Democrats' position of supporting the government in the introduction of RSAs. I think I heard Senator Allison say that they could expect a return of around two per cent. What a load of nonsense—complete and utter rubbish. These funds will, at best, attract a quarter of a per cent. I think I also heard Senator Allison say that the Democrats would move to amend some guarantees in terms of fees and charges. Another load of rubbish.

People ought to understand that the Australian banking system is one of the most pathetic in the world. Over 50 per cent of the money that ordinary Australians currently have in banks earns less than two per cent in interest. You are talking about $120 billion. Banks have around $15 billion of Australians' money that the banks pay no interest on whatsoever.

I am not going to be about supporting a piece of legislation that endeavours to give those banks more Australians' money that is supposed to be for their retirement where the bank will pay them no interest and, on top of that, turn around and charge them fees on it. The Senate ought to understand that we have an obligation to the people of Australia, particularly those that are looking to governments to provide legislation in respect of their retirement, to ensure that there will be some benefit.

I want to go back to this matter of freedom of choice. There are already products in the market that can deal with problems of portability and pay a minimum rate of interest of around four per cent. I am totally amazed that the Democrats have chosen to support the government in this way in terms of this legislation. The other issue of freedom of choice, which was raised before, is about workers' rights. There is no way that workers will be guaranteed any rights in this.

Moreover, they will end up with a heap of RSAs: one with Westpac, one with Commonwealth, one with ANZ, one with NAB—a great lot they are!—and maybe with credit unions. Whomever the employer banks with will be where the money goes—and all attracting fees and charges because the government cannot and will not legislate to remove all the banking facilities' rights to charge fees on these accounts.

It is worthwhile noting what the Australian Consumers Association had to say about bank fees and charges. I think in 1996 bank fees and charges went up by 200 per cent. I do not know whether or not the government plans to amend this legislation to provide for a maximum level of fee, but even if it took that small step it would never protect these small amounts of money in these types of RSAs.

There are a number of problems with the existing superannuation process. The government would do better if it addressed itself to some of those problems. What some superannuation schemes have done in the past—and some may well continue to do—is set up a particular program of investment which will attract a set of fees. They do not necessarily tell you over what period those fees will have to be paid and, if you choose to take the money out of one particular fund and place it in another, that there are opt‐out penalties. The government says that as far as RSAs are concerned there will not be an opt‐out penalty. It is just simply not good enough.

It really has to come down to this: if you are on about providing choice and benefit, then you will withdraw this legislation and have a really hard look at what is required for the provision of superannuation benefits and retirement schemes to Australian workers. This proposed legislation will do nothing and provide nothing, except provide the banks with the ability to further rip off the Australian community in terms of the money that in many cases will be forcibly taken from workers and put in their particular bank or banking institution, and the workers will have no say. The banks will then lend this money at interest.

I think someone pointed out earlier what banks charge us when we borrow. They and their shareholders will be reaping huge benefits. It is very interesting to look at the National Australia Bank: a $2 billion‐plus profit and a return to shareholders of around 17½ per cent. But look at what they pay the poor old punters whose money they exist on. Without the punters' money, banks would not exist. It is about time we took a long hard look at that.

I suggest to the government: withdraw this legislation and really do something that is positive for the Australian workers and Australian consumers. Take the right steps by making legislation that provides for better outcomes for retirement savings and take a long, hard look at legislation that makes our banking industry more competitive and treats Australian banking consumers more equitably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate because what we have seen from this government is a persistent attack on what is really a world‐class retirement incomes framework that was established by the previous government. That is not simply my view; that is the view of overseas experts about the system which has been established here and which provides a basis for the provision of retirement incomes into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure will do little to develop that framework further. In many respects, this measure will weaken it and will weaken the trust that people are developing in the superannuation framework. We have heard about other measures, particularly in relation to the 15 per cent additional tax on superannuation, known colloquially as a surcharge, that this government is seeking to place on the high income earners. We are told that a number of people will withdraw some of their funds from the superannuation system. That is not doing anything to strengthen the system. Whether or not it is supported in this chamber, the fact is that there are so many changes being proposed to superannuation and this is not doing anything for anyone's security in the superannuation system.

When the previous government was attending to appropriate regulation many concerns were raised as to the extent of legislation which governed the superannuation industry and the investment mechanisms that underpin it. There was a lot of criticism. The Labor government was told that there needed to be a greater degree of simplicity in the system and that the legislation is difficult to understand. But what do we have? This is one of a number of pieces of legislation. I understand that when the bill was introduced into the House of Representatives it had 154 pages with a consequential amendment bill of 83 pages and a regime which would require between 200 and 300 regulations to underpin it. So much for simplicity for probably a small part of the system. Nothing to engender confidence in the superannuation system would arise from this bill.

When it comes to the underpinning tenet of this bill—that is, the issue of choice and the protection of the balances of lower income earners, whose money, it is alleged, would be better placed in these retirement savings accounts—the reality is that, firstly, this bill does not guarantee that the fees and charges which will be levied against these accounts will be reduced compared with the fees and levies which would otherwise be brought against accounts in trustee based superannuation fund accounts.

At this stage nothing ensures that the balances could easily be withdrawn from these accounts without the attraction of significant fees—fees, in fact, significantly higher than those which might be levied by trustee based funds—so that employees would have real choice and portability in relation to their funds, particularly as their balances reached a level where the rate of return became critical as to the rate of growth over the life of those funds.

We heard in relation to another bill in this chamber, the workplace relations bill, that this government was concerned about choice and freedom of choice. We were told about the ability for individuals to reach agreements, Australian workplace agreements, and there would be freedom of choice. Subsequently, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) announced in support of the Workplace Agreements Commissioner who was appointed, Mr Rowe, that the requirement to enter into an agreement prior to employment was not duress but freedom of choice.

This bill has provisions which require banks to make disclosures about all information relevant to the performance of retirement savings accounts, but whom do they have to disclose that to? Not the employee, whose money will be in the account, but the employer, who will make deposits on behalf of the employee in circumstances which would otherwise mean the holder of the moneys would be a trustee organisation. But this legislation will obviate the banks from having that trustee structure—a structure that is required in other superannuation funds.

This type of account is being equated with an ordinary bank account, yet the employees will, I believe from my reading of the legislation, have no say. Their money will be placed into an account which will be entirely within the control of the bank. That is quite remarkable. There is no point in this bill requiring the retirement savings account provider to disclose information directly to the employee prior to the account being opened. Indeed, the account may be opened without the express permission of the employee. The employer can open that account.

No doubt it is possible, as has already been said in this debate, that the employer will decide that it is advantageous to have all accounts held in a retirement savings account provided by the banking provider that conducts the other banking of that business. If we are looking at freedom of choice, there can be no confidence about real choice being made in these circumstances.

It has been suggested that this situation is no different from the current one where employees are, by virtue of awards, required to have their superannuation accounts held in one or another of particular industry fund accounts. But that occurs not because the employer or an employer organisation determines that. It is at the direction of either the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or one of the state commissions. So an independent body able to look at the matter makes an order, but in these circumstances an employer could say to employees, `I want all of you to have your superannuation in retirement savings accounts with the bank I bank with,' or another bank or provider that that employer chooses.

I believe nothing in this bill allows, for example, groups of employees with a particular employer to opt for different providers—that is, there may be 10 employees and each choose 10 different retirement savings account providers. That would be freedom of choice. I do not think many businesses would welcome it, and possibly that is why the government does not make that option available to employers. Nevertheless, that is real choice. If this government is about real choice, it would provide that option.

It is suggested that this was one of the government's election promises and that it is only fulfilling its election promises in pursuing this legislation. That is an honourable notion, but if it were consistent in pursuing its election promises I would have a great deal more respect for it. We have seen so many of this government's election promises declared `non‐core', which is an interesting code term for `breakable' because so many of this government's election promises have been broken. But in this case we have an election promise, which will deliver to the banks billions of dollars of low cost money, which this government is apparently not prepared to countenance breaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they finance the election campaign?

—That is very interesting, Senator Carr. Who did finance them last time? I think I read somewhere that there was a $10 million unsecured loan to a gentleman connected to one of the banks and to the Liberal Party.
—And a casino.

—And a casino? Is that true? It seems to me that there was a great deal of choice involved in the government's decision about this legislation and that the government is the one which is exercising choice on behalf of contributors to its campaign funds.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a bill that, in its current form, is insupportable. I believe it is a bill which, if it is not significantly amended and amended in the terms that the Labor Party will be pursuing, ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw senators' attention to the register of senators' interests, which will indicate that my partner is a director of an industry super fund. In addressing this bill, I think four questions need to be answered. Will RSAs provide a sound investment? Will having the option of having RSAs improve consumer choice? Will they improve access to superannuation by low income earners. Whom does the establishment of RSAs benefit? Unless those questions can be answered comprehensively—and certainly in the case of the first three very clearly to the advantage of the consumer—I do not believe there is justification for this legislation to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go to the first question: will they provide a sound investment? You need to look no further than the fact that this legislation has not provided for restrictions on fees and charges to see that there is no secure investment here for people opting for an RSA. The second point I wish to make is in respect of the trustee structure. Here you have a piece of legislation advocating the establishment of superannuation type accounts, but the people who are managing those accounts do not have the members' interests at heart. This is where the real contrast can be drawn between the existing contributory superannuation schemes and RSAs where it is the shareholders of the banks and the profit margins of those banks which become the primary interest. Indeed, the banks have to take the shareholders' interests to heart in making their commercial decisions so there is an inherent contradiction here in these accounts supposedly providing for the best interests of members as their first point of concern.

On the other hand, the industry superannuation schemes provide very secure mechanisms to ensure their members' interests are at heart; that is, through their trustee system of management. That trustee system, by having both industry employee and industry employer representatives, ensures that those interests and any profits that are made are returned directly to the members' accounts.

You have already heard my colleagues talk about the reduction in national savings which will arise from this legislation. That has been established. We have also heard that because of the low rate of return on RSAs—they are low risk investments but they also have low rates of return—individuals who have their retirement savings placed in one of these accounts will be definitely financially disadvantaged. I do not believe that you can answer `yes' to the question, `Will RSAs provide a sound investment?'. The answer is no.

The second question I posed was: will having the option of RSAs improve consumer choice? The question of choice is the basis of this government's whole campaign about retirement savings accounts. Once again, we are hearing the glib exercise: `Why is it necessary to implement these? Oh, it is because of choice.' We need to look no further back than the debate in respect of the Workplace Relations Bill to see how this government is becoming quite adept at dressing up a removal of worker rights and entitle ments by stating that the question of choice has been a foremost and primary concern.

When we look at the introduction of RSAs, we are not talking about choice. We are talking about this government legislating to provide an inferior option for people seeking superannuation accounts or funds. For a start, the accounts, can be opened by employers. What happened to the quite sound principle of providing a system in which consumers themselves are empowered to make decisions about their own financial future and financial security? Surely, you need look no further than the way in which some of the industry funds manage themselves and provide information to members about exactly what the rates of return are and exactly what the particular investment will furnish those people with on retirement.

With the super guarantee currently in place, there is a requirement for employers to provide for their employees. This bill specifically undermines the intent of that super guarantee. It does that by providing an inferior product and by providing it in a way in which the employers, at this point of time under this current legislation, do not have any say in how it is put in place. The employer can open an account on behalf of the employee and, at the moment as this legislation stands, they can do it without even providing full identification. Surely, this flies in the face of principles that have been previously established.

In relation to the issue of choice, let us go back and look at the Workplace Relations Bill debate. To my recollection, an amendment was moved that ensured that superannuation was part of the essential elements of an award, of the allowable matters. This government wanted to exclude superannuation from awards. It was through negotiation, in the greatest instance with the Democrats, and certainly insistence by Labor that superannuation was indeed included as an allowable matter.

Let us speculate for a moment about where we would be now with RSAs if the government had been successful in removing the requirement that superannuation be an allowable matter. Not only would the superannuation requirement in the awards not be there, but this government then would also have a far more open ended regime to pursue retirement savings type accounts without any requirement on employers to provide contributions to a certain fund. So the answer to my second question about whether the option of RSAs would improve consumer choice is no. RSAs specifically deny the choice of particularly lower income earners as to where their superannuation guarantee contributions are placed.

My third question is: will it improve access to superannuation by low income earners? Once again, we cannot answer this question in the affirmative. There is a considerable number of moves by this government that undermine superannuation, but none is more blatantly obvious than that of providing a retirement savings type account designed quite specifically to draw funds away from industry superannuation and put them straight into the banks through the establishment of superannuation funds.

These funds are specifically targeted at lower income earners and people who get a lower rate of return with respect to their superannuation. Perhaps their superannuation guarantee is lower by virtue of the fact that they earn less money. Perhaps it is lower because they have transient employment. Perhaps it is lower because they are part-time workers. You do not need to make too many more points than that to realise that it will be women who suffer disproportionately, once again, under this legislation. The issue of gender equity in superannuation is something that had been at the forefront of the development of superannuation policy under Labor.

The industry superannuation funds quite clearly have established their product to ensure that the lower income earners, the part-time wage earners and the high proportion of women who make up those groups are directly serviced under the existing superannuation arrangements. RSAs, on the other hand, will provide a mechanism for employers to divert funds for those people into an inferior fund, into an RSA that we know is low risk and has a lower rate of return. We know that employers will have the choice to put the money there if they so choose and we know there is no assurance that the bank will not apply fees and charges to the accounts in the way there are assurances for other superannuation funds.

The next question is: who does the establishment of RSAs benefit? Well, I cannot see too many beneficiaries at all except for one. That, of course, is the banks. Most Senate colleagues have articulated quite clearly some of the motivations behind the government enacting this legislation, which quite specifically benefits only the banks.

In closing my comments with respect to these bills, I can only say that the ad hoc approach by this government to superannuation policy shows that they have no clear direction and that there is no public interest at heart here. So what is motivating this government? The timing of this bill shows, once again, a lack of strategic approach to national policy. With the Wallis recommendations forthcoming, it is very clear that enacting this type of legislation at this point in time would pre-empt a large number of the issues that are going to be dealt with or attempted to be covered in this RSA legislation. The four questions I have asked cannot be satisfactorily answered. Therefore, I do not believe there is any justification in proceeding.

One final point I would like to make about the superannuation industry funds, apart from their rates of return and their provision of services to industry, is that, because of the way they are run with the members' interests at heart, an array of benefits are now provided to members of industry superannuation schemes. They include cheap home loans, information and general education about retirement investment. They provide other insurances as well, such as death and disability coverage.

Even if there is only a relatively small amount of money put into those accounts and the government's justification for drawing the lower income earners away from the industry funds, I do not see the banks providing those sorts of services at all to those lower income earners. When we do a comparison of industry superannuation funds and RSAs, we need to look further than just the sheer financial advantage of having your money invested in an industry superannuation fund. You need to look at the other services they provide.

The distinction is that the industry superannuation funds as they are currently constructed provide those additional benefits to the members themselves. If the banks proceed with these RSAs, the incentives and advantages the bank can offer as a package do not go to the members but to the employers, who can choose whether or not to open the RSAs. There is a direct question here of equity and of who is benefiting from this whole process. When they are compared in that light, there is no way you can possibly draw the conclusion that RSAs will be of any benefit to anyone contemplating saving for their retirement. I believe that, having put it in that perspective, the government is best advised for a whole range of reasons to not proceed with this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The treatment of retirement savings is of immense national and personal significance for Australians. As Pitt the Younger, in his speech to the House of Commons introducing the first income tax legislation in 1798—almost 200 years ago—said: it is right and proper that those who have only their labour to sustain them and their families should be allowed deductions for the cost of ensuring the continuance of their incomes in case of death, disability or old age. That principle has been forgotten in recent years but it is in fact fundamentally important, and no less true now than it was then. Without properly protected means of retirement saving or life insurance, the working man or woman has no means of providing against the vicissitudes of life.

SPEECH.PARA: We will be discussing the principles of the superannuation tax in later legislation that is coming before us. I do not want to bore the Senate with my views—not on this bill, anyhow—which have been long held in those particular respects. I just want here to focus on the proper legal framework for prudential aspects of superannuation savings.

The first point to remember is in fact whose money we are talking about. It is the workers' money. It is not the employers' money, it is not the banks' money, it is not the superannuation funds' money, it is not the life offices' money—it is the workers' money. What we are talking about here is workers' money set aside for extremely important purposes—the protection of the worker and his or her family in the event of death, disability or old age. We are talking about money which is the money, in many cases, of widows and orphans.

There has been a lot said in the press and elsewhere about the high fees charged by superannuation funds. One of the arguments for retirement savings accounts is that banks can compete cheaply in the provision of savings repositories for these superannuation moneys. I accept that workers should not be impeded from choosing the best place for investing their retirement savings. If competition leads to reduced fees and charges on workers' superannuation savings, that is all to the good. I therefore have no theoretical objection to banks and other properly supervised financial institutions from being allowed to offer retirement savings accounts.

However, I might note that it would be wrong to accept what appears to be the start of a propaganda campaign that all superannuation schemes are necessarily inefficient or costly. I can speak personally of one particular scheme, REST—the Retail Employees Superannuation Trust. That is an industry scheme that is run for retail employees. It is quite efficiently run and charges are moderate. Further, because of union representation on the board of trustees, workers are better able to ensure that their funds are being properly administered.

Nonetheless, I accept that there will be cases where workers, for example, workers with frequent changes in jobs between different industries, may wish to have a retirement savings account with a bank into which they direct their employers to pay superannuation contributions on their behalf. However, if there is to be competition in the area of retirement savings, it should be founded on the basis of a level playing field in terms of accountability to employees.

There must be an acceptance of the fundamental principle that these are essentially trust funds. These funds are being compulsorily set aside by workers to protect themselves and their families. They are being held for the benefit of all workers, from the most sophisticated and well educated to the least educated. These workers are reposing their trust and confidence in the institutions into which they place their money.

It has always been accepted that the law of trusts provides proper protection where one person holds money for the benefit of another. Since the 19th century, superannuation funds have almost invariably been administered under trust deeds. The protection of superannuation beneficiaries was grounded on the full power of the courts of equity to enforce fiduciary duties of trustees to trace misappropriated funds and to compel production of accounts and disclosure to beneficiaries. The principle of trustee obligations was implemented in the life insurance act 1945, which provided in section 38(8) that every director of a life insurance company should be under the same liability in respect of policyholders' statutory funds as if he had been a trustee under a trust under which policyholders were beneficiaries.

Remember, we are talking about financial institutions soliciting funds of the public without prospectuses and that those funds represent moneys dedicated for the protection of workers and their families. This is being done without any prospectuses. Parliament has seen fit, in the past, to require that persons holding such funds accept the duties of trustees.

You have to remember also that we are talking about RSAs into which funds can be directed by employers. This is one matter on which I agree with the opposition. They have raised this in the committee. One of their recommendations, which I will be supporting, is that it will be a requirement on the employers to show that there has been agreement and direction by the employee, the beneficiary, that their funds go to a particular RSA, if that is the case.

There could be an enormous amount of pressure and an enormous number of incentives offered to the employer to make sure that all of the employees' superannuation contributions go into a particular bank which is running the RSA. Those incentives, for example, could mean a reduction in the overdraft rate of interest, et cetera. That could benefit not the beneficiary of the superannuation payment but the employer.

I consider the law of fiduciary obligations and of trustee responsibilities entirely appropriate in this context. Every person putting aside retirement savings in a financial institution should have the protection of the law of trusts. The institutions are large, powerful and well advised. They hold themselves out as experts in the management of money. Those entrusting them with their retirement savings are generally, at best, unequal in bargaining power and may often be naive or commercially unsophisticated.

For these reasons, I am strongly of the view that the law of contract, the law of debtor and creditor, should not be the sole basis upon which retirement savings accounts are based. We are told that we have got the Trade Practices Act. That is not sufficient in these particular regards. I think it ought to be recognised all round that the law of contracts, the law of debtor and creditor, should not be the sole basis upon which retirement savings accounts are based. We would not be acting responsibly in creating these vehicles for workers' savings unless we make it clear that the financial institutions accepting these funds must also accept the obligations of trustees in relation to the beneficiaries of these funds.

The noted legal historian Professor F.W. Maitland once described the law of trusts as England's greatest gift to the field of jurisprudence—interesting. The whole law of trusts is built on the concept of loyalty and fidelity to the interests of beneficiaries. Where we are dealing, as we are here in this bill, with moneys being set aside for the protection of widows and orphans, moneys being taken without prospectuses and moneys not being borrowed in a commercial context, then the law of trusts in my view should be our starting point in terms of consumer protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the contributions from the other side of the chamber on the retirement savings accounts bills, I was quite amazed. I thought the only allegation which had not been levelled at those of us on this side was that this legislation was going to confiscate people's children and sell them to Chinese restaurants, because all the other arguments we heard from the other side were rather spurious.
—Is that a racist comment?

—I can tell that one, Senator Collins; you cannot. All the other arguments we heard from the other side of the chamber were rather spurious indeed. They ignored one simple fact—that there is an inherent risk in money which is invested in the superannuation funds as they are currently structured in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to relate that the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon. Senator Kemp, and I were about five or six years ago early advocates of an alternative to the industry superannuation fund route, which the previous government was then putting into place. Senator Kemp in his wisdom recognised that the great danger with the superannuation funds was that a preponderance of the money was invested on the stock market.

Honourable senators would know that it is easy to be wise in the middle of a bull run, but it is a little bit more difficult to be wise in a bear run. The reason why retirement savings accounts need to be introduced as soon as possible is that we are about to go into a bear run. For people who are within five years of retirement, leaving their money in a currently structured industry superannuation fund could have disastrous consequences for the real value of their superannuation when they come to retirement. I think there are some wiser heads on the opposition benches that recognise this fact.

If I were in an industry superannuation fund and were to ring up today and ask what my payout is, I would only get an indicative payout. There is no guarantee that the money that would be available to me today would be available to me tomorrow if the stock market collapsed this afternoon. That is why it is absolutely critical that we have retirement savings accounts as an additional means of providing certainty to workers in terms of their retirement funds.

BREAK.PARA: If we just go down this blind route—and blind it is—of saying, `Industry superannuation is the cure for all our woes. Industry superannuation will make every Australian richer when they come to retire,' that is absolutely and utterly wrong. There are many workers in this country who have been made poorer by the existence of the current industry superannuation system. There are many workers who do not earn large sums of money and who, in fact, pay more in fees than they receive from contributions to the fund. So at the end of every month they end up poorer. That is what this legislation is aimed at correcting. This legislation is aimed at correcting that problem which was a direct consequence of the legislation introduced by those on the other side.

We are attempting to ensure not only that we provide choice and not only that people on low incomes do not have their retirement savings eaten up by fees and charges from the industry funds but also that we provide a mechanism to ensure that those who are about to retire can lock away the value of their current superannuation and be saved from the risk of having that fund eaten up by a collapse of the stock market in three months or three years. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
