TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, given that the majority of high income earners that are targeted by your new 15 per cent superannuation tax are in defined benefit funds, will you categorically rule out that any person will have to pay greater than 15 per cent of their superannuation in tax on retirement?

—Senator, as you are aware, a significant number of people will be in defined benefit funds. We are seeking to establish the actuarial standards to ensure that equity applies across the system. There are many types of superannuation funds. The purpose of the actuarial standards is to ensure that they are applied in an equitable fashion right across the system. Those standards are now being established. We are confident that the system will be applied in a fair and an equitable fashion.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. But, apparently, Senator, you are not confident that some people will not be taxed more than 15 per cent. The actuarial guidelines have not been published yet and, apparently, according to your own assistant government actuary, will not be published for some two to three months. How can the Senate support a measure to tax high income earners an additional 15 per cent when we do not have the actuarial guidelines and will not have them for some time?

—According to your leader and according to your previous statements, Senator, the Senate supports the 15 per cent surcharge. I would have thought that that was fairly clear. I understand, and if I am wrong, please correct me—
—Rule out them being affected by more than 15 per cent.

—No. I understand that your leader said that the bills would be passed. You do not have to ask me that question; you just have to knock on the door of Mr Beazley and ask whether he gave that answer. I understand that that is the case. The reality is that we have a system in place which will make superannuation fairer. We are establishing the actuarial standards to make it a fairer system. If you are worried about your own seat, Senator Sherry—if that is the underlying aspect of your question, and I suspect that it is—don't go and hide. You can run, Senator, but you can't hide. I think that was the underlying aspect of your question. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Minister, small business was on its knees when the coalition came to power a year ago. What steps has the coalition government taken to offer our vital small business sector a brighter future? In particular, what are the benefits of the government response to the deregulation task force? Will the minister explain how changes to capital gains tax are a great step forward for small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Ferguson for his question. The coalition has fulfilled an election commitment in its More time for business publication. As Senator Hill has pointed out in his answer, small business is the engine of employment growth in the Australian economy. Small business under the previous Labor government was decimated. It was decimated by interest rates of over 20 per cent. It was decimated by a rigid centralised industrial relations system. Labor had no sympathy whatsoever for small business because it was largely non-unionised. It did not feature in the accord. Small business was decimated by the unfair dismissals, which were a deterrent to employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Labor Party never understood that small business in the main started off with small equity and relatively large debt. This meant that if a business was sold to buy a new business or on retirement, it was slugged with crippling capital gains tax. There was no recognition whatsoever under the Labor Party that to small business operators their business was the major part of their retirement plans.

The government has acted strongly and positively to address the concerns of small business in relation to capital gains tax. The measures announced by the government today ensure that capital gains tax rules do not unnecessarily restrict the flexibility and entrepreneurship of Australian small business. Already the government has introduced capital gains rollover relief and exempted the proceeds on the sale of business from capital gains tax. The measures announced by the Prime Minister build on those initiatives and respond to issues raised by the small business community about the use of different business structures.

The government will extend rollover relief in respect of the sale of business assets for reinvestment to include the sale of shares in a company operating a small business. It will extend the capital gains tax exemption on the sale of a small business by an individual on retirement to include situations where the small business has operated through a private company or a trust. The government will eliminate the need for keeping capital gains records for more than five years by introducing an assets register for capital gains tax.

The measures go further than the recommendations made by the small business deregulation task force and demonstrate the government's commitment to developing a flexible and attractive environment for Australia's small business sector.

I heard Mr Beazley's response to the small business package and I could not believe my ears. When it was distilled, what he said was this, `Under Labor, small business never had it so good'—I have heard those words before—and I thought we had a new Labor Party. By comparison, in More time for business, this government has shown that it means business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what other initiatives have been taken that will ensure easy access to the government and its information?

—The government will reduce the number of forms filled out by small business and improve access to government information for small business. Mr Prosser, the minister, has said that the government will set up a single contact point between small business and government agencies and reduce the number of licences, registration forms and renewals for small business. Mr Prosser has said that small business operators spend too much time establishing their obligations and then providing the same basic information to many government agencies across the three levels of government.

BREAK.PARA: With these reforms the government has delivered on its pledge to give business more time to grow, create jobs and invest in Australia. The government will also institute a program aimed at streamlining the business licensing and approval process in cooperation with state and territory governments, with each state and territory to complete projects for at least two business activities by June 1998.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to election promises and it is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, as you are an avid surfer of the Internet, have you recently visited the Liberal Party's official worldwide web site containing the coalition's policy on broadcasting? Minister, are you aware that the policy includes the following statement on Radio Australia:

QUESTION.PARA: Radio Australia has a proud place in the ABC. It has been providing overseas services for half a century benefiting not only Australian expatriates but also the nationals of many countries, particularly those in our region. The coalition is strongly supportive of Radio Australia's existing services and will ensure that they are not prejudiced or downgraded in any way.
Minister, will you stand by this policy, or will it become just another broken promise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what is important to understand is that in our policy document we made it very clear that Radio Australia has indeed had a proud track record. If you go back over the period of many years, you will find that Radio Australia did provide a service to people who were not otherwise able to discover what was going on not only in this country but in many instances in countries in the region where access to information was quite limited.

ANSWER.PARA: What has happened in recent years, as Mansfield points out, is that since 1981 you have had virtually a technological revolution, with people relying on short‐wave radio much less than ever before. Mansfield would, I think, describe it as a declining technology and, as you well know, that is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has the BBC just recommitted to it then, Richard?

—The BBC has a very different model. The BBC World Service is actually funded by the foreign service, the foreign office, in the UK. I very much hope that, when Senator Forshaw puts down his report in the fullness of time—and, unfortunately, far too late for budget deliberations—he will at least turn his attention to that approach because that is an interesting model. I am not saying it is necessarily relevant to Australia, but the fact is that it at least demonstrates that, as far as the British are concerned, they see it as a useful adjunct to foreign policy.

ANSWER.PARA: But that was not the view expressed by the Department of Foreign Affairs in giving evidence to Mansfield. Indeed, they reflected that they could not be sure about the efficiency and the appropriateness of Radio Australia, and they had some serious question marks which no doubt led them to express a reluctance to undertake funding.

But the fact remains that there are a large number of other ways in which people get access to information in the region. Something like 100 transponder sites are, or shortly will be, available. All of these provide opportunities for people to find out what is going on in the real world—certainly through news and current affairs services. That is what is important, I think—not that some people in Europe who are expats might like to tune into the AFL, but that people who want to know what is going on in terms of news are able to ensure that they can get access to those services. They can get them from places other than Radio Australia, and I think it is important that that continues to be the case.

But from the government's point of view, as you would well know, Senator Forshaw, the policy position we announced subsequent to the election for future funding of the ABC involved a commitment to a reduction of $55 million in the next financial year. Mansfield endorsed that as perfectly do‐able, but he did it on the basis that they had to find that $55 million.

If you want to say that somehow that should not be met by something like $20 million from Radio Australia, then the onus is on you to indicate where it should come from. If your preference is to see ABC programming around Australia cut back very significantly so you can preserve a fully fledged international service, then stand up and say so. I do not think that is the view of the Australian population. I doubt very much that the ABC would see it as their top priority. The onus, I think, is on those who want to preserve these things to show how they ought to be funded. There is no magic pudding in this instance. It is very important that people continue to have access to international services. But it is just as important that the ABC gets its priorities right.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is very important also that the people can understand what your policy is, and it is clear from your answer that the policy that appears on the Internet is not what your policy is. Are you also aware that the same policy entry on the Internet includes this statement about Australia Television:

QUESTION.PARA: The ABC's international satellite television service, Australia Television (ATV), provides a golden opportunity for Australia to establish itself in the Asia Pacific region as a high quality, independent, international news and current affairs broadcaster . . .

And it further says that the coalition will `ensure that ATV has a guaranteed long‐term place in the Asia‐Pacific region'. Minister, will you stand by this policy on ATV and on Radio Australia and the commitments you have made, or will they also become other broken promises? Minister, if your policy and commitments on Radio Australia and ATV are no longer applicable, why do you not update your own Liberal Party's information on the Internet and tell the Australian people and the world the truth about your policy? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Forshaw for his belated interest in this portfolio area. Perhaps he might like to give Senator Schacht some lessons on how to surf the Internet. Senator Schacht, unfortunately, has had some very bad experiences. He has been dumped on a regular basis. Every time he has tried to get on the wave, he has found that he has fallen off completely. He has not even been able to get around to giving us his ABC submission. Maybe you have seen it and maybe you know what is in it about Radio Australia and ATV. But I do not and I would be very interested in it, because that will then be, in all its stark glory, the ALP's policy position. You had every opportunity to put it all before Mansfield—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. The question is about Senator Alston's policy, not about the ALP. It is a question about whether or not the policy he put on the Internet 12 months ago and which still sits there is still relevant today, and it is obvious that it is not.
—Order! I call Senator Alston.

—Again, the Internet is only backing up what we have already put in print, so you have got at least a couple of opportunities to compare your policy with ours. What you are saying is you do not have policies, you are not interested in policy—I understand that—but it is a very unfortunate vacuum for the people of Australia who have to make a choice. They will understand where we are going on these important issues. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Minister, last week you fudged three Democrat questions on manufacturing, so today I thought I would found out whether you are prepared to fudge an answer to the same concerns when someone else is expressing them. Minister, do you agree with the lead paragraph of a news article today, based on comments by the Chamber of Manufactures, which appeared under the headline: `Manufacturers blame budget cuts'? It says:

QUESTION.PARA: Government cost cutting in the last Federal Budget has almost halted a decade of growth in manufactured exports by the end of 1996.
Minister, will you now concede there is a problem in manufacturing industry policy—namely, that you do not have one?

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister for open‐cut mines is talking about manufacturing!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Schacht asking this question, Madam President, or Senator Murray?
—Order, Senator Schacht! It is Senator Murray's question, Senator Parer.

—This ongoing line of questioning basically runs along the line that the government has no industry policy—basically you have said that. There has been a suggestion that tariff reform has become a de facto industry policy. The rationale for these questions appears to be that, because the government rationalised some industry programs to reduce the budget deficit, there is no policy. I would be interested, Senator Murray, if you would give me the source of your information in your response because last week when you raised this question you talked about the loss of 200,000 jobs. Let me point out to you that there was a growth in employment of 20,000 jobs in manufacturing over the previous year. This takes into account a small drop of about 2,000 jobs in February. So, not the 200,000 that you keep talking about; in fact, there has been an increase of 20,000 jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: The rationale for these questions is a nonsense and belies the fact that the Commonwealth's industries policy is coordinated and comprehensive and includes the following elements: macro‐economic stability, efficient product in labour markets, promoting investment, encouraging innovation, improved market access, improving education, reducing the regulatory burden for small business, and working with industry sectors to counteract market failures and facilitate structural adjustment. The suggestion that the government has no industry policy or that tariff reduction is a de facto policy is quite ludicrous. It is more ludicrous because of the fact that we are essentially a free trading country.

This government has made policy changes which reflect differences in the belief systems of the government and the opposition. The previous government talked about getting the business environment right, but did little or nothing about it because it was hostage to vested interest. As part of our approach, we are taking on issues that are vital to business which Labor ignored for years. These are not small measures, and they will create jobs which are sustainable. I would like to repeat what I have said in the past: we are repairing the budget deficit—notwithstanding, I might say, the pressure put on by the opposition and the Democrats not to repair the budget. We have reformed the labour market, we are tackling the waterfront and we are cutting red tape.

The principal source of job creation is a thriving private sector. I think I said that last week, Senator. We are committed to providing programs that provide the support that business needs. To this end, we have established the Mortimer review to examine the grab bag of programs left behind by Labor. We will also apply sectoral policies where they are appropriate. For example—and I mentioned it last week; I have forgotten whether it was in answer to your question or not—we are committed to the future viability of the automotive manufacturing industry. Some have been running around, I might say, like Chicken Little, proclaiming the sky is falling in because the Productivity Commission is reducing tariffs on cars. Apparently the Chicken Littles have only just realised that the Bogor declaration includes cars. The question of when to reduce tariffs to meet our APEC targets is an important one which the government will be addressing after the Productivity Commission completes its report.

I can be quite clear that the issues that the government will be tackling will go beyond whether we have free trade in the year 2010 or a few years earlier. These issues, including those that the opposition never managed to come to grips with, will be fundamental to the manufacturing industry's long‐term competitiveness.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the 200,000 jobs you refer to is your target for manufacturing jobs creation. Minister, if what you say is true, how do you explain the shrinkage in manufacturing exports as confirmed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics?

—I will respond quickly. In previous questions Senator Murray has talked about job losses in the manufacturing industry. Let me remind him again that the growth in employment has been 20,000 jobs in manufacturing over the previous year. This takes into account a reduction of 2,000 in the February figure. Regarding drops in export income, there are lots of reasons for that—and these are measured, as you would know, Senator, in dollar terms—and one is the exchange rate between the Australian and the US dollar, which has gone up. I know that people in the industry that I represent—the resources industry—do not like the dollar going up; neither do people involved in the import replacement business. However, we do have a free trade in the dollar, and that is supposed to take account of country differences as they occur. But it is a nuisance. It is an annoyance to people. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, isn't it true that the 1996 coalition election promises included a commitment that, `A coalition government will deliver the government contribution of $4.5 billion into superannuation or like savings'? Didn't the Treasurer, Mr Costello, reaffirm this promise on 22 August in the House of Representatives question time, when he said, `We put them in the forward estimates and, as we said in relation to the budget, they will be paid into superannuation or like savings in an equitable way, consistent with our budget strategy.'? Minister, do you still stand by your election promise reaffirmed by the Treasurer on 22 August last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The question the senator has referred to has a bit of history behind it—I think we will recall—and it is the history of the infamous l-a-w law tax cuts. Remember those, Senator? I do not know whether you were in the chamber then, but do you remember that your government went to an election in 1993 promising to deliver l-a-w law tax cuts? Do you remember what happened to those? They were never delivered. The reality is that you could not afford them, Senator. You made the promise, but you could not afford them. Senator Sherry knows that. He is nodding over there, and he understands it. So in order to try to pretend to keep faith, you put it out seven, eight or nine years before it could be delivered. That is what you said, Senator. For a Labor senator to get up and to pretend to lecture us about l-a-w law tax cuts would have to be—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. The point of order relates to relevance. The question went to Senator Kemp on Mr Costello's promise to deliver the money into superannuation. The history is interesting, but it is your promise. Will you keep it?
—Senator Kemp, it is not a point of order, but I remind you to keep the question in mind.

—Thank you, Madam President. Indeed, I am keeping the question very acutely in mind. Senator Sherry passed this question off on to a new senator because he knew the enormous baggage that this particular question carries. It is one of the most infamous broken promises—the l-a-w law tax cuts—in Australian political history. It writ large, I think, in the minds of Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, in relation to what the government proposes to do in the next budget, you will have to wait until the next budget. You will have to be like everybody else in the community, Senator, and you will have to wait.

Mr Costello reflected on these matters on the weekend, as you will recall, and this is what Mr Costello said, `What we have said is that in our budget we have set aside some money for savings measures. When you see them, it will be on these principles.' That is the information I am able to give to you but, Senator, you will have to wait until the budget like everybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Treasurer also said in his interview on Meet the Press , `I think you can expect something far more exciting with wider application and also fairer.' Minister, how is it fairer not to deliver $4.5 billion over three years—already factored into forward estimates—to all lower and middle income Australians' superannuation accounts for retirement, when this blatant breaking of the Liberals' election promise will reduce the average Australian's retirement income by $100,000?

—I have never heard a sillier end to a question. Senator Sherry wants Senator Bishop to run his lines; get Senator Sherry to get up and run them and we will have a ripper of a debate. But Senator Sherry don't pass those types of statements off on to your new senators. Senator, you will have to wait until the budget. This government is about fairness. Unlike the Keating Labor Party, we are about fairness.
—The new tax is all about fairness; everyone is going to know about that one.

—Senator Sherry, gosh you are all over the place today. Senator Sherry, your leader has said that he supports the 15 per cent surcharge. You are all over the place today, as is usual with the Labor Party. Senator, you will have to wait until the budget before all is revealed to you.

—My question goes to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I note that the Prime Minister is travelling to China on the weekend and will meet Premier Li Peng on Monday and President Jiang Zemin on Tuesday. Will he raise the question of the repression of human rights, environmental destruction and cultural degradation in Tibet when meeting these Chinese leaders? In particular, will he intercede on behalf of the six-year-old Panchen Lama, who remains the world's youngest political prisoner, and the hundreds of other Tibetans who are at the moment in gaol in their own country in Tibet under the rule of the Chinese authorities?

—I have said before that we make representations to China on human rights issues from time to time. We do it in a number of different ways. Whether it is the Prime Minister's intention to raise these issues again during this visit, I do not know, but I take it from Senator Brown's question that he is requesting that the Prime Minister does so. I will therefore pass that request on to the Prime Minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the honour able leader, firstly, will you let the Senate know by Wednesday what the response from the Prime Minister is? Secondly, will there be cross‐trading between the economic aspirations of the Australian government in the Asian region and the matter of civil rights in Tibet?

—Senator, as I said, I will pass the request on to the Prime Minister. On the last part of the question, that really is somewhat offensive. There is nothing illegitimate for the Prime Minister of our country to visit one of our major trading and investment partners, and to advance Australia's economic interests, because that is in the interests of all Australians. Jobs, wealth creation and material advantage are not something that we shy away from. So I would be amazed if the Prime Minister does not raise these issues on this visit, particularly as he said publicly that that is his intention to do so. In relation to the substance, the first part of the question, as I said, I will pass your request on to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp as Assistant Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's interview on Meet the Press yesterday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: One of the things that we now know, as a result of the superannuation surcharge, is that a co‐contribution scheme could never have worked.
Given the Treasurer's belated admission that the so‐called superannuation surcharge has administrative difficulties, when is this going to be acknowledged in amendments to the package of legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think, Senator, that you are singularly ill‐informed.
—I watched Meet the Press .

—You might have watched Meet the Press , but I do not think you absorbed all that much. Can we get this absolutely clear with you, Senator. The Labor Party—and again you have repeated it today—supports the 15 per cent surcharge. You have indicated that you support the 15 per cent surcharge. We are waiting to see what your approach will be on the implementation of that surcharge, the collection approach, because it is very interesting that today the government had a focus on trying to get government off the back of small business and trying to assist small business.

ANSWER.PARA: What Senator Sherry has proposed—I do not know whether or not he has pointed this out to your party room—is to transfer a significant amount of the administration costs from the superannuation funds to small business. That is exactly what Senator Sherry has proposed. On this day of all days, what Senator Sherry has proposed is to transfer much of the administration to the almost one million people in small business. That is what Senator Sherry has proposed. So for you to get up—on the basis, I might say, not of great knowledge, because you do not know what your own policy is—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is far too high.
—Make him answer the question.

—We are answering the question. The question related to the collection mechanism, and what I am shocked about is Senator Sherry's approach. Has he put this through your party room—the approach he is proposing the Labor Party take? Senator Collins, when you stand up and ask me the supplementary, you might indicate that, because I can tell you that what Senator Sherry has proposed is an immensely complex scheme. It will raise the costs of small business—
—Oh, come on!
—I know you are embarrassed, Senator, but why didn't you ask the question?
—Senator Kemp, address your remarks through the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator, we have always acknowledged that there will obviously be administration costs. No‐one has hidden that fact; we have acknowledged that. But we have said that the administration of superannuation is, after all, one of the major functions, if not the major function, of superannuation funds, and they are singularly well equipped to be involved in the administration of the superannuation surcharge which we have proposed. I am shocked that Senator Sherry has proposed such a complex scheme which, above all, imposes yet again additional costs on small business. Isn't that always the way with the Labor Party?

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to go back to Mr Costello's comments yesterday but also, minister—gosh!—I ask: why then is your Liberal colleague in the House of Representatives Mr Eoin Cameron threatening to cross the floor on this issue?

—First of all, I notice that you are better on the pronunciation of names than is your colleague. I am not aware of the matter you have raised. I suspect there may be some on your own side who are a trifle unhappy, and not for entirely elevated reasons.

—I ask a question of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, about fringe benefits tax. The small business deregulation task force has found that the paperwork burden of the fringe benefits tax is crippling small business and that changes are vital to boost small business and promote economic growth and jobs. I ask: what initiatives announced today in the Prime Minister's small business statement will relieve the paperwork burden on small business, in particular those small businesses with minor FBT liabilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —How good it is to get a question on small business and the need to encourage small business in this country, whereas on this very day the Labor Party wants to impose very substantial costs on small business. Thank you for that question. It shows the difference between the Keating type Labor Party and the coalition.

ANSWER.PARA: The government believes in small business and is doing everything possible to help small business to grow, to prosper and to create jobs. Senator Hill has already discussed the substantial benefits small business is reaping from the coalition's policy. As the senator noted in his question, for years small business has been crying out for relief from the paperwork burden arising from the FBT—a cry, I might say, that was unanswered by Labor. I cannot remember Senator Schacht, the former minister for small business, ever showing any concern about this particular problem. The reality is that Labor are absolutely contemptuous of small business, and their attitude to the implementation of the superannuation surcharge demonstrates that point.

I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Prime Minister's statement earlier today announced measures targeted directly at the major criticism of FBT levelled by small business—that excessive paperwork imposed by FBT on businesses with minor FBT liabilities. The government will be introducing an exemption from FBT record keeping where an employer submits an FBT return in a base year with $5,000 or less in taxable benefits and thereafter does not significantly alter the amount and type of benefits provided. In subsequent years the employer would pay the amount of FBT established in the base year. The record keeping exemption will provide a reduction in compliance costs for small FBT players who do not make a material change in the amount and type of benefits provided each year.

Cars will be subject to the general 20 per cent variation rule under the record keeping exemption arrangements. Under the record keeping exemption arrangements, for those using the statutory formula method, the employer could continue to use the same fraction as the base year if it is reasonable to believe that distance travelled during the year has not varied by more than 20 per cent from the base year.

With regard to the operating cost method, after the base year figure is established, the employer would not be required to re‐estimate the business's usage for each year unless it were reasonable to believe there had been a variation of more than 20 per cent from the base year usage. Employers would need to continue to keep the usual income tax records and other records required for other purposes. The record keeping exemption will apply from the date the necessary legislation is enacted and will not be available for government bodies and tax exempt employers.

The government is pleased to be able to help small business by reducing the tax paperwork burden. We believe in small business and we want to help small business to grow. Labor treated small business with contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question.
—He didn't answer the first one!

—I thought he did very well, actually. It was a brilliant and clear exposition of the problem. Can the minister explain how the government will be addressing the particular concerns raised in the Bell report regarding the application of FBT to car parking and taxi travel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be addressing concerns raised in the Bell report regarding FBT on car parking and taxi travel. From 1 April 1997 small business will no longer be subject to FBT on car parking on their business premises—
—What about travel? Are you going to address that?

—which you welcome, I trust, Senator Cook. In addition, from 1 July 1997 the government will remove the provisions that denied tax deductibility for car parking for self-employed persons in circumstances where FBT would apply to car parking for employees.

ANSWER.PARA: The government will also be addressing concerns in the report that the FBT arrangements for taxi travel need to be simplified. The government will be extending the FBT exemption for employee taxi travel to cover travel to and from work at any time of the day. The exemption will benefit all businesses. This is further evidence that this government is helping small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is it a fact that Australia has a trade deficit in information technology of $6 billion a year, predicted to rise to $20 billion a year by the year 2000. In these circumstances, why has the government chopped 30 per cent off the budget for trade promotion at CeBIT, the best international showcase for Australian information technology exports? Isn't it true that these cuts are, as the Australian newspaper has put it, `sabotaging our IT export drive'? Isn't it also true that they have led to the resignation of Austrade's general manager for Europe, Mr Dieter Le Comte, and to protests from Austrade and the information technology companies concerned that Australia has lost significant ground in the international information technology market?
—Again we have a question from Senator Cook which does not specifically relate to my portfolio area. Senator Cook —The budget!

—You have referred to the trade area. Didn't you learn anything in all those years in government, Senator Cook? You stand up here day after day and pop a question over here and it goes to the wrong minister. You made that same blunder last week. Trade questions, Senator Cook, as you should know, do not come in this direction. We believe that the government has policies in place which are fair, which are equitable and which address the concerns of the community. But, if you want any specific things in relation to Austrade, I suggest you ask the responsible minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. These matters relate to budgetary outlays. I thought I was asking the Assistant Treasurer, who is in a position to answer questions on the budget. Can you explain why you have not only chopped the budget for trade promotion at CeBIT but have also slashed the export market development grant scheme, broken your election undertaking to maintain the computer bounty to the end of the century and cut the government's information technology purchasing budget? —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Following last week's confirmation of an outbreak of salmonella with two deaths and the reported pork contamination yesterday, can the minister provide any guarantee to Australian consumers that the cost cutting that has occurred in the departments and agencies which administer and regulate food standards will not expose consumers to further and more frequent dangers from contaminated foods? Can the minister further confirm that the food hygiene standards are on the agenda for the next COAG meeting? Will the minister provide an undertaking that food hygiene standards will be completed, and by what date will they be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you have asked me a question that really should be directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. The only thing I can do is give you some information that I have here in relation to the food poisoning outbreak in Victoria. I am happy to do that for you.

ANSWER.PARA: The Victorian Department of Human Services and Health released information to the Australian New Zealand Food Authority on two recent outbreaks of food poisoning in Victoria. I think that is what you are referring to. Over 100 cases of gastroenteritis have been linked by the Victorian department of human services to contaminated Vietnamese pork rolls called $2 bread. The causes of organisms have not been verified at this stage but the Springvale bakery where they were made has been closed.

In the earlier and apparently unrelated food poisoning incident, it is understood from the Victorian Department of Human Services and Health that an outbreak of gastroenteritis due to salmonella muenchen has been linked to people eating contaminated ham and/or corned beef. It is understood that the salmonella outbreaks have affected 24 people in Victoria, aged from 1 to 95 years. I am advised the investigations by the department of human services into a link between deaths and consumption of meats is continuing.

The Victorian department has indicated they believe the contamination has now ceased. The health department is monitoring these issues through liaison with ANZFA, the Australian New Zealand Food Authority, and states and territories through the Communicable Disease Network of Australia and New Zealand.

A national working party on food‐borne diseases, which working party has a secretariat in the health department, is meeting on Wednesday, 26 March to finalise recommendations aimed at reducing food‐borne illness in Australia. The recommendations will lead to improved surveillance of food‐borne illness and an enhanced capacity to respond to outbreaks. The recommendations will complement work being done by ANZFA and the proposed food hygiene reforms.

The incidence of food poisoning is increasing worldwide, including in Australia. The increased incidence is due to changing patterns of food consumption and production, changing population demographics and new and emerging pathogenic bacteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are fewer inspectors; what about the fewer inspectors?

—I will come to that, Senator. I think I am going to run out of time but I can give you afterwards a more detailed brief on this, Senator, if you wish. It should be remembered that Australia does have a safe food supply and one in which we can all have confidence. The recently reported cases represent a tiny fraction—
—A tiny fraction!

—keep it in perspective, Senator—of the total volume of foodstuffs consumed by Australians. There is cause for concern but not panic. Commonwealth, state and territory governments are acting to implement initiatives to reduce the likelihood of future food safety failures. The point I am making is that this is a cooperative effort between the federal government and the states where they have overlapping responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Commonwealth, state and territory health ministers have asked ANZFA to develop nationally uniform food hygiene regulations to replace the current disparate array of prescriptive state and territory regulations. ANZFA is currently developing a proposal for nationally uniform food hygiene regulations. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act prescribes the process for setting food standards which ANZFA must follow, including the requirement to invite public submissions at various stages of the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I am aware of the ANZFA consultation process that is under way. While I am aware that there is a federal as well as a state role in this, can you give an assurance to Australian consumers that there will be no further budget cuts to these regulatory and administrative agencies?

—Senator, as I indicated when I began answering your previous question, you really should have directed this to the Minister for Health and Family Services. So I will refer your question to the minister for health. When I get an answer from him, I will let you know.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that, under the government's proposed abolition of the CES and the creation of the one-stop shop, one in four people who are currently eligible for assistance from the CES to find work will be ineligible for assistance? Does the minister agree that spouses with working partners, recently retrenched workers in receipt of severance pay, part-time workers looking for alternative employment and anyone looking for work but not eligible for or interested in the DSS allowance even though they are unemployed should no longer be able to get assistance in looking for work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. Senator, what the government is doing in rearranging the employment services market is corporatising the CES, turning that into the Public Employment Placement Enterprise, and expanding the range of competition with PEPE, as it is called, and community and private sectors.

ANSWER.PARA: The initial level of competition between the old CES and the community and private providers was in fact started by the previous Labor government. It was one of the initiatives of Working Nation, for which we have given them significant credit. It is one of the initiatives we intend to expand so that there will be competition between the old CES and private and community providers not only for case management, or intensive employment assistance, but also for job placement services. In the past there was no competition in this area.

Senator, you have asked me whether any people will not be able to get assistance. The touch screens, which provide the general information now available in the CES, will be available to anybody, as they are now. But for benefits for which the Commonwealth pays, which are job placement services—we will be paying for those—and for intensive employment assistance for those benefits, there is a more restricted access.

It is the view of this government that it is the role of those services to assist people who are unemployed and on a benefit to get off that benefit and to get a degree of independence, because that is what getting a job does for you. It gives you independence from being dependent on the Commonwealth. So that is one of the criteria—not the only one—for those people who can benefit.

Can the wife of a wealthy job seeker or the spouse of a very successful female, who is acting as a househusband, get intensive employment assistance? No. Could they do that now? Probably not, because, as you know, case management under the previous government is not an unlimited access program. It is a capped program of expenditure. When you cap a program of expenditure, it is obvious that what you want to do is direct your services to those most in need in the first instance. That is what this government is about—giving the services first up to those most in need. Those most in need are the ones who are now on a benefit and they will have first access to the services.

One particular exception to that which I would like to raise is access to intensive employment assistance for young Australians who might be judged at risk of becoming long‐term unemployed. In their circumstances, it will not matter whether they are on a benefit or not.

There are some other variations, but the bottom line to your question is that where the Commonwealth is paying money for a benefit to be provided—that is, job placement or intensive employment assistance—the first access to that must be to those who are now on a benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yes, first access is all right, but no access is another matter. Does the minister agree that these measures will discriminate against women whose spouses are working and against workers wishing to change jobs, and that these measures will remove access for part‐time workers who wish to find full‐time jobs? In each of these cases, these people will no longer be able to use the CES.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Faulkner(from 10 citizens), Senator Ferris(from 25 citizens)and Senator Robert Ray(from 20 citizens)

BREAK.PARA: STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 AUTUMN SITTINGS

This bill amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to remove all references to "spirituous beverages" and replace them with references to "distilled alcohol". This will ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol regardless of their alcohol content.

Under item 2 of the Schedule to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Tariff Act) all potable spirits are subject to excise duty, including beverages containing spirits. Such beverages have been treated as excisable regardless of their alcohol content. Approximately $17 million in excise duty is expected to be collected in respect of spirituous beverages in 1996-97.

In November 1994, Carlton and United Breweries (CUB) commenced the manufacture of the product known as "Subzero Alcoholic Soda". At that time, the beverage was made from spirit obtained from the de-alcoholisation of beer and has approximately 5.5% alcohol content. The Australian Customs Service (the ACS) considered "Subzero" excisable under item 2 of the Schedule to the Tariff Act as a spirituous beverage. CUB appealed the decision of the ACS to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). In June 1996, the AAT determined that the production of "Subzero", with such a low alcohol content by volume, could not be described as spirituous and is therefore not excisable under item 2.

Despite this decision, the ACS is continuing to impose excise duty under item 2 on all other similar low alcohol beverages. Approximately $ 12.6 million in excise duty has been paid under protest on such beverages since June 1996. The ACS is also appealing the AAT's decision to the Federal Court.

However, if the Federal Court upholds the decision of the AAT in the CUB case, it may mean that all beverages which contain distilled alcohol and are of low alcohol content (other than those made with caramel or water) are not spirituous beverages and are not excisable under the Tariff Act. This appeal will be heard on 5 May 1997. Therefore, it is necessary to deal with this bill in one sittings to eliminate the possibility of refunds of several million dollars in excise duty having to be made to manufacturers of low alcohol beverages.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs.

All I can say is that, come 26 May, if there is no report and/or if there is an unsatisfactory outcome, I will be endeavouring to proceed with the motion. I think that, to deliver justice to these people, that is what has to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion in respect of the statement and document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the statement by the Prime Minister, together with the government's response to the report of the small business deregulation task force entitled More time for business .

SPEECH.PARA: The statement read as follows—
I have pleasure in tabling the government's response to the report of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force.
The government's response is the fulfilment of yet another election promise.

The government thanks the members of the Task Force, which was chaired by Charlie Bell, the Managing Director of McDonald's, for their work in developing a comprehensive blueprint of practical reforms to significantly reduce the burden of regulation and red tape on small business.

The Bell Report was entitled `Time for Business'. The government's response is entitled `More Time for Business'—it is all about giving small business men and women more time to be productive in their businesses.
The government endorses the great bulk of the Task Force's 62 recommendations. We have also decided on additional measures to assist small business.

Small business is the engine room of the Australian economy. Small business is an integral part of the decentralised network of family, workplaces and community which is the most effective guarantor of freedom and choice in our society. Small business is also a job creation machine. In the decade to 199495, small business accounted for 1.1 million of the 1.2 million net jobs created over that period.

According to surveys undertaken for the Bell Task Force, half of all small business operators surveyed said that a significant reduction in compliance costs would allow more time to run the business and more than a quarter saw it as increasing profitability, with benefits for economic growth and jobs.

Our aim is to get governments at all levels off the back of small business. Small business should not be bogged down in paperwork and forced to deal with a multiplicity of overlapping regulatory bodies. Small business cannot afford excessive overheads and on‐costs: the overriding priority is to maximise time for business, which will generate economic growth and jobs for all Australians.

We promised small business a new deal at the last election and we are delivering on that commitment. Our macroeconomic policies are contributing to higher national savings and delivering low inflation, which have taken pressure off interest rates and delivered lower debt servicing costs to small business. We understand, however, that many small businesses are still doing it tough in the new, very competitive, low inflation environment.

We announced in the last budget capital gains tax rollover relief which will encourage the expansion of small business. Another budgetary measure, the capital gains tax exemption on retirement, will provide a nest egg for small business owners who have been too busy ploughing all their capital back into the business to worry about superannuation. The provisional tax uplift factor has been reduced from eight per cent to six per cent at a cost to revenue of $180 million, improving the cash flow of small business.

We have swept away Labor's jobs‐destroying unfair dismissal laws. Compulsory unionism has been abolished and a new, more flexible industrial relations framework established to encourage greater cooperation in workplaces.

The Bureau of Statistics is reducing the burden of statistical collections on small business by 20 per cent. New regulations affecting business are subject to a sunset clause and we are reviewing existing business rules and regulations to abolish outdated ones.

Our response to the Bell Report builds on these achievements. The overall package involves reforms to business taxation and regulatory programmes at a cost of over $600 million over 4 years. Our willingness to fund this package in the current budgetary circumstances is a reflection of the government's strong support for the small business sector.
I now wish to outline some of the main measures.
Dealing with our complex tax system was the number one compliance issue identified by small business in submissions to the Bell Task Force.
The volume of tax legislation has become a tidal wave which threatens to overwhelm small business.

Few areas of taxation are more complicated than fringe benefits tax, FBT. There are around 55,000 small businesses that currently pay FBT, many of which pay relatively small amounts but incur substantial paperwork and compliance costs. We have therefore decided to abolish the FBT record keeping requirement for businesses which provide less than $5,000 in taxable benefits in a base year and which maintain a similar level of benefits from year to year. FBT paid in subsequent years will be based on the base year liability. This will benefit up to half of small FBT payers.

Employers would be required to establish a new base year if they elect to have the amount of FBT varied down in later years or the benefits provided increase by more than 20 per cent above the base year, or by more than $100 if this is greater. However, once they have established a new base year, they will again not be required to keep records as long as the taxable value of benefits does not materially alter thereafter.

The FBT treatment of car parking will also be reformed. From 1 April 1997, car parking provided by small businesses on their premises will be exempt from FBT. Certain provisions denying deductibility for self‐employed car parking will also be removed from 1 July 1997.
All businesses will benefit from the extension of the FBT exemption for taxi travel to cover travel to and from the place of work at any time of the day.

We will also liberalise capital gains tax rollover relief. It will now apply to the sale of shares in a small business. This will assist those small business owners who prefer to realise their interest by selling shares rather than the underlying assets of the business. This further liberalisation will increase the cost to revenue of the measure by about $90 million to around $300 million per annum.

The capital gains tax exemption on the sale of a small business for retirement will now be extended to taxpayers who operate their small business through a private company or trust. This will increase the cost to revenue of this measure by about $35 million to an estimated $50 million per annum.
These new capital gains tax provisions will apply from 1 July 1997.
The use of asset registers for capital gains tax purposes will be allowed, eliminating the need for taxpayers to keep source documents after five years.

Businesses will be better able to manage their cash flow through changes which will enable them to make voluntary tax payments at any time from 1 July 1997. The amount of time in which small companies and small instalment taxpayers can lodge their returns and pay liabilities will also be extended.
The government has not accepted the Task Force's recommendation for changes to the wholesale sales tax system, which would have involved increasing taxes for a range of goods and taxpayers.

The Bell Report recommended a review of the new unfair dismissal laws after 12 months. We support that recommendation but have decided to go further in recognition of the particular difficulty small business has in dealing with complex industrial relations requirements and our concern to stimulate employment, particularly youth employment.

Businesses with 15 or fewer employees will be exempt from the Federal unfair dismissal provisions for new employees until they have been continuously employed, whether full time or part time or on a regular casual basis, for 12 months. This will give small business every encouragement to hire new staff confidently, particularly younger, less experienced employees. Safeguards will remain. Small businesses will still be required to provide the statutory minimum period of notice on termination and to satisfy the provisions of the law preventing dismissal of employees on discriminatory grounds, such as pregnancy.
I will be writing to State Premiers to encourage them to adopt similar provisions in their jurisdictions to provide the maximum boost possible to small business employment.

Also, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will be required to improve the system for parties in terms of when and where industrial matters, including unfair dismissals, are dealt with. This will be particularly relevant to small business.

Small business cannot afford the time or expense of dealing with multiple regulatory authorities, including duplication by different tiers of government. The former Industry Commission found, for example, that a proprietor of a small hotel in one jurisdiction had to be familiar with 12 separate statutes and six codes of practice just to be sure of complying with state and Commonwealth occupational health and safety laws. Business regulation should be as efficient and streamlined as businesses demand of their own operations.
We will establish a single registration process for the Australian Taxation Office, Securities Commission, Bureau of Statistics and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission by July 1998.

We will work with state and territory governments to develop a single point of entry for all levels of government through which business can obtain information on all government requirements and programmes.

Over the next four years we will create a comprehensive national business information service, including a business regulation free‐call service, streamline business licensing and approvals processes and merge similar licenses into single, `common' licences. These initiatives, which will cost around $23 million over the next four years, will result in considerable savings in compliance costs for small business.

The preparation of regulation impact statements for all Commonwealth legislation or regulation that has the potential to affect business will be mandatory. The costs and benefits of regulation will be weighed up carefully to ensure that the putative benefits are not outweighed by excessive economic and financial costs, including the compliance burden on business. The Assistant Treasurer will be given the authority to enforce these rules.

A tangible demonstration of the government's determination to avoid unnecessary increases in the regulatory burden on industry was our recent decision not to implement privacy legislation for the private sector at the Commonwealth level. I also raised the matter at last week's Premiers' Conference. I have asked the Premiers and Chief Ministers not to introduce such legislation at the state level. Queensland and the Northern Territory have already agreed to our request and the other states will consider the Commonwealth's request further. I will be writing to the states to set out our concerns.

In cooperation with state and Territory Governments, the Commonwealth Government will be accelerating processes to reform regulations in the areas of food, agricultural and veterinary chemicals, building codes, occupational health and safety, workers' compensation and the environment.

The former Industry Commission has estimated, for example, that savings of $350 million a year could be made from more efficient building regulations and a further $750 million from improved planning. Our reforms will reduce overlap and duplication, encourage greater national consistency and simplify processes. We will not be pursuing uniformity for its own sake. The aim is to achieve lower compliance costs for all businesses, large and small.
The government recognises that small business must have adequate access to finance if it is to grow and prosper.

Apart from its reforms to capital gains tax and provisional tax, the government has made it easier for banks to invest equity capital in business by changing prudential guidelines on equity investments and making the tax treatment of equity investments in small and medium‐sized enterprises more attractive.
We have now decided to go further to encourage our small technology‐based firms. The high risks and long time horizons in the high technology sector justify targeted assistance.

We are setting up a Small Business Innovation Fund, under which up to six early‐stage capital funds will be established to invest in more than 100 small technology firms over five years. The Commonwealth will provide $130 million from the R&D Start programme and private sector fund managers will be responsible for finding matching private contributions on the basis of $1 of private capital for every $2 contributed by government. This will provide up to $200 million for investment in this growing sector over the next few years. This support will provide more jobs and exports in this important and growing area of the economy.
Mr Speaker, during the election campaign, we committed ourselves to the goal of reducing the burden of paperwork and red tape on small business by 50 per cent in our first term.
I am confident that our response to the Bell Report, along with other initiatives that we have already taken, will make a substantial contribution to that objective by the end of our first term.
As evidence of the government's good faith, we are establishing objective performance indicators which can be used to measure our efforts by June 1999.

The new package will require the ongoing commitment of governments at all levels and regular feedback from, and constructive dialogue with, small business if it is to work. I appreciate the willingness already indicated by Premiers and Chief Ministers to cooperate on matters involving Commonwealth‐State regulation.

We recognise that we can never meet all of the expectations of one sector of the community. We have kept faith with small business and gone further in some areas than we promised. We also know the ongoing challenges which small business faces and that our small business policies must be subject to a process of continuous improvement. That is why I pledge that my government will keep listening to small business and acting on what we hear.
I commend the government's response to the Bell Report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1997 I informed the Senate that the Speaker of the House of Representatives and I had decided to implement a management structure for the parliament based on the two chamber departments. I indicated that the Speaker and I had asked the departmental heads to provide us with an implementation plan and that they had established a working group to suggest detailed arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now received the working group's report entitled Managing the Parliament—the way ahead. We have also received some written comments, which we regard as basi cally being related to the detailed implementation stage and which will be considered during the consultative period. As a further step in the consultative process, the Speaker and I invite written comments from members, senators, staff, staff associations and other interested people on the proposals in the report. All comments will be most welcome and should reach my office by Monday, 14 April 1997.

No doubt there will be questions about the working group's proposals and other aspects of this matter. However, I believe it will be more appropriate to canvass these issues after senators have had the opportunity to fully consider the contents of the report. Of course, as is required by resolution of the Senate, I will also be consulting the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. I table a copy of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

My statements will be brief. I am a little concerned about the timing of this announcement today. There is obviously a lot of interest in the outcomes of the report entitled Managing the Parliament—the way ahead . In the invitation for people to make their presentations by 14 April, we now notice that if today's noting of the announcement is put on the Notice Paper , it will fall off during this sitting, so we will not see it again until after May.

I am not sure at what point decisions will be made as to what will happen as a result of the public consultation process. I am just disappointed that the ability for the parliament, in particular the Senate, to make comments on the report now becomes almost irrelevant unless the actual decisions for any changes will not take place until perhaps somewhat later or further on in the process.

I have not seen the report—and it might be my fault for not seeing it—but I would like to express my disappointment that the timing of today's report by the working group means that, whilst people can make written comments, there will not be any actual debate within this chamber before some further decisions might be made along the process. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I would comment upon that. We are taking advantage of the April period of non-sittings. The Speaker and I felt that it was important that the document be tabled and made available now while we are still sitting, asking for comments by the date in April that I mentioned so that they be can be examined over the further period of the recess. I can assure you that it cannot proceed without coming to this chamber. The Appropriations and Staffing Committee, if need be, is a safeguard for the Senate and for the process. It will be looking at the matter not before we resume on 2 May.

SPEECH.PARA: Is leave granted for Senator Margetts to continue her remarks? There being no objection, leave is granted.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
