TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the undertakings which I gave on 6 and 18 March 1997, I present to the Senate two reports by Senate department officers on a crosscheck of records of travelling allowance payments made to Senator Colston, with records of Senator Colston's travel held by the Department of Administrative Services. I also present a response by Senator Colston to the reports and associated correspondence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 March 1997 Senator Faulkner asked me whether the Australian Federal Police had communicated with officers of the Department of the Senate in relation to Senator Colston's travelling allowance. I provide the following answer to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: An Australian Federal Police agent met the Clerk and the Clerk Assistant (Corporate Management) on 4 March 1997 as part of the police assessment of four allegations made against Senator Colston by a former staff member. No investigation as such was under way. Allegations were being assessed.

None of the matters raised related to travelling allowance claims. They concerned allegations already in the public domain about the use of postage stamps, the use of postage franking machines, the activities of electorate staff and the declaration of gifts. It was explained to the Australian Federal Police agent that electorate franking machines and staff are matters for the Department of Administrative Services, and that the Department of the Senate had no evidence of misuse of postage stamps and was unaware of any abuse by Senator Colston of the rules concerning declaration of gifts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 18 March 1997, I present, on behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services, a document setting out details of travelling allowance payments made to current and former ministers, certain office holders, leaders and deputy leaders of the opposition in the Senate in those capacities for the period 1 January 1992 to 3 March 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Before I commence my remarks, Madam President, I would indicate, on a point of order to you, that I think there is an understanding across the chamber that this debate take place for one hour, with obviously limitations to speakers as per the standing orders.

The first document tabled today, in my view, outlines a systematic abuse of parliamentary entitlements by Senator Colston. The first Senate report identifies some 16 occasions on which Senator Colston claimed travel allowance for overnight stays in Canberra when the travel records show that he was not in Canberra. Those 16 occasions relate to 23 overnight stays, the payments involved totalling $3,230. Madam President, the second report that you have tabled today identifies a further eight similar discrepancies in Senator Colston's allowance claims. They involve some 12 overnight stays, and the overpayments there are some $3,065. The total in the two reports comes to $6,295 being falsely claimed and paid.

But the documentation that we now have before us also reveals a report by the Department of Administrative Services—a report, as I understand it according to this documentation, that Senator Colston has had in his possession since 5 March. That identifies a further seven discrepancies relating to Senator Colston's travel claims, and these involve eight overnight stays.

The reports that you have tabled today contain irrefutable documentary evidence that, while Senator Colston was claiming travel allowance for being in one place, he was actually in another place. There is nothing in the information that you have tabled, and there is certainly nothing in Senator Colston's limp defence, that in any way convinces the opposition that what we are dealing with here today is anything other than deliberate and systematic abuse of Senator Colston's parlia mentary entitlements. To make one or two mistakes would be understandable, to make half a dozen mistakes could perhaps be put down to carelessness, but to make 31 mistakes for 43 overnight stays is neither understandable nor attributable to carelessness. In my view, and in the view of the opposition, it does represent deliberate and systematic abuse. I go to my comments in this chamber last week. I said:

The Senate is entitled to know whether the irregularities and discrepancies are merely mistakes by the Department of the Senate or poor staff work by all of Senator Colston's employees or whether they constitute systematic fraud against the Commonwealth.

I said then that the only possible reasons for these overpayments could be mistakes by the Department of the Senate or, as I have said, poor staff work by Senator Colston's employees or systematic fraud.

In the light of the report that we have before us now, it is absolutely clear that this extraordinary number of breaches is in no way due to mistakes by either the Department of the Senate or the Department of Administrative Services—and, I might say, not even Senator Colston suggests that that is the case. It begs the question: could this be due to poor staff work? It is no surprise that that is where Senator Colston lays the blame. He expects us to believe that the fault lies with a staff member—a Mrs Christine Smith. Quite frankly, that just does not wash. This is the same Mrs Smith whom the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) moved heaven and earth to promote. I suspect that if Mr Howard is the only person in Australia willing to swallow this sort of pretence, he will just as quickly—again without any due regard for proper process—move to demote the same Mrs Smith. I think that everyone in this chamber knows what we are dealing with here and who is at fault. It is the person who signed for each and every one of these claims. It is the person who banked each and every one of these payments. It is the person who wrongfully claimed taxpayers' money over and over again.

Madam President, We should all bear in mind that the reports that you have tabled, damning though they are, are very narrow in scope. They simply match two sets of documentation that are available to the Department of the Senate to check Senator Colston's whereabouts against his claims. They are limited in the period they cover and they are limited in the number of claims that they cover. Frankly, they raise as many questions as they resolve. I think we can now understand why the government protected Senator Colston and opposed the opposition's move to reconvene the estimates committee to pursue these issues. We can see why the government just opposed the motion that I moved to have the DAS report tabled.

It is an extraordinary situation, I believe, that Senator Colston himself, with a clear interest in this, came into this chamber to defeat a motion to have these reports tabled, reports which he has had in his possession—according to the documents that you have tabled, Madam President—since 5 March. There are number of loose ends that have got to be tied. For example, the Department of the Senate points out in relation to each of the incidents it identifies:
Potential additional supporting evidence may be available from airline passenger lists on relevant flights.
This evidence must be obtained. We also note the comment of Mr Holt, an officer of the Department of the Senate, in the second report:
In addition to the above,—
that is, the two reports that we referred to earlier—
there are a number of potential irregularities on which the department is awaiting further advice from DAS.
The Senate is entitled to be informed of the outcome of those investigations and those irregularities. Details ought be tabled in the Senate.

I have said it before but let me say it again: it is time to end this farce. It is time for the government—particularly the government—to stop pussyfooting around. Madam President, it is time that you put this matter in the hands of the competent authorities. I ask you, on behalf of the opposition, to hand these reports that you have tabled in the Senate today to the Australian Federal Police without delay for a full and comprehensive investigation and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been through this a number of times before, and I guess now we are all very familiar with what is going on here today. The Labor Party is determined to hound Senator Colston out of office for reasons to serve its political benefit. It sought to do it in the short term to demonstrate that it requires a loyalty within its party—`We will not truck somebody—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You acknowledged it. You said in this place the other day that anyone who resigns from the ALP is guilty of treachery and must be punished as such. You said it the other day, and now you are embarrassed by the fact that you said it. You are embarrassed by the fact that you said that he will be punished for this treachery. That is primarily what the ALP is interested in. But, of course, it is also—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner was listened to in silence, and Senator Hill should be also.

—The Labor Party is also interested in the future in regaining a Labor number in this place. It is interested in the future—after it succeeds, it hopes, in hounding Senator Colston out of office—in ultimately getting a Labor appointee back here. As I said on the last occasion we went through this, if the Labor Party were serious about this matter, if the Labor Party were as principled over its years in government as it now claims to be, what has it done about this matter for the last 10 years in all of these issues?
—You appointed him Deputy President in 1990. Bob Collins voted for him.
—I'll answer that, Senator Campbell.

—Let us run through them. Who were all the ministers for administrative services during this time? Hey? They were Labor. Was somebody tapping Senator Colston on the shoulder then? No, they were not. So why the change of principles now? Why the conversion? They did not care about sloppy bookkeeping when they controlled the levers. Why the conversion now? The conversion now is, firstly, because they want to punish what they see as treachery and, secondly, because they want to get the numbers back in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections. Senator Faulkner was heard, and Senator Hill is entitled to be.

—They say, `Address the report.' What you have put down today, Madam President, certainly shows plenty of evidence of sloppy bookkeeping. There is no doubt about that at all. The interesting thing, which the Leader of the Opposition did not want to acknowledge, is that that was admitted by Senator Colston.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He says, `I wish to make it perfectly clear at the outset that these overpayments were caused by an inadequate bookkeeping system, which was in place at the time in my electorate office,' et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting. What seems to have happened in most instances is that Senator Colston, unlike most of us, appears to have stayed in Canberra over weekends from time to time. On a number of instances over this period of four-odd years, it looks as though, for example, on Friday nights—most of them seem to be Friday nights—there was a claim.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them—as I said, Senator Ray—are claims to have been in Canberra. Most of them seem to relate to days that he was in Canberra but, because it was a Friday night in these instances, he had returned to Brisbane. That is sloppy bookkeeping. There is no doubt about that. The sloppy bookkeeping has been acknowledged by him and by his staff.
—Say it with a straight face.

—Senator Faulkner comes in here and he says this proves fraud. He says this proves a `deliberate and systematic abuse'. I would say it does not prove a guilty intent at all, because there is an explanation that has been given that is totally consistent with the facts that have been tabled in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is embarrassing. I acknowledge that it is embarrassing for Senator Colston. It is embarrassing for his staff.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections in the chamber.

—You suffer a political consequence for that sloppy bookkeeping. There is no doubt that Senator Colston would suffer a political consequence for this. But it is not on the face of it what Senator Faulkner claims, and that is evidence of a deliberate intent to defraud.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Colston said here, it is interesting. There is only one person in this place who has been audited in this way, and it is him. Without wanting to compare it with the facts of anybody else, you come in here and you look at these facts and you say, `For four years there have been a number of instances, particularly on a Friday night, where the records do not substantiate it.' In Canberra, yes, but not here overnight. Therefore, he should not have claimed; he did claim. The acknowledgment has been given of it.
Do you want me to go through what was said by the staff member? The staff member said:
On a number of occasions I gave the senator an incorrect list of the dates for his travelling allowance claims. The senator accepted the dates I provided to him as being correct.

You can say that he should not have; that he should have gone back and double-checked all the dates of his staff. You can say that. His failure to do so, you could say, should be at some political cost. The explanation is totally consistent with the facts that have been put before this place.

In different circumstances you may have sought to draw different conclusions, but you have to put it to the background of the pros ecutors in this instance. The prosecutors in this instance—Senator Ray, Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr in particular—are hounding Senator Colston with the sole purpose of getting him out of this place as punishment for leaving their party and in order that he might be replaced by another Labor person.
Madam President, they have succeeded to the extent that they have caused an audit to be taken, which is highly embarrassing to Senator Colston. This audit has shown errors in the—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did you know?
—Senator Carr, your lot controlled the books, not us. You were the ones who controlled the books.
—Was it part of the talks to get his defection?
—Your lot had the Minister for Administrative Services. Your lot looked after the purse.
—The Senate department paid it.
—Your lot paid the TA, Senator Ray—your lot.
—The Senate.
—Your President of the Senate. Whose President?
—The Senate.
—Labor President! Labor administration.
—Order!

—Madam President, they have succeeded today in further embarrassing Senator Colston. There is no doubt about that. He is embarrassed. His staff are embarrassed. They have had to own up to sloppy bookkeeping. They have had to own up that, as a result of that sloppy bookkeeping, he was in certain instances overpaid TA. As you will see from these documents, as soon as that has been demonstrated, he has repaid this money.
—Forty‐three cases that we know of.

—What we know, Madam President, is that on one previous occasion there was a difference between Senator Colston and his Minister for Administrative Services—and who was that, Senator Carr? That was Mr Beazley, wasn't it? Now Leader of the Opposition. So what did they do?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Madam President. What did they say? They said: `There is no evidence of guilty intent. Therefore, we'll take the cheque and that is the end of the matter.' That was all right for Labor. Senator Carr, what is the difference? What is the difference now? In both instances—
—You are in government. That is the difference. You backed him as Deputy President.
—Senator Collins!

—No, I don't condemn Mr Beazley, because, if there was no evidence of guilty intent, the step that Mr Beazley took was correct, you see. Mr Beazley acted properly on the evidence. Right? The money was repaid and the matter was ended.
—Do you know that?

—I've got a fair idea of that. So, Madam President, the double standards of this lot are extraordinary. If they were not double standards, you could draw different conclusions. There is no credibility in the case they bring when they acknowledge that their motive is the repayment of treachery. This document stands as it is and it is a reasonable explanation of the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think this debate is about whether the coalition government is going to deal with this in a more appropriate way, although I look forward to the answer to that. I think much of the debate about these reports tabled today and other reports somewhere out there goes to the heart of whether Senator Colston is a fit and proper person to be the Deputy President of the Senate, and deserving of the Howard government's support in that important role.

SPEECH.PARA: The responses tabled, while narrow, are in fact very revealing. Senator Colston's response has been, as has been pointed out, to simply lay the blame squarely on one of his employees, Christine Smith, and to make a monetary repayment. I, too, note that Ms Smith is the same staff member who has been the recipient of the salary package upgrade. One might have thought that efficiency would be a component in a promotion. I think it is very odd that for 3½ years a person can be administratively inefficient and still be capable of being on the receiving end of such an important promotion.

This report is very narrow in that it deals only with the allegation that Senator Colston claimed travel allowances for stays in Canberra when, according to Comcar and airline records, he was elsewhere. The report identifies 31 occasions relating to 43 overnight stays during a 3½‐year period when Senator Colston falsely claimed a travel allowance for nights in Canberra. The total cost, according to the Department of the Senate, was $7,580. At the end of this report, there is a photocopy of a cheque from Senator Colston for $6,880. Whatever else Senator Hill might want to say about sloppy bookkeeping, it seems to me that 43 overpayments in 3½ years cannot be legitimately explained away by inadequate bookkeeping or administrative error.

When Senator Colston was reconciling the dates from the list given to him by Ms Smith and transcribing that on to the form that he signed himself, it is inconceivable that he did not look at a calendar and notice that so many of these were weekend dates and ask himself the question: was I really in Canberra for all these weekends? That is a question that would occur to me.

This report does not examine the distinct possibility that further illegitimate claims or further bookkeeping errors may have been made in respect of travel outside of Canberra. I suggest that a perusal of the records suggests that this is quite plausible. This report also does not look into numerous other allegations against Senator Colston, in particular those specifically raised at estimates committee by Senator Ray: the use of Comcar services; the misuse of travel allowance by his son, Douglas; and allegations of misuse of parliamentary entitlements including postage. We know why. We know that there is a big question mark over who is responsible for the administration of these matters. Nevertheless, I think people out there listening to us would wonder why we are only having this little focus on nights spent in Canberra.

I think this report is deficient in that it fails to comment on the undeniable pattern of either unnecessary or unwarranted travel as a member of various committees. Surely this is the responsibility of the Department of the Senate. Just from reconciling the information on this matter that we do have on the public record, a very clear pattern emerges. For example, take the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. Four external territories visits have been made since 1993, for a total of 33 days, by Senator Colston.

The only other senator to claim an external territories visit was former senator John Coates—and that was for six days, two of which were for committee hearings. There was an external territories visit for six days in November 1993 tacked on to the end of a committee hearing. There was an external territories visit for 11 days in January 1994—11 days on Cocos and Christmas islands, three in Perth and then off to Norfolk Island for another four days for the committee hearing. There was an external territories visit on 24 September 1994 for eight days, but ironically Senator Colston missed the committee hearing in Canberra on 23 September 1994. There was another one for eight days in January 1996.

On the matter of a pattern being established: in the two months prior to Senator Colston being replaced as Deputy President, for 40 days and 40 nights—which has some religious significance at this time of the year—Senator Colston travelled on either office holder or regulation and ordinances chair business: two days in Hobart, six in Launceston, 12 in Canberra, six in Melbourne and nine in Sydney. I wonder whether that had anything to do with the fact that his travel allowance at that time was worth $300 a night and it was about to fall, after his loss of that position, to $190 a night! I do think you can look at these matters; they are relevant.

On the matter of the regulation and ordinances committee: in 1993-94 Senator Colston spent 11 days on regulation and ordinances work. Only one other committee member joined him for two of those days. In 1994 Senator Colston found a great deal more interest in regulation and ordinances work; he went from 11 days to 25 days. In 1995-96 that grew to 36 days. Only one other member of that committee—again, Senator O'Chee—claimed, and he claimed for two days but in a different city and at a different time from Senator Colston.

In four years Senator Colston has claimed 75 days as the chair of the regulation and ordinances committee, compared with five days of claims for all other committee members. That is compared with 40 days of claims for Senator John Watson, who has been running 17 full inquiry references in the important superannuation select committee. Why have these matters not been commented on? I am happy to receive an answer on that from you, Madam President.

The other issue is the Department of Administrative Services' report. On 25 February—that is one month ago—when Senator Colston's alleged misuse of Comcar was revealed on Channel 9, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, told the ABC PM program and Channel 9 that DAS would be commencing a full investigation. On 20 March the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Kemp, confirmed in an answer to a question from Senator Ray that, yes, DAS was preparing a report on the misuse of Comcars and parliamentary entitlements and that Senator Colston would be given the opportunity to respond to that report when it was ready.

Today the government, Senator Harradine and Senator Colston himself voted against a motion to require that this particular DAS report be tabled by 5 p.m. tomorrow. Why does the government refuse to table this material? Why isn't the Australian public entitled to all the relevant information being brought together, not dribbled out bit by bit to try to draw your conclusions here and there?

I have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) say that this matter should run its course. Why is the DAS report not ready after one month? Why should it not be available to all of us in conjunction with this other important report which is being tabled today? I ask Madam President and Senator Kemp to give an answer to this question to the Senate, because I do not think that taking a cheque for a second time from Senator Colston is the appropriate or accountable way.

If this government is serious about accountability and trust in the system, then taking a cheque for the second time is not acceptable nor appropriate. Mr Howard, in my view, has to reply to this parliament about what he intends to do with the cheque given to the Collector of Public Moneys by Senator Colston. Madam President, I would like you to answer this next question at some stage: when can the Senate expect to see the DAS report?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Hill comes in here and says, `This was due to poor bookkeeping,' you could probably believe that that was the case for 74 senators in this place. But, as Senator Colston's ex-staffers will all attest, the first duty Senator Colston attended to for a period of up to two hours when he returned to his electorate office was to fill out his financial journal, in which he filled out every possible claim for travel allowance, every possible tax deduction and every transaction he had committed up until the last time he was in his electorate office. He would not receive phone calls, he would not see constituents and he would talk to no-one until he had completed that task. So I do not think Senator Hill will get a refresher fee today for producing poor bookkeeping as the excuse.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill also said, `Why single Senator Colston out?' Well, excuse me; I thought Senator Colston requested this inquiry—albeit it was only after he found out that you, Madam President, were holding one that he enjoined in the case. So he should not complain about being singled out when he in fact requested such an inquiry. But then, in classic Senator Colston methods, he says in his report, `I want everyone else audited.' Haven't we all heard that before when it comes to the publication of figures!

BREAK.PARA: Let him make an accusation. But I am sure every one of the other 75 senators here will, if an accusation is made, take the first available opportunity to defend themselves in this chamber. All of us may have made mistakes in the past; who knows? And I think the leader was right to say, `You could expect two or three mistakes over five or six years.' But not to this extent.

I will not repeat the figures, but I will go to one set of figures alone. According to the second report, Senator Colston has falsely claimed four nights in Melbourne and four nights in Sydney within a couple of months of each other. That is eight nights and $2,400. Do not tell me that when that was put before Senator Colston—and he physically, as he says in this document, transcribed it on a form—he could not remember spending four successive nights in Melbourne and four successive nights in Sydney. Not even the most busy minister would come up with that excuse. I hate staying a night in Sydney. How could you forget four nights there, and how could my home city, the glorious city of Melbourne, be forgettable when you have spent four nights in a row there? It is just not believable!

Let me say something about the methodology of this inquiry. If there is an implicit criticism of the Senate department, I do not intend it, but this was a very limited inquiry. This inquiry did not go back past 1 July 1993, and it should go back to at least 1990, because the Collector of Public Moneys will get a great dividend if it goes back that far.

The second limitation of the inquiry is that only six months of interstate travel has been checked thoroughly by the department. So there is another minefield there of about seven years to be gone through to see what other mistakes have been made. The third methodological error, the classic error—I do not think the Senate department would have contemplated this till this report came out—is that they have checked only the nights Senator Colston was in Canberra and when there was countervailing evidence he was elsewhere. Given these 43 nights, it may be time to check for evidence of whether Senator Colston was in Canberra on the several hundred other occasions when there is not that countervailing evidence. At least airline bookings and Comcar records should now be checked to see whether he ever came here or just hid up in Queensland and put in his claims. That is a big task, I admit, but that is logically where the next set of inquiry should go.

I repeat that, from a methodological point of view, these inquiries failed to go back past July 1993, failed to look at all the interstate claims other than for a six-month period and failed, if you like, to try to verify all those other claims in Canberra when Senator Colston may have used no other parliamentary entitlement elsewhere but still claimed for Canberra.

As John Faulkner indicated, we might believe up to six nights mistakenly claimed. How can we believe 43? I will make a prediction, Madam President. If you order your department to go through all the interstate claims and all the Canberra claims to seek evidence, this figure will go from 43 to 100. Clearly it will go that high. At the very least you would be fulfilling a public duty by ordering such an inquiry because the Collector of Public Moneys will be a major beneficiary and so will the taxpayers of Australia.

Let me come to the issue of blame. Senator Hill has asked why any minister for administrative services had not done something about this years ago. Of course, he ignores the fact that travel allowance in this case is paid by the Department of the Senate and therefore it is its responsibility. He ignores the fact that there was no visibility on these claims until you, Madam President, reinforced President Beahan's decision—both of you to your credit—that there be full visibility for Senate claims. This is the reason why Senator Colston tried, in a sneaky way, to head this off by getting it referred to the Privacy Commissioner: because he could not undo all the claims he had made and therefore the visibility was there. Senator Hill has to be joking when he talks about DAS ministers. They did not pay the travel allowance.

While we are on that subject, DAS has done an inquiry. DAS has in fact put two pieces of advice to its minister. It has put the accusations against Senator Colston to Senator Colston, and it did so as early as 5 March. It told the press that these matters would be tabled in the House of Representatives at the same time as this report was produced last week. But uh, oh, change of plans. Do senators know why there has been a change of plans? If senators think this report is red hot, they should see what DAS has found. It is five times as red hot as anything in this report. Naturally DAS will give Senator Colston until 18 April to respond, because that will keep him locked in here a lot longer than he otherwise should be.

In one way I am not sure that that DAS report should be tabled here. I disagree with some colleagues. I think it should go straight to the Australian Federal Police and the prosecutor for his or her evaluation straightaway. Undoubtedly this Senate report should go to the AFP, and undoubtedly the inquiry should be broadened for the following reason in addition to the others I have outlined: the airlines and some staff in this building will not cooperate unless it is the Australian Federal Police making the inquiries. That fact is known. I do not think it will be contested. The airlines should and would be required by the Federal Police to examine these issues to a much wider extent than they have been in the past.

There are some peripheral issues here to do with travel allowance. I am still waiting for some sort of answer on what travel allowance was paid to Senator Colston by the Australian National University. They are like the Kremlin over there: maybe they are right; maybe they are wrong. All we know is that privacy rules say they cannot declare anything. We have Senator Colston's own words in the newspaper that he did in fact claim travel allowance from the ANU, but we do not know how much or when. He never declared that as a source of income on his pecuniary interest form. He did, however, say that he had given all that money to needy students. I want to know when he gave it to needy students.

I also want to know whether he deducted that off his tax. If he claimed off his tax the $145 that this parliament paid during all those times he double‐dipped, he would have received about $154 back. He was on a nice little earner, as Arthur Daly would say, of $295 a night by going to the Australian National University National Council and pretending to do regular regulations and ordinances committee work or some other work. He turned up at the external territories committee hearing for two minutes on a day he had claimed $145.

At the end of the day, the defence of Senator Colston will be that these are merely a few series of mistakes. Given the background of the avarice of this individual and given the background of repeated offences—Senator Kernot was wrong; he has filled out at least four cheques, to my knowledge, but who's counting?—it is very hard to plead that this was because of poor bookkeeping, his staff mucked up or something else. This is the only individual who has been able to work out the complexity of claiming travel allowance on Norfolk Island, and those opposite are telling me he cannot fill out forms correctly when he has claimed 777 days in four years.

Madam President, send this to the Australian Federal Police. Wash your hands of it and send it straight to them now. Your clerk said he would give you advice on this. It has not been received yet, obviously. You should do that straightaway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what seems to be forgotten here is that this is entirely a vendetta driven exercise on the part of the Labor Party, obviously aided and abetted—
—He is your boy.

—No, not our boy at all. It is aided and abetted by people who seem to be prepared to give Senator Ray information that is not in the public arena and to tell him about all sorts of things that are going to be revealed later on.
—Eh?

—Well, he just said that the next report is going to be five times as red‐hot as this one, so he obviously knows a fair bit about what is going on. He claims that there have been a number of repayments. I am not aware of it; I am not aware that is even in the public arena. But if that were the case and if it were known to certain individuals, including former ministers for administrative services, you would have thought they would have wanted to put in place procedures to ensure that mistakes did not happen, that irregularities were detected, so that people were not simply allowed to go on, for whatever reasons, continuing to receive moneys that they were not entitled to. Instead, what we now seem to have is all of a sudden twenty‐twenty vision in hindsight and we get into the big persecution business.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing particularly sinister about this being a report confined to certain matters. If you really wanted to have it go back over a period of time or address more issues—or even, as you now seem to imply, if you do not even accept at face value that Senator Colston was here during parliamentary sittings, from the sound of it—then all these matters could have been raised by you. You have trawled through everything in the estimates committees. You could have put those questions on notice. You could have written letters—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are still waiting on answers!

—And you know you will get those answers, presumably, through the relevant ministers. But, instead, what you are wanting to do is just keep dragging it out, just keep dribbling it out bit by bit. Somehow you think you can encourage a crescendo of fabricated outrage.

SPEECH.PARA: What is most unfortunate about this whole exercise is that the Labor Party came in here with a predetermined response to your report. In other words, they proceeded on the basis that there was evidence of irregularities—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie and you know it.

—I will demonstrate it in a moment. They came in here on the basis that there was virtually no defence to what they understood to be a series of irregularities. Senator Faulkner simply threw around a lot of words like `systematic and deliberate abuse', and then he changed the wording to `deliberate and systematic abuse', `falsely claimed and paid' and `systematic abuse of parliamentary entitlements'. That is all very colourful language but it does not in any shape or form address what is actually on the public record. When Senator Colston says, through his staffer, that matters were put in front of him and that he was simply signing what he understood—
—No, he says he filled them out. You read it.

—All right. I know you have done nothing else but pore over this. We will proceed on the basis that he filled in the forms. He filled in the forms on the basis of information provided to him by someone else. And you then say, in effect, `Why should we believe Ms Smith?' In other words, it is the old conspiracy theory. Ms Smith puts down an explanation which you do not like so you disregard it. You say, `Clearly it is fabricated.' You are not just saying that Senator Colston has fabricated it, you are saying that she has fabricated it, because—
—She's been forced into it. He bullies all his staff and you know it.

—So that is the explanation, is it, that he basically twisted her arm and she came up with an explanation which you do not like to accept and therefore you say no‐one else should accept. That is what it boils down to, does it? In other words, irrespective of the evidence, irrespective of what is on the record, you have come in here determined to proceed on the basis that there can be no credible explanation. Where you get egg on your face is that there is a credible explanation and you are not in a position to do anything about it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is really what it comes down to—that, if there were evidence of a guilty intent, as those on the other side would like to suggest, that would be a basis for your saying that there may be matters that deserve further attention. But where you have matters of irregularity raised, the person in question is given an opportunity to respond and he provides an explanation on the record, then what are you left with? You are left with explanations on both sides, neither of which amounts to the very sorts of things that the other side would say justify it being referred to the Federal Police.

Senator Kernot says there is an undeniable pattern. Presumably that is something less than `deliberate and systematic abuse', but what does `pattern' mean? All that is really being said is that 31 claims were made in almost four years, and Senator Kernot therefore wants to say that that constitutes a pattern. A pattern therefore implies something deliberate and systematic. So she shies away from using your words but the effect is still the same. Unless you are prepared to say that there is evidence of deliberate and systematic abuse or fraud—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it to the police.

—There is simply no basis on which you can refer it to anyone. On what basis would you do it? Let us be clear on this. There is a series of examples of what are called irregularities. There is then an explanation which is perfectly credible on its face but, because you put an interpretation on it of deliberate and systematic fraud, you say that is the basis on which a matter should be referred to the Federal Police. I have never heard such a test in all my years. I defy anyone to demonstrate that that is a basis for referring a matter to the police. We all know that that is a very serious secondary step to take. And what basis would you do that on? You would do it if there was evidence to confirm or corroborate the proposition for which you argue.
—You're happy for Bob Woods to be investigated.

—I would have thought that everyone is entitled to their rights in a matter like this. You are saying it is not a civil matter, it is a criminal matter. I ask you on what basis a matter should be referred to the Federal Police. I say it ought to be referred to the Federal Police where there is evidence to corroborate what you argue for, in other words, evidence of deliberate and systematic fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: But you do not say that. You say, `That's the interpretation we would like to place on it. And because we think that is the case, off it goes.' I do not think that is the basis on which this Senate should proceed. These are very serious issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't even read the report.
—Have you read it?
—I am not up there speaking.
—Well, why are you complaining? I have read it.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm sorry, but I have to confess I have read it. I have read it and I have seen the explanations. I have seen that there is no evidence to corroborate the proposition of deliberate and systematic fraud. There is, quite to the contrary, an explanation on the part of a secretary that you do not like. That is your real problem. There is an explanation there that you do not like. You want to wish it away. I don't think Senator Ray even addressed that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray talked about a whole range of things—veiled threats about one thing or another—but I don't think Senator Ray ever addressed what Mrs Smith said in her statement. Did he? Did you say something about Mrs Smith? No, you didn't. In other words, you weren't interested. You wanted to give us a few snide references to the number of cheques you are aware of that were repaid. We are not aware of that, but you seem to know all about it. You are the one who gets the leaks. You are the one who seems to be fed on a regular basis. What you are interested in is beating it up, keeping it going, throwing around as much mud as you can.

As you, the vicious viper from Victoria, say, this is a vengeance exercise. Nowhere did you address yourself to the very sort of thing that is critical in determining whether the matter goes any further. In other words, if there had been no explanation given, you would say, `Here we are: on the face of it irregularities. Has not been able to answer it. Off it goes.' But when you get an explanation, the trouble is that you do not like it, so you pretend it does not exist. You do not even talk about it and then you want us to proceed on the basis that somehow it should not be believed. It is a very tawdry exercise. Senator Hill has eloquently explained the political motivations for it. I think the public will understand that as well. If you have not even got the decency to address the defence, then you do not deserve to be taken seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us today two reports of the three that are actually referred to in this report. I think that has to be understood by all who are actually participating in this debate. There are three reports but we have seen only two. We have seen within those reports some 31 claims involving some 43 days of what I say is systematic and deliberate fraud. We see in the Sun‐Herald of yesterday a report that Senator Colston will not face charges. Who told the Herald‐Sun that Senator Colston will not face charges? What is the level of protection within this government to ensure that Senator Colston will not face charges?

SPEECH.PARA: What we are also told is that a full and frank and believable explanation will be forthcoming. I am afraid we might all be disappointed here because we have not had a full, frank or believable explanation of these events involving some 43 days of claims which are not proper within the terms of the guidelines and, I say, not proper in terms of the law.

This is a case where, quite clearly, the President has an obligation to refer these issues directly to the Federal Police. We have before us a senator who has yet to come into this chamber and explain his position. What an extraordinary proposition, that the Senator concerned has chosen not to come into this chamber and give a full account of these matters.

We have a senator with a PhD, but not a PhD in form filling. It might be a PhD in many other things, but not in form filling. We cannot expect a bloke like Senator Colston not to make a few wrong entries. Essentially, that is the claim being put before us. What it suggests is that his staff are responsible.

The senator said in the Sunday Telegraph of 16 March, two days before the last deadline for presentation to this chamber, that he believes he is innocent and will be cleared of any wrongdoing by reports tabled in the parliament `this week'. He well knew that there was a letter to the President being drafted at that time seeking a further delay of one week. At the same time, he was telling the press that he would be cleared by those reports tabled in the chamber, reports that he had had for some weeks.

He informed the Sunday Telegraph that he had never attempted to be secretive. The evidence is quite to the contrary in respect of the way in which bookings were made, remade, cancelled and re-entered into the system. Throughout this report you see quite deliberate actions being taken to disguise the travel arrangements that in fact were made. The senator also says that when questions were raised, `I voluntarily submitted my records to the Department of the Senate.'

The senator concerned sought these inquiries. He sought to cooperate with these inquiries. The report quite clearly indicates that there were 43 occasions on which payments were made which ought not to have been made. He also said on 16 March he that always checked his Senate staff himself. That was the claim made two days before the last deadline.

Further, we see the explanation given today. What is the defence? The defence rests on the proposition that it was not his fault; it was his staff's fault. It was his long‐suffering staff. I have heard some pathetic explanations and weak claims being made, but to blame the staff I think has to be the worst. It is as good as the old one about always being misquoted in the press. It was not the things that you said; it was the way in which you were misquoted. It fits into that sort of category. In the documents before us today, Senator Colston acknowledges:

I do not offer Mrs Smith's explanation as an excuse for these overpayments occurring. I accept that I am ultimately responsible for ensuring the accuracy of any claims which I have made. However, it is an explanation of how these overpayments occurred and clearly establishes that there has never been any intent on my part or any member of my staff to claim travel allowances for which I was not entitled.
What the form indicates quite clearly—this is the form each and every one of us must fill in—is a certification by the senator concerned. This form states:
I certify that the information provided above is true and accurate and the claims I have made comply with the provisions of Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 21 of 1995.

That is the basis on which the claims have been made for some years in this Senate. To turn around and suggest that the forms were filled in incorrectly by the senator himself and that they were based on information provided by staff, incorrectly, of course is not an appropriate basis on which to proceed.
The Usher of the Black Rod made some comments in the public arena about these matters. He said:
It would appear, from the airline schedules from Senator Colston, that he was in one place when his travel allowance claims suggest that he was in another.
At this stage, the Usher indicated:
It appears that the allegations can be proven on the documentations. I would imagine that Senator Colston has a case to answer.
Of course, nothing could be clearer than that statement. How accurate that statement is.

What this ultimately is about, however, is not just one senator rorting the system. It is not about one senator seeking to fraudulently make claims which he has no entitlement to make. It goes much deeper than that. It goes to the basis on which this government has behaved. It goes to the issue of the basis on which this government organised Senator Colston's defection from the Labor Party. It goes to the question of how the matter was arrived at in which this government was guaranteed its legislative program, in which a whole series of important pieces of legislation were to be able to gain passage through this chamber. It goes to the issue, ultimately, of the integrity of the Senate. That is why I put to you, Madam President, that the real issue here ultimately goes to that integrity.

It is your responsibility, I contend, that this matter be referred to the Federal Police. It is a matter that this government ought to take up, given that it is a government that asserts that it is interested in proper integrity and that its legislative program should be above question when it is carried by this chamber. You, Madam President, have the responsibility to ensure that senators behave properly and that the legislative program of this government is not corrupted by a process which we have seen in recent times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, the sad truth is that the Deputy President of the Senate is guilty of longstanding, systematic and deliberate fraud of his Senate entitlements. That is the sad truth. Christine Smith, this poor staffer, who has been set up to take the rap for this, may well have been responsible for some mistakes. Unfortunately for Senator Colston and fortunately for her and her integrity, all of Senator Colston's claims have to be seen in the context of all the other claims that he has made.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, I am rising in this debate purely and simply as a former chair of your regulations and ordinances committee. It is a committee, as you know, of international repute. It is a committee that sits only when the Senate sits. It is a committee that still meets for only half an hour every sitting fortnight. It sits for 30 minutes—
Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It still does, Senator Hill—I took the trouble to inquire. I would not try to defend Senator Colston on this one, Senator Hill. In the 2½ years that I chaired that committee, I do not believe that I can recall submitting a single claim for travelling allowance as chair of the committee. It never occurred to me to do so. There may have been a few nights for the rare conferences that the chairs of that committee have to attend.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Kernot has already laid out, in 1995 Senator Colston made a whopping 36 nights claim on the regulations and ordinances committee—32 of those claims as chair of the committee. Is it possible—even remotely possible—that anyone could even come close to justifying that extent of claims on that committee? The answer is—and you know it, Madam President—that it is not. In the 10 years preceding Senator Colston's chairmanship of that committee, four other chairs submitted an average of two to three nights claims a year—that is in the decade prior to Senator Colston. When Senator Colston took over that committee, as Senator Kernot has rightly said, he incrementally increased those claims until, in 1995, he put in a whopping 32 nights. There is a pattern there as well—Sunday, Monday; Sunday, Monday.

Madam President, let me say this to you very directly, and I am saying this to you directly as President: there are two high public offices in this place, and you know it—President and Deputy President. And they are high public offices indeed. I am not talking about Senator Colston remaining in here as a senator. I am addressing this debate purely and simply in his position as Deputy President.

Senator Colston deliberately and systematically defrauded his Senate entitlements as chairman of regulations and ordinances. Madam President, you know what that committee does, you know what its chairs do and you know that Senator Colston is not fit to continue as Deputy President of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the following reports: sixth report entitled The Oakey Agreement: Australia and Singapore and seventh report entitled Australia's withdrawal from UNIDO and treaties tabled on 11 February 1997 , together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings for both reports. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

The two committee reports I am tabling today have both domestic and international importance. Report 6 deals with the agreement between Australia and Singapore to locate a helicopter squadron at the Army Aviation Centre, near Oakey in Queensland. We recommend early ratification of this agreement.

Report 7 is an omnibus report that examined a number of matters. The most significant being Australia's withdrawal from the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO) and a double taxation agreement with Vietnam.

The Oakey Agreement covers the location of a Singaporean helicopter squadron at the Army Aviation Centre to conduct helicopter flying training activities, supported by approximately 250 Republic of Singapore air force personnel and their dependents, and will include the establishment of purpose built on‐base at a cost to Singapore of approximately A$30 million.

There is wide spread support for this agreement amongst the local communities of Toowoomba and Oakey. Both local councils believe that the presence of the Singaporeans will provide significant economic benefits to the local communities. In addition to the A$30 million capital investment, on‐going annual maintenance requirements will be in the vicinity of A$5 million per year, with a further A$9 million per year injected into the economy through the expenditure of Singaporean salaries in the Oakey/Toowoomba area.

Evidence presented to the Committee by three individuals opposed the agreement. We noted, however, that this opposition came from outside the Oakey/Toowoomba area. Issues raised included concerns over religious allegiance and the stationing and training of foreign troops in Australia. The Committee rejects completely any suggestion that the Singaporeans would not be welcome on the basis of race or religious affiliations. We concluded that the evidence presented by the local communities supporting the agreement, and the benefits in general to Australia, far outweighed these objections.

The first issue dealt with in our 7th Report was Australia's withdrawal from UNIDO, initiated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in December 1996. Binding treaty action was taken by the Minister in this case before a full fifteen sitting days had elapsed for parliamentary review of the proposal.

Given the need for immediate action to avoid future funding obligations, it was not possible to consult fully with all interested organisations and firms before the decision was effected on 31 December 1996. However, the report emphasised that consultation ought to be undertaken before such decisions are announced.
The Committee noted other recent withdrawals from UNIDO, including Canada (1993), the United States of America (1995) and most recently, the United Kingdom (1997).

Australia first joined UNIDO in 1985 but in 1987 the Government of the day made the decision to withdraw from the organisation. In 1989 the Government agreed to review Australia's withdrawal from UNIDO, and on the basis that organisational reform had occurred and that potential procurement activities were available to Australian firms, agreed to rejoin the organisation in 1992.

In January 1996, UNIDO had a broad membership of 169 member states. In the last twenty years, the organisation has fielded more than 16,000 projects and generated investment for nearly 2,000 joint industrial projects. While UNIDO focuses 40 per cent of its aid activities in Africa, more than a third of the organisation's technical cooperation expenditure is devoted to Asia.

The Committee heard evidence not only from departmental representatives, but also from UNIDO and the principal industry beneficiary in Australia, Hassall and Associates Pty Ltd. Departmental evidence indicated that membership of UNIDO was not considered to be making a contribution to Australia's priority development objectives, the impact of UNIDO country‐level programs remained unsatisfactory, and the funding obligation to UNIDO did not represent value for money.

UNIDO emphasised to the Committee that it felt membership of the organisation met both Australia's aid objectives and geopolitical interests. While insisting that Australian firms would not be excluded from UNIDO procurement activities following the withdrawal, the organisation did concede that internal political pressure may influence the selection of future procurement sources. As the major financial beneficiary, this issue was of concern to Hassall and Associates. At the public hearing, the company articulated a concern that future opportunities to win UNIDO contacts would be severely restricted by Australia's decision to withdraw financial support from the organisation.

The Committee also acknowledged the significant reforms that have taken place within UNIDO, particularly in the areas of management processes and the reduction of administrative overheads. However, apart from a relative small number of firms benefiting from Australia's membership of UNIDO, there have been very few other tangible procurement benefits resulting from membership.

We therefore noted the governments decision to withdraw from UNIDO, but recommended that any savings from the withdrawal be redirected to other areas of the aid program where they can be more effectively utilised.

In the limited time remaining I would like to comment briefly on the double taxation agreement with Vietnam. While the Committee supports early ratification of this agreement, I wish to stress that we were concerned over a number of issues. These concerns included the lack of consultation between the Australian tax office and professional accounting bodies, and the quality of the National Interest Analysis (NIA) that accompanied the agreement. We were particularly concerned that the NIA not only omitted necessary information, but was also unduly complex and difficult to understand.

We also noted that this agreement excludes banking, insurance, accounting, auditing, and commercial services. The Committee concluded that, should Vietnam change its approach and amend its laws, which caused the exclusion, there should be a renewed effort through negotiation with Vietnam to remove this exclusion.
I commend these reports to the Senate.
Debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 22, page 31 (lines 18 to 22), omit paragraph (a), substitute:

(a) in a case where a telecommunications network is used to supply a carriage service to an end‐user in a building by means of a line that enters the building—the point agreed between the customer and the carrier or carriage service provider who operates the telecommunications network, or, failing agreement:

PARA.TAB: (i) if there is a main distribution frame in the building and the line is connected to the frame—the side of the frame nearest to the end‐user; or

(ii) if subparagraph (i) does not apply but the line is connected to a network termination device located in, on or within close proximity to, the building—the side of the device nearest to the end‐user; or

(iii) if neither subparagraph (i) nor (ii) applies but the line is connected to one or more sockets in the building—the side nearest to the end‐user of the first socket after the building entry point; or

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 22, page 31 (after line 34), after subclause (4), insert:

(4A) If, immediately before 1 July 1997, the boundary of a telecommunications network used to supply a standard telephone service to an end‐user in a building by means of a line that enters the building is the side of a main distribution frame, or a telephone socket, nearest to the end‐user, paragraph (4)(a) has effect, on and after 1 July 1997, as if the customer and the carrier or carriage service provider who operates the network had agreed to the boundary at that point.
(4B) Subclause (4A) does not prevent the customer and the carrier or carriage service provider agreeing to a boundary at a different point.
(3) Clause 112, page 108 (line 1), after "22(2)(d) or (e), insert "or (4)(a)".

These amendments in relation to the network boundary arise out of the earlier discussions we had and some further talks. The effect of these amendments is to retain the status quo for existing customers and to give additional customers the option to seek further changes in the location of the boundary at their premises and to ensure the customers are informed that they have a choice and about the consequences of any change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would prefer it if Senator Margetts formally withdrew her amendments which have been moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendments 1 to 3 during the debate showed that there was a great deal of confusion within the government but also that there was likely to be a great deal of confusion amongst present and future consumers in relation to network boundaries. I am pleased to see that—as a result of this debate and I am sure from communication from a number of groups suggesting something similar—there has been some rewording by the government. I am happy to withdraw my amendments Nos 1 to 3 and indicate that I will be supporting the government's proposed amendments Nos 1 to 3.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments, by leave, withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we are pleased to support government amendments (1), (2) and (3). When we deferred this issue several days ago last week, I think we got a good outcome. As Senator Margetts said, in the discussion that took place in the Senate, it became quite clear that there were some issues, particularly about consumer rights, that the new proposed legislation would not address. Amendment (2), subclause (4B) states:

BREAK.PARA: Subclause (4A) does not prevent the customer and the carrier or carriage service provider agreeing to a boundary at a different point.
This means that the customer can be advised that there may be advantages to them to shift the boundary point. Subclause (4A) ends with:
. . . on and after 1 July 1997, as if the customer and the carrier or carriage service provider who operates the network had agreed to the boundary at that point.

I believe that we have the balance about right. I hope that the carriers or carriage service providers accept their responsibility in providing adequate information to customers. We do not want customers finding out by default at some later stage that the boundary point, unbeknownst to them, has been shifted. We do not want consumers to be told, `We put a notice in the local throwaway newspaper that this was happening in an area,' or `A bit of junk mail was sent out written in obtuse language that no-one could have understood.' The result of that would be that people will be left high and dry as far as maintenance is concerned regarding the new boundary which may be from the kerb into the customer's residence or flat.

I think this is a very good balance. I hope the carriers and the new ACA monitor the operation of these arrangements with customers so that customers get appropriate information about their rights in this area. If they do, I think this could work very well. Maybe in two or three years time the parliament can further review it. In the meantime, I think we have the balance about right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Democrats support government amendments (1), (2) and (3).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is ironic that I did not move many amendments to this bill in the committee stage but that both of them ended up getting reworked. However, it is a good sign. Once again, my amendments in relation to public interest have been looked at by the government. They are proposing another amendment in their stead. TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

—I am therefore happy to withdraw Greens WA amendment (4). I signal that I will be supporting the government's amendment to clause 111.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the amendment circulated by the government and notes that the Greens are accepting the government's amendment. Again, I think that is a very useful outcome. I trust that, in the new regime post‐1 July, when the new industry codes will be drawn up after public consultation, all those processes are understandable to the common lay person in Australia. I hope that we do not have an obtuse, legalistic document that is very difficult for ordinary people at the community level—when they get hold of one—to understand. This is not just a problem of this government; it has been a problem for a long time in telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, the opposition hopes that the new ACA can draw up these codes after public consultation in a layman's form of words that is demonstrably understandable to the community without having to employ a legion of lawyers to interpret it for them. That would be a very useful step. It is not a criticism I make particularly of this government but of the history of telecommunications. We have often made up documents that make it very difficult for the ordinary citizen to understand exactly what the code means and how it operates.
