TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have had the debate on the Democrat amendments. This matter was postponed. I assume this was because the government wished to consider it further or to propose another amendment. I am happy to go through the arguments again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 173 (after line 24), after clause 216, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 216A Benefits for customers outside standard zones

SPEECH.PARA: (1) For the purposes of this section, if a customer of a carriage service provider is in Australia, but is not in a standard zone, the customer is a designated customer .
(2) The regulations may formulate a scheme to give benefits to designated customers, where the benefits:

PARA.TAB: (a) relate to charges for calls made using a standard telephone service supplied to the customer; and
(b) are comparable to the benefits given to eligible customers under section 214 (which deals with the requirement to provide an untimed local call option).

SPEECH.PARA: (3) For the purposes of subsection (2), a comparison of benefits is to have regard to (among other things), the ability to make calls to essential business and community services on an untimed basis.
(4) Regulations made for the purposes of subsection (2) may impose requirements on carriage service providers.
(5) A carriage service provider must comply with any applicable requirements imposed by regulations made for the purposes of subsection (2).
(6) The Minister must take all reasonable steps to ensure that, at all times on and after 1 January 1998, regulations are in force for the purposes of subsection (2).

(7) For the purposes of this section, charges for particular calls are worked out on an untimed basis if, and only if, the charges for those calls are worked out by reference to the number of such calls made during a particular period, regardless of how long each call lasted.
This amendment, which deals with benefits to customers outside standard zones, should have been circulated in the chamber.

The government is concerned that a small number of people in Australia do not have access to untimed local calls on the same basis as the majority of customers. This amendment provides for a scheme designed to give customers who do not have access to untimed local call charging benefits comparable to those available to customers under part 8 of the bill.

The amendment provides that regulations must be made and kept in force to provide a scheme to give benefits to customers outside standard zones where those benefits relate to charges for calls by the customer and are comparable to the benefits available to beneficiaries of the untimed local call obligation under part 8.

In providing comparable benefits for isolated customers, regard would have to be had, amongst another things, for the ability of other customers to make calls to essential business and community services on an untimed basis. The scheme would, in effect, provide that these customers can get the equivalent of an untimed call rate to their relevant major service centre. The scheme would be required to be put in place by regulations from 1 January 1998. This ensures that the scheme is implemented promptly but recognises that, given the complexity of the issues involved, a reasonable time will be required to develop sensible and sustainable arrangements.

This approach does ensure that all people in Australia will effectively gain the benefit of untimed local calls. However, that benefit will be provided in a manner that is considered, taking into account the views of interested parties—notably the customers themselves—and is practical and cost‐effective.
I indicate for Senator Schacht's benefit that the government would certainly have no objection to a review of the workings of this process to ensure that we remain on track.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister explain in what way this differs from the Democrats' amendments. It seems to have picked up a number of them. Are there any points that the government has not agreed to in these later amendments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The best way to compare the two is to say that the Democrat amendment would essentially treat the customer as the centre of the calling zone rather than the local exchange, which is the normal basis on which telecommunications call zones are drawn. That, of course, can lead to a multitude of complexities, depending upon the precise physical location of customers and the obvious very extensive overlap. Because of those technical difficulties, it is the view of the government that that simply would not work with any degree of equity, whereas the government proposal effectively ensures that every customer will get the benefit of an untimed local call.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I rise to support the government's amendment. As I understand, in terms of what the common vernacular of people reading all these transcripts and listening to this may be, there are people in remote or regional areas of Australia, as Senator Allison quite rightly demonstrated, who have no access to any local untimed calls. Her amendment, which the government has adapted here, proposed that those people will have access to an untimed call to a service centre for the first time. I think this is a commendable initiative for the parliament, and the government has done well to pick it up. The opposition is very keen to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased, Minister, that you have given an undertaking in both this area and also another area which the Democrats raised, whereby someone who was in a defined local call zone in a rural area had to make an STD call to, say, another service centre in another local call zone in a rural area where their natural service centre was for local government, et cetera. The Democrat amendment initially enabled them to go from one call zone into another call zone within a certain radius for a local untimed call.

The government, in private discussions I have had, has indicated some technical difficulties in trying to deal with that. Though I think it is commendable what Senator Allison raised, it is clear that there are some really technical difficulties of trying to write into legislation those arrangements across from one local call zone to another where you might accidentally wipe out a lot of regional zones and might not achieve it, except at some significant cost to revenue as well as the capital cost of implementation of equipment for Telstra, who would have to bear it.

I am pleased, Minister, that you have given an acknowledgment that these matters will be reviewed at an appropriate stage over the next year or so by the ACA. That is a very clear commitment, which we welcome. I am sure that regional and rural Australia will welcome it as well.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, in the last few hours there have been informal discussions with your advisers—and I have appreciated their cooperation. I just wonder whether the government has any amendment to move in this area. There was a suggestion that you may be interested in having one. If you have, I would like to look at it. I do not think anything has been circulated. As the government does not appear to have an alternate proposal, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 216, page 172 (lines 21 to 23), omit paragraph (a).
As the significance of this amendment is not explained on document sheet No. 443, I will explain it now.

This amendment removes the distinction between `residential' and `business' for business data calls.This issue raised its vigorous head at the Senate inquiry. As an opposition we made comment that we would support that, in the `local loop'—as it is called colloquially—where there is the local untimed call rate, there should not be a time charge put on ISP, Internet service providers, and other data information flowing between users.

However, Telstra argued strenuously at the hearing that this will lead to congestion, overuse and a distortion in its charging rates and those of the system. Telstra said that in the end, through this unnecessary congestion and overuse because of there being this untimed local call rate for business, it may have to invest more money, keep charges up elsewhere and there may be an enforced cross‐subsidy coming from domestic users to subsidise business users.

When that evidence came before the Senate committee, it was immediately challenged by a range of witnesses. I do not expect the government or anybody else, myself included, to automatically agree with everything that was said by the witnesses who, when they came before the committee, disagreed with Telstra; I do not automatically say that they got it right either. But I do have to say that in the committee hearings Telstra, in my view, did not prove its case that congestion was about to clog up, close down and stop the telephone system in Australia through overuse of Internet providers and data information being transferred and communicated around in the local loop area.

BREAK.PARA: Evidence was given by some of the other witnesses which showed, I think, that was not the case. For example, in response to the idea that Internet users would be clagging or clogging up the exchange, to use a non-technical term, some witnesses pointed out that so far most Internet users are active at times of the day when there is spare capacity in the telephone exchange; people are using their Internet connections during the late afternoon, into early evening, into late evening. The peak times for business through the telephone exchange, of course, are during business hours—late morning, early afternoon, after lunch, and so on.

So far Telstra has not been able to show that those periods of high use by normal business were automatically being affected by the use of Internet providers and others. In fact, it was pointed out that Telstra was actually getting more business at times it had spare capacity in its telephone exchanges—that is, in late afternoon and early evening—and, therefore, that was beneficial for Telstra in that it was getting a better balanced revenue base on its investment. The people who said that may not be correct. But, certainly, I found that Telstra could not refute that evidence which was given by a number of witnesses.

Of course, the ISP people, the Internet service providers, do have a vested interest, their own self-interest. They do not want to get charged on the basis of timed calls in the local loop for accessing Internet. But, Minister, I also have to say that today is the day the government has released its small business statement, outlining a number of ways to promote small business. Internet over the next few years—as you yourself know and have said in a number of speeches—will be one of the big boons for small business in Australia and the world, enabling it to directly communicate its services and information to potential customers in a very cost efficient way.

If we automatically start to charge now, before there is evidence to show overuse and congestion, we will be stifling the development of small business—a growth area for jobs in Australia; an area where the growth of small business can be enhanced not only in the cities, but even in regional areas. Of course, when communicating from one call zone to another, a timed rate will be paid.

We in the opposition believe we should remove this distinction so that business people, such as Internet service providers, are guaranteed for the future until the government, on behalf of Telstra, can put evidence before us that there is congestion, overuse and abuse. Until that is proven, I do not think we should find them guilty. I do not think we should say, `Well, in three or five years time we think there will be congestion.'

Some of the evidence I have seen is that the growth which will occur in this area with Internet means that Telstra has a wonderful new business stream coming on which will be to its advantage in new revenue, in straight volumes, even at an untimed rate in the local loop. Telstra should be encouraging Internet service providers and those other services which are to come from the broadband and on‐line areas.

Another area of the evidence was of concern to the opposition. I asked, `If you put a timed rate on data information, how do we know that a normal fax machine, using a normal voice telephony system in a local loop, would not be accidentally caught by a timed rate?' Again, it was unclear in the evidence from both Telstra and other experts—there was a dispute about it. I thought it would probably be a very popular thing for an opposition to accuse a government of accidentally forgetting this. But I do not think it would be good for the community to suddenly find that, although they presumed what was being faxed was within a local call zone—remember that, in the metropolitan areas of Australia in particular, that is one side of Sydney to the other, one side of Brisbane to the other, one side of Melbourne to the other, and so on—our putting in a device to catch business data transmission meant we could also accidentally catch fax machines operating at the local level, and that they were paying a timed rate. I have to say that would be something that would send a lot of small businesses broke. But, above all else, many residential people are now operating their own faxes from home.

The final point in all this is the growth in the number of self‐employed people or micro‐businesses. I must say, as a former small business minister, that one of the most exciting developments in job growth in Australia is the number of micro‐businesses and the number of people working from home, particularly women. A higher proportion of women start micro‐businesses, are self‐employed and work from home. They have to have access to not only a telephone but also an on‐line fax. That will enable them make their businesses grow.

I do not think we ought to put the brakes on right now and say, `Well, we're going to start charging you a timed rate'—even accidentally—`for a normal fax machine.' Therefore, unless there is any other amendment for consideration, I believe this amendment is one of the most important amendments this chamber should support in favour of small business. As I said, the timing of the amendment is coincidental—on the day the government released a major statement to help small business. This amendment would be a very useful thing to support to help small businesses in the Australian community. I commend the amendment to the Australian Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support the opposition's amendment. I remind the Senate that this amendment was put forward by us in December last year. At that time the opposition said they would not support it, but that this would be the appropriate time to raise it, and they have done so. I thought it would be interesting today to read into Hansard some of the correspondence that has been received by all our offices on this matter of the Internet. I think this was one of the better ones. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra are pulling a shonky over timed Internet calls. At a recent Senate inquiry they threw in a big red herring. They showed proof that domestic call peaks coincide with Internet use. Well, so what? Domestic calls do not make a big difference to overall peaks. Internet traffic is just one per cent of the total domestic and exchanges are designed to carry 14 per cent of all local users at any one time. The real con lies here. The minister has said that local calls won't be timed—fine—but the telecoms act does not prevent Telstra timing business calls, nor does the minister's guidelines. Here's the catch: the telecoms act allows Telstra to charge for incoming calls. Since the Internet providers are business customers, Telstra can time the calls and charge accordingly. This cost will then be passed on to the users. So, in effect, the user pays once to establish the call and then pays by time—a huge con. Worse still is the fact that the minister is aware of this loophole. The red herrings at the inquiry were there to throw the senators off the scent.

I do not wish to add too much more to the debate than that. We will support the opposition amendment, as I have already said. To repeat something I think I said in my speech at the second reading stage, the Internet service providers are probably dominated by small Australian businesses. I would have hoped that we could encourage those businesses to grow and to provide real competition in Australia by Australian owned and operated companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak in favour of this crucial amendment. The issue of timed local data business calls is something that goes to the very heart of this developing technology called the Internet. The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) has taken some great pains to speak in favour of the importance of this developing technology. I would like to take the next few minutes of the Senate's time to articulate why it is so crucial for this amendment to be passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that, in the big scheme of things with technology, how this data is transferred is absolutely crucial. Telstra's role in the costs imposed upon these data calls can have the impact of determining just how available these services are to consumers. At the moment, there are several hundred Internet service providers in this country. The issue at hand for them is how competitive they will be in the context of this particular issue going through. I put to the Senate that, unless this amendment is carried, this will render those ISPs unable to compete successfully against services provided by Telstra's big pond Internet services. I say that on the basis that you would need to go no further than to look at how Telstra charge for their big pond Internet access and how that relates to the Internet service providers. In questions that we placed on notice at additional estimates, I asked the question:
How does Telstra calculate their own ISP service bandwidth usage in applying indicative costs for market share or comparative purposes? Please supply these figures.

What I was hoping to extract from Telstra is how they remove themselves from being in direct conflict with the ISPs by providing some sort of once-removed process to ensure that true competition could prevail. I think the response says a lot. Whilst it was not a direct answer to my question, it gave us an insight as to what we are dealing with in respect of this issue. The answer provided was as follows:

Telstra's ISP service connects to Telstra's big pond direct service as a customer paying standard commercial rates in accordance with publicly available tariff, as do non-Telstra ISPs. It has multiple connections to several big pond direct points of presence.

What that says is that any customer, residential or small business, has the opportunity to connect to the big pond service on the same terms and conditions as an ISP. If this does not add an additional layer for ISPs in terms of competition, I do not know what does because, in addition to just providing an Internet access service, the ISPs give a lot more to the community than just that access point. What the ISPs provide is a whole range of content provision services.

I think to say that Telstra does not have an inherent advantage by virtue of the fact that it is providing an ISP service to the community—the same as the existing independent ISP services provided—but has no such way of accounting for that indicative layer in between the two points, shows that Telstra does have an advantage and that, if this amendment does not go through, it will perpetuate that advantage.

So, Minister, I ask you to look at it in that context. You need to go no further than what Telstra's own pricing policy is for the ISPs to show that there is, in fact, the potential for conflict. This does have the potential to put severe pressure on the ISPs and the services they provide. I know the ISPs can provide their pricing formulae in a whole range of different ways, but the bottom line is that they are competing for customers with Telstra, which is providing the same pricing regime to the ISPs as it is to customers direct. It really begs the question of the need for appropriate regulation to ensure that such calls cannot be timed.

The point of all of this is that, once those timed calls are allowed on that local business data basis, that provides another layer of cost imposition upon customers, who may choose to go via their ISP as opposed to straight to Telstra's big pond service. So, by implementing a local timed data business call, there is the imposition of a direct disincentive to business for going through an independent ISP as opposed to going through Telstra's big pond Internet service.

The imposition of that layer can be avoided quite specifically and quite easily by supporting this amendment. This amendment would ensure that Telstra cannot time those calls between the customer and the independent ISP. In the same way that this point goes to the heart of ensuring that Telstra and the ISPs are working on a level playing field, I think it is incumbent upon the government to also ensure that the health and the viability of ISPs is maintained.

Minister, the other point I would like you to take on board quite specifically is what is contained in the report of the Senate inquiry. Quite specifically in that report is the point about Telstra arguing that there is overall congestion on the lines, and that is quite unequivocally rejected by the majority report. Minister, it was quite clear, as arising out of this report, that the government had acknowledged the evidence that was put before it and was not going to support the allowing of timed local data calls for businesses.

Minister, I ask you to clarify, firstly, your views with respect to the majority report—if, indeed, you have taken on the advice provided in that majority report. Secondly, I ask for your views with respect to the pricing regime that is imposed by Telstra's big pond. Do you acknowledge that, if timed local data calls are to proceed for business, it does represent an additional layer of expense placed upon, and operating as a disincentive to, businesses actually connecting to the Internet via an independent ISP as opposed to Telstra's big pond service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —That last argument is tantamount to saying: if a service is free, you have every incentive to use it, but the minute you impose any charge, it becomes a disincentive or an extra layer or a business burden. Yes, all of those things are true in one sense, but that does not mean that you are not justified in imposing a charge because there are costs incurred in providing that service. I think in a perfect world the pricing regime ought reflect the underlying cost structure.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority report, as I understand it, only went so far as to suggest a review. It did not argue explicitly against what the government has consistently said on this issue; that is, that we would preserve the right of residential users of Internet services—and all data services for that matter—to have untimed local calls.

When it comes to business users—and we are not just talking about the Internet; we are talking about the high speed transfer of data through computers and the like—that does not clog up the lines by definition. Whether or not there is an ultimate congestion or whether the carrier simply goes on building more and more, if it is an untimed call—and, in theory, in 24 hours you can make a massive transfer of data for 25c—then someone has to pay for that. The mere fact that you can go out and build more capacity to absorb it does not for a moment mean that you are recouping your outlay.

It seems to us that a rational pricing regime will take account of not just the extent of the demand but also the capacity to pay. That is why it is our view that a clever country ought to be encouraging residential users, particularly families and kids, who want to get on to the Internet. You do that by going against the normal method of pricing, taking account of the time value of money or the money value of time, and, in that instance, giving them a special benefit—an untimed local call.

BREAK.PARA: Businesses—who by definition have the capacity to pay or they are out of business—are the ones who can afford to bear that burden, as long as it is not an oppressive price that is set. But it seems to us that if you do simply treat them as entitled to a blanket exemption as well, you are moving away from normal cost recovery principles

Senator Lundy expressed a deal of concern about the behaviour of big pond and I suppose it is a reasonable starting point to say that if you are a lot bigger than anyone else then you are exposed to temptations to exercise improper market power.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the 600‐pound gorilla.

—That is precisely the 600‐pound gorilla, dressed in another suit. This time he is providing Internet services. But the fact is that the bill does have competitive safeguards built in to guard against just those sorts of practices. To the extent that the big pond service is providing special arrangements, those can be taken into account by the ACCC when it arbitrates upon the interconnect regime that the ISPs would want to see put in place.

BREAK.PARA: I did not hear you distinguishing, on a consistent basis, residential from business consumers. You simply talked about ISPs servicing the market. To the extent that ISPs are responding to calls from residential users, that will still be an untimed call. It is only when they are responding to calls from businesses that you start to have a realistic cost burden imposed.

We are not talking here about just small businesses; we are talking about businesses in general. No matter what the size of the business, you go into business knowing that you have got certain fixed overheads and you have got variable costs. You have to take account of your revenue and your level of customers and you pass on the costs and hope to make a profit at the end of the day. So there is nothing inherently wrong with imposing a cost burden on business, particularly where it reflects the underlying cost structure. It is not as if these calls are free irrespective of time. If they are taking up space on the Net and elsewhere, then one rational way of discouraging people from overuse is to make them conscious of that through the prices they pay.
As I understand Senator Schacht, his argument is that currently there is no congestion and therefore we ought to proceed—

TALK.START.PARA: —The case is not proven on the evidence given.

—That is what I am saying. Your argument is that there is currently no congestion and therefore we ought to simply assume, if you like, that there will never be congestion. I do not think that is your position. I think you are saying there is not currently congestion but if there is credible evidence of a sign of it and, after an inquiry, you are satisfied there is real evidence of congestion acting in a way that is making it difficult, something should be done. It is a bit like directory assistance charges. The fact is that if you are forced to provide a service and you are not able to properly cost recover, you will find ways of making life fairly difficult. So it seems to me that the logic of your argument is that there might not be congestion now but if there is later on, there ought to be a mechanism in place that would enable a government to do something about it.
—Parliament will do something about it.
—That is right—enable parliament to address the issue. I think you would need to have that built into your regime, and I do not think it is built in there at the moment.

BREAK.PARA: But, fundamentally, the issue for the government is that we do think it is reasonable to expect business to ration the use of a service and it will not do that if the calls are untimed. We know that it is very easy to transfer vast amounts of data and not pay any cost penalty for doing that at the present time, other than a nominal 25c rate.

In this day and age, fax machines are not as they were a few years ago. The actual time spent transferring the data is minuscule because it is stored up at one end and it then goes through in the twinkling of an eye and it is already in place. So for home users, who still have the benefit of an untimed call—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point I am making. They are not clogging up the system because it goes whoosh from one machine to the other.

—That might be the case for fax machines, but people who are using the service for constant data transfers are potentially clogging up the system. That is why the untimed rate is not so important for modern fax machines but it is very important for wholesale transfer of data. For ISPs, who are able to pass the cost on to business users—whether or not they are using a dedicated line—it is the call‐in price that is relevant to them and they can simply pass that on to the business consumer. They are not passing it on to the residential consumer and it seems to us that that is the right balance to strike on this issue. For those reasons, the government will be opposed to the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are some issues here that ought to be brought out. I am not a surfer of the Internet. I am somewhat of a technophobe—I use computers but I have not quite got on to regular use of the Internet—but it is my understanding that we have a situation at the moment where a lot of people are using the Internet as a means of putting advertisements out to a very large number of people. Sometimes they do this with something like 17 pages of addresses. If you charge the businesses for somebody else's attempt to get their attention, you might end up being charged for the 17 pages of addresses which has got a message at the end saying, `This is a test' or `Sorry, I didn't mean to send that.'

SPEECH.PARA: There are issues such as people running someone's business down by sending them lots and lots of messages. That is not something I am an expert in, but I do think there certainly is the desire to turn the information superhighway into the information super‐tollway. There are many people concerned about the thin end of the wedge that might be associated with this particular move today or with the proposal.

BREAK.PARA: I know that the Telstra bill, when it was put to the committee, did not get put on the Internet. That was interesting, considering that the industrial relations bill did and was very eagerly received by a large number of people. Perhaps the minister or his advisers could advise me as to whether this group of telecommunications bills and the terms of reference did go out on the Internet, because it seems to me that it would have been one of the most ideal ones to distribute in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did.

—Thank you for that answer. It might clarify why there are more concerns now and why we are getting more responses in relation to Internet use than we did during the Telstra inquiry. I believe the message is only beginning to get through to the many Internet users throughout Australia that this whole issue of deregulation of the industry and privatisation is likely to affect them in many ways. I indicate that, on the balance of the arguments, the Greens (WA) will be supporting the opposition's amendment on sheet 443.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go back to a few points that the minister made. Firstly, Minister, you criticised me for not being distinct when using the word `consumers' in relation to residential and business. The same generalisation was made in the context of the paragraph in the majority report that deals very specifically with this issue. It states, `The committee does not believe that the government should allow these guarantees to be exploited by some to the cost of consumers in general.' By the same token, I do generalise because you cannot create the distinction between residential and business because they are all potential clients of either ISP or big pond service.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point I would like to make relates to your comments with respect to the review. You claim that the government's position on this issue is that there will just be a review in 12 months. I believe your report is more specific than that and that it advocates quite clearly that the status quo remain and then a review be conducted to address issues of congestion that may arise at a later date. So I put to you that in fact your report quite specifically advocates that the status quo remain and those local timed data calls for business do not come into force or are not eligible to come into play if and when that review recommends that such calls be provided.

I ask you to comment specifically on that, particularly in the context that, for all the confusion that has arisen around this issue on behalf of the government's position, it has arisen because your report quite clearly indicates that you do not accept evidence advocating a move to timed local data calls for business but you acknowledge the need for a review based on the evidence put before you with respect to potential congestion.

The other point I put to you is with respect to your quite glib response to competition policy and whether any serious concerns are raised with respect to the competitive nature of Telstra's big pond service when it is compared with the services offered by independent ISPs. I believe that those issues need to be resolved quite clearly now. When we have had representations from particular Internet service providers that they will be adversely affected, in the first instance, the government has an obligation to address that quite specifically and not just push it under the carpet, to be dealt with perhaps in all sorts of processes and really test the merits or otherwise of the ACCC's role in telecommunications down the track.

I say that you have an obligation to resolve it before you get to that point because I do believe that there will be an adverse impact upon those businesses and that it would be in fact in your interest as the government to be able to anticipate that in a proactive and up-front way, particularly given that you have already indicated that you are going to review the situation in 12 months. Another 12 months to make sure that timed calls cannot be imposed could well save the 470 businesses that currently provide Internet services independently. To allow it to go ahead, if you do not support this amendment, could put in jeopardy those businesses.

At a time when you talk about the clever country, we are not just talking about the businesses that are clients to the ISPs not being able to afford the services but also talking specifically about the entities of these ISPs themselves and what they actually contribute to the industry. It has been demonstrated by their growth, by the number of people these small businesses employ and by the content provisions that they put into the system that indeed they are quite essential to the growth, to the diversity and to the strength of our national development on Internet technology, particularly with respect to content development.

It is also worth noting—and this was a point well made in one of the recent commentaries on this issue—that basically these ISPs do provide more than just a connection with various pricing options for consumers, whether they be residential or business. They do provide this in the form of local content and Australian content. If this role is impinged upon, can you take into account when making your decision that a considerable source of independent Australian content comes forth from these ISPs? To jeopardise their future in any way jeopardises the potential source of Australian content on the Internet.

I do not believe that an Internet backbone provider such as Telstra can replace the sort of independent content that I am talking about and that is produced by the independent ISPs. I put to you that the backbone providers, Telstra and others, are getting a bit of a free ride because they are the ones that on‐sell this content and benefit from people wanting to get onto the Internet. Whilst they are not putting too much back into it, they are making money out of people wanting to get onto the Internet. They are not contributing to the content provision, which is where the ISPs clearly have a role.

The last point I would like to make relates to what the minister said about the big pond, pricing policies and clogging up the system. Congestion goes to the heart of the government's justification as to why this issue does not need to be addressed quite specifically. Telstra's policy on how they actually sell the bandwidth to the ISPs is not only on the basis of the actual bandwidth that is transferred but also on the basis of utilisation. So usage is defined by them as the number of megabytes that are transferred but, with respect to utilisation, Telstra sell bandwidth on the basis that it becomes more expensive for ISPs if they use a greater amount of the bandwidth that they are eligible or able to access.

At the moment Telstra's pricing regime operates on the basis of less than or equal to 40 per cent of the potential bandwidth that is available to ISPs. So Telstra have quite specifically built into their pricing structure for selling bandwidth from their backbone system to the ISPs a safeguard to ensure that congestion does not occur at that point. I acknowledge, Minister, that that does not address the claim about night‐time congestion from houses and so forth, but I think that has been dealt with in the report. It is an absolute misnomer to use congestion on those main lines from the backbone to the ISPs as the reason for allowing the government to pursue the notion of imposing timed local data calls for business.

I think we do not need to go too much further than that to see just what a furphy the issue of congestion is. If we remove from this debate the arguments relating to congestion, there is absolutely no justification whatsoever for the imposition of timed calls on business. So I think we are dealing with a whole range of issues, and you as a minister need to look quite specifically at what Telstra are offering and how that impinges upon the arguments they have used with you, and then relate that to the overall issue of competition policy and how that applies.

I say to this government: you have a responsibility to avoid stepping into what I see as a quagmire of challenges to that competition policy and you have an obligation to foster and promote a section of small business in the Australian economy that, as you and I have acknowledged on numerous occasions, really does have the potential to take our IT industry just that one step further in the pursuit of placing Australia at the forefront of Internet content development and service provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the committee. I have listened to the discussions that have taken place. The committee certainly dealt with this and had evidence before it. It dealt with it on pages 30 to 32 of the report, and I think on page 148 is the minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of balance, but for mine I feel that at this stage I would be inclined to vote for the amendment. There is going to be a review. That is clear. This whole issue of congestion was relied upon rather heavily by Telstra. I just happen to believe that the evidence was considered by the committee and, on balance, I would be inclined to support the opposition's amendment.

I can clearly see that the government has some pretty valid reasons, but I just wonder whether the government should not just let things go for untimed local calls and see what the review comes up with. We will obviously have to revisit this at some stage if in fact they are correct at the present moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one very quick and simple question of the minister: given that residential users of the Internet get their service through an Internet service provider, under any circumstances can residential users get the Internet on an untimed service; that is, because residences get their service through a business, would they all, for the purposes of the Internet, be on timed local calls if this bill went ahead?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is no. If they are making the call from the residence, then the call to the ISP is untimed.
—As I understand it, there is a problem with the two-wayness of that in that—

—I can assure you there is not. Perhaps I could address this in the context of replying very briefly to Senator Lundy. If you maintain the status quo, which you say is what the majority of the committee recommended—that is, committee members; not the government—then you would simply have no untimed local call guarantee at the moment except for residential users of voice calls. We are in fact extending that to businesses for the first time.

BREAK.PARA: The issue then is whether you go further. We say you go further in extending the untimed local data call option to residential consumers. You want to go even further again, but the fact of the matter is that at the moment only one of those four groups gets untimed local calls, so a recommendation of the status quo followed by a review would probably not satisfy any of us. What we are talking about at the moment is whether or not you ought to be able to charge, and ISPs would then pass that charge on. If it is a timed call, they would pass that on to the user. If you do not do that, the residential user would simply pay that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to change it? You are going to introduce it, are you—to change them?

—No. This is all about whether you extend the right to an untimed option. At the moment, there is no guarantee of an untimed option for residential or business consumers of non‐voice services. The act is silent. We are proposing to put in an untimed guaranteed option for residential consumers. You want to extend that to business.

—I wish to acknowledge the minister's point. When I am talking about status quo, I am talking about what he describes as the extension of that protection from timed calls for local business data calls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the minister may put it as though he is extending the arrangements to untimed data calls for residential and that that is an extra guarantee. Minister, you are quite right: we want the guarantee to go to untimed local data calls for business—full stop, with no argument about that—because the evidence to the contrary has not been produced yet, and certainly not at the committee hearings when there was a robust discussion. Anyone listening to that discussion and to Telstra would know—in my view and I think in the majority of the committee's view; probably unanimously in one form or another—that Telstra did not convince people. I think that, as they cannot convince us yet, we should make sure that what de facto has been happening—untimed local data business calls—should continue.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, whether there is a commitment to have a review or not, I have no doubt that, if in six, 12, or 18 months or two years Telstra believe they have an overwhelming case to convince you and the parliament that it ought to be introduced, you will come before us to amend this legislation. That is the way it should be. I think Senator Harradine has got it right when saying that, as the evidence has not been produced, we should leave the status quo which, de facto, is that there are no timed business calls for data.

If Telstra get their case together, get the evidence and can show congestion, they will be hot‐trotting to the government and the parliament to amend this legislation. It would be a matter of a simple one page bill to go through the parliament, based on the evidence they could put before you and the parliament to convince us to amend it. Until they can, I believe my amendment maintains the status quo—what de facto has been happening, and that is that the local untimed data calls should continue for businesses whether they are Internet service providers, Internet operators, or other data ones. Until they can be shown by Telstra to be clogging up the system and to be abusing it, that should be the case. We rest our position and we certainly commend this amendment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I ask you under standing order 99 whether you intend to vote and if so how, because I believe your vote will make the difference to this.
—I have in fact voted and I have informed the tellers that I am voting no.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Schacht's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator McKiernan did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Cook did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate for benefit of industry that we do adopt a responsible approach on these issues and, consistent with that, will be watching carefully to see how these things work out in practice. We will obviously be prepared to take advice on any trends that develop in the market, but we are confident—
—Bankruptcies, you mean.
—No. We are confident that there will be a rational allocation of resources.

—Minister, does that mean that, before you made any administrative approval to Telstra on this charging of business data, you would make a statement to the parliament? As I understand it, if Telstra came to you now, after our amendment has been defeated, and requested a change to the charging regime for untimed data business calls, you could make that change without reference back to parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, it will be necessary for any carrier proposing to make such charges to apply to Austel in the first instance. There will be opportunities along the way for—
—For the ACCC?
—The ACCC, yes.

—I want to get this clear. They can apply to the ACCC to prove that it is not anti-competitive or all of those other rules that the ACCC have. If the ACCC made the decision to grant the change, then that is it, there is no further involvement of the parliamentary process, administrative process or even a ministerial part of the process under what we now have in the bill?
—Perhaps, Minister, I could just take that query a step further and ask whether or not that mechanism would in fact be a disallowable instrument under your proposals?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that they are required to abide by the price cap. But, otherwise, it is not subject to ministerial discretion.
—Minister, there is the point of Senator Lundy's about it being a disallowable instrument.
—I think that answers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to put on the record, Minister, that I think that, allowing for those arrangements of the ACCC, as this issue is not in the end either a disallowable instrument or coming back to parliament, when all other areas about untimed calls cannot be changed for domestic use and telephony, et cetera, unless they are referred to parliament, it is a bleak day. I think we now have the worst outcome and that is why I moved the amendment. It is now out of the hands of parliament. The biggest growth area in telecommunications all the experts say is in the on-line services and in the local loop area.

SPEECH.PARA: The only chance the public or the business community or the on-line services or the Internet service providers have is to convince the ACCC—but only on a competition basis. I think that really is a very bad outcome. Though you say that the government would be cautious and review information coming in, the fact is, if they make an application to the ACCC, it is even out of your hands. And if it is out of your hands, that means we cannot even ask you a question about it because you will shrug your shoulders and say, `Well, the ACCC have decided this issue—bad luck.'

This is even worse. At least the minister had some discretion to make the decision. I want to finally ask: can you, Minister, make any determination or give any instruction to the ACCC when they are dealing with any application to charge for data information in the local call zone for business? Do you have any discretion to put a view to the ACCC that it is not just a competition issue; there are broader issues—we might claim in the national interest or in the economic interest of Australia. Do you have any power to put a submission to the ACCC?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think so, but the parliament has always got the right to amend legislation and to make changes if it thinks it is necessary. That is really all you are talking about—to have a power of disallowance. The exercise of ministerial discretion is simply saying that parliament ought to be able to have another go at an issue. All I am saying to you is see how this works out. If there are any problems caused, then obviously parliament has always got the right to review it and to do something about it. You cannot, by the backdoor, get what you have not got presently by the front door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not trying to get anything by the back door or any door. I just want to get it on the record. Of course parliament can change the legislation, but the reality is that, unless the government puts the legislation through and has the numbers in the House of Representatives to support it, any legislation, any private member's bill is not going to go through the parliament unless the government supports it. That is the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: The next thing is if we did propose such a change in a couple of years time, we would probably get the argument: `There is a process through the ACCC. We are not going to change that. The ACCC will decide it on competition policy alone; therefore it will be there.' I appreciate your sensitivity about this issue, but you have just admitted that it is up to the ACCC; it is not even up to you. You cannot go and tell the ACCC, unless you introduce direct legislation to amend what you would not vote for today. I find that—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely the point—
—The point was the other way around.
—that there ought to be untimed local calls.
—But what you are saying now is that if the ACCC got it wrong or the government—
—No, I am just saying that we are not going to review decisions.

—Anyway, Minister, I just wanted to get on the record the fact that this decision now is unrecoverable unless the government itself chooses to introduce legislation to amend and overrule any decision of the ACCC. I have said my piece.
—We really have thrashed this to death. The next amendment is No. 6.
—On a point of order: I wanted to comment on the same point.
—Go ahead, Senator Lundy.

—The point I want to make, Minister, is that because it is such a complex issue, and it deals with competition policy as much as it deals with claims by carriers about congestion, there is a very strong argument that in fact we should revisit this in the first instance if in fact there is application by Telstra or another other major carrier to in fact impose timed calls upon local businesses for data. The issue at stake—

—On a point of order: you are wanting to have a debate on a matter that has already been decided by the parliament. I do not know why you want to run this. It is not going to get anywhere. I am not going to say anything more that will give you any encouragement or enlightenment.

—On the point of order: the minister, after the vote was taken, then started the debate again by indicating a number of views the government may have to monitor the situation. He started the debate after the vote, not us. We then responded about what his remarks meant.

—That might be quite true, Senator Schacht, but I think the minister was doing that to help inform the parliament of his point of view. Since the matter has been resolved by the parliament, there is little point, unless there is something absolutely revolutionary, in our continuing with this argument. Next amendment.
—On the point of order—
—I have ruled on the point of order.
—Perhaps I was seeking the call again with respect to this issue. I do not believe you have satisfied—
—I ruled that the matter has been closed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the government's intention to proceed with amendment No. 6 in relation to research into health effects.
—Circulated in your name?
—Yes.

—Can the minister give us a reason why, after circulating it, the government is now not proceeding with this amendment. What has happened to change the government's mind? There has been genuine discussion between all the parties and the government on a range of issues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at it and you think that it still needs to be moved, then we are happy to move it. But it seemed to us to be superfluous in the scheme of things. I assume that, because it had been circulated, you would have had a chance to peruse it. If you still think it is worth proceeding with, then it is not really something that I am going to want to argue about for any length of time. It seemed to us that it did not really take things much further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, in the private discussions, I thought this was a reasonable outcome for it. I would suggest—
—If there has been an agreement, I am not wanting to walk away from that agreement.
—All I can say is that, in the formal discussion about it, I thought that was good enough to say, `We are happy it with.' I cannot speak for other senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Alston) proposed:
Schedule 3, page 498 (after line 5), after clause 44, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 44A Research into health effects of telecommunications transmission towers

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy Program is to include an examination of the health effects of emissions arising from the operation of telecommunications transmission towers.

(2) As soon as practicable after the completion of that examination, the Minister or the Minister for Health and Family Services must cause to be prepared a report relating to any implications of that examination for the siting of telecommunications transmission towers.

(3) The Minister or the Minister for Health and Family Services must cause copies of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the preparation of the report.
(4) In this clause:

PARA.TAB: Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy Program means the program funded by the Commonwealth and known as the Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy Program.
telecommunications transmission tower means:
(a) a tower; or
(b) a pole; or
(c) a mast; or
(d) a similar structure;

SPEECH.PARA: used to supply a carriage service by means of radiocommunications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek an explanation from the minister as to what this amendment would achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is most unfair. When we say we are withdrawing an amendment, we are asked why; when we say you will go ahead with the amendment, they ask why. Do you want it or don't you?

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment proposes that an examination of the health effects of emissions from telecommunications transmission towers be included in the radiofrequency electromagnetic energy program. The government proposes that research be undertaken as part of that program and include the examination of the possible health effects of emission from mobile phone towers.

BREAK.PARA: I had understood that that was already included and that was why this did not seem to me to take us a great deal further. It is being specific rather than just assuming that it would be covered, but now, hopefully, it is clear what the amendment is designed to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why the government has wanted to withdraw this amendment. It does not seem to me to add anything at all to what we already have. It seems to have no purpose. All of this can be done under the $4.5 million that was set aside for a four-year period. I think there might be some dangers in agreeing to this amendment because, given that that $4.5 million was for a four-year period, it might be a way of saying, `There is no need for us to make any judgments about whether or not transmission towers are problematic until we have finished this four-year study.'

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I do not want to support this amendment because I think it is already covered. There is no need for the amendment. I think it probably sends the wrong message. It talks about telecommunications transmission towers as meaning a tower, a pole, a mast or a similar structure when what we really ought to be talking about is the transmitters themselves.

I suggest both to the opposition and to the government that they scrap this whole idea because it does nothing and it is probably a bit more dangerous than something which does nothing in that it is pretty unclear about what it all means. It might be construed as to be reassuring even. I am not all together sure what the implications of it were.

I think the Democrats will not vote for this. We would certainly like to have another go at doing another amendment, which the government probably would not support. I would like to flag that we will not support that amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for being hopelessly flexible. All I can say is that the issue is squarely in the opposition's court. If they want to go ahead with it and we have agreed, then we will go ahead with it. But, as you can see, I have a high level of indifference on the issue. If you do not want to go ahead with it, I will withdraw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew this probably would not be exactly what the Democrats wanted, but in the discussions which took place privately I thought this was at least an effort to show that this was an important issue about electromagnetic radiation, et cetera. Therefore, that is why I in my discussions with government advisers quite openly thought that this was a useful step.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment came out of the Democrat material last week, which now seems like an age ago. But if the Democrats do not wish to proceed with it, I am not going to die in the ditch for it. If they do not want to vote for it, I am certainly not going to proceed with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, seek leave to withdraw the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw government amendment No. 6.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendment withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The next amendment is in relation to the National Relay Service. It is to insert a new subclause 138A after clause 138; it is unnumbered. The reason that this is to be moved is that there were two technical problems with an earlier amendment, No. 14, moved by the Democrats and passed by the Senate. We wanted to avoid the unintended consequences. The Democrat amendment did not deem the supply of the standard telephone service to include the National Relay Service and the amendment is designed to ensure that that is in fact the case.
—The question is that Democrat amendment No. 14 be withdrawn. Is leave granted?
—Chair, is it not possible just to amend the Democrats' amendment? Do we have to withdraw it and replace it with another?
—I am advised that this is the desirable procedure to follow: to withdraw the Democrat amendment and substitute the government amendment.
—You are not changing the intent of the will of the Senate; you are just making a technical change.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking instructions as to whether it simply cannot be added on to what is already in place, but I am told it cannot.
—My advice is that the Democrat amendment technically has to be withdrawn by leave and the new amendment substituted.

—They are my instructions. On the face of it, it just appears to be an addition. All I can say is that presumably what is being contended is that the amendment already passed does not, on its face, ensure that the supply of the standard telephone service covers the National Relay Service, whereas this one does, and that is why it is desirable to replace that with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to accept the minister's explanation that this is a technical change and that the intent is not altered. I seek leave to withdraw amendment No. 14 of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendment withdrawn.
Amendment (by Senator Alston) agreed to:
Page 126 (after line 16), after clause 138, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 138A Supply of services similar to the National Relay Service to be treated as the supply of standard telephone services

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A reference in this Part to the supply of a standard telephone service includes a reference to the supply of a service that is:

PARA.TAB: (a) specified in the regulations; and
(b) similar in scope and purpose to the National Relay Service; and
(c) intended to facilitate personal communication by persons with hearing and/or speech impairments; and
(d) for use in connection with the standard telephone service

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Minister must take all reasonable steps to ensure that, at all times on and after 30 June 1998, regulations are in force for the purposes of paragraph (1)(a).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The last item on the running sheet is an opposition amendment on which in the division last week Senator Brown claimed misadventure in missing the division. It was a tied vote and he indicated that his vote would have changed the decision. It was agreed that at the end of the committee stage on this part of the package we would then recommit this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we do, I wonder if I could put another matter to the minister, because after that we will have finished this section of the Telecommunications Bill. Minister, this is not actually an amendment that I have indicated that I was going to move but it is about my amendment on document 417, which is to do with levies to fund placing lines underground. I have indicated to you in discussions with your advisers that amendment No. 1, which is to clause 42, and amendment No. 2 are two different aspects of the issue of paying to get cables placed underground.

The first amendment was actually a proposal that, if state governments, local government and a carrier agreed to the imposition of a levy to put cables underground, under state law that would be allowed as long as that levy was approved by the ACA. The second amendment was referring to your review of the constitutional aspects of the imposition of a levy on carriers across the board, et cetera, and about those constitutional matters.

Minister, this is something we have had private discussions about with your advisers, but I seek an undertaking that both my amendment No. 1 and amendment No. 2—Nos 3, 4 and 5 are consequential—be referred to the panel reviewing undergrounding issues, which will report back by 1 July next year. I would like you to agree that both those issues will be considered by the review panel in its considerations. We had an informal discus sion. I just wanted to get it on the record that you would be willing to ask them to consider my two amendments and therefore there would be no need for me to proceed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think that is reasonable. The issue of the constitutionality of clause 42 is presumably a matter for persons other than the lay members who will comprise the working group, but no doubt—
—But they can seek advice?
—They can commission it, yes.
—Is leave granted to resubmit the opposition amendment on sheet 420? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say that there is no need to debate this. This is a recommittal and the issues have already been debated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 432 (after line 15), after clause 11, insert:
(1) If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan.
(2) Subclause (1) has no effect to the extent (if any) to which it is inconsistent with Australia's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation.
