SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 6, page 27 (after line 24), after Division 4, insert:
(1) This section applies to a charge for a basic carriage service.
(2) At least 7 days before:

PARA.TAB: (a) imposing a new charge; or
(b) varying a charge; or
(c) ceasing to impose a charge;

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra must give the Commission, in a form approved in writing by the Commission, a written statement setting out such information about Telstra's intentions as the Commission requires.

(3) The Commission may, on the application of Telstra, make a written determination that subsection (2) has effect, in relation to a specified matter, as if the reference in that subsection to 7 days were reference to such shorter period as specified in the determination.
(4) A determination under subsection (3) has effect accordingly.
(5) Divisions 6 and 7 apply to a contravention of subsection (2) in a corresponding way to the way in which they apply to a contravention of a tariff filing direction.
(6) This section does not, by implication, limit the application of Division 4 to Telstra.
(7) The Commission may, by written notice given to Telstra, exempt a charge for a specified basic carriage service from the scope of subsection (2).
(8) A basic carriage service may be specified for the purposes of subsection (7) by reference to any or all of the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) the customers to whom the services are, or are proposed to be, supplied;
(b) the kinds of terms and conditions on which the services are, or are proposed to be, supplied.

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Subsection (8) does not, by implication, limit subsection (7).
(10) An exemption under subsection (7) may be unconditional or subject to such conditions (if any) as are specified in the exemption.

(11) Section 151BQ applies to information given to the Commission under this section in a corresponding way to the way in which it applies to information given to the Commission in accordance with a tariff filing direction.

(12) Section 151BS applies to information given to the Commission in purported compliance with this section in a corresponding way to the way in which it applies to information given to the Commission in purported compliance with a tariff filing direction.
(13) In this section:
basic carriage service has the meaning given by section 174 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 , as in force before 1 July 1997, but does not include a service supplied to an existing carrier.
existing carrier means a person who held a general telecommunications licence, or a public mobile licence, that was in force under the Telecommunications Act 1991 immediately before 1 July 1997.
Telstra has the same meaning as in the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 .
terms and conditions has the same meaning as in section 151BT.
variation , in relation to a charge, means a variation of the nature of the charge or the amount of the charge, or both.

This amendment seeks to make it compulsory for Telstra to file all its tariffs. This may not be a great issue for the large number of Australian telecommunications consumers, but in the balance of competition policy, which is much of the theme of this legislation, we think it is important that this amendment be moved. For a period of time post‐1 July, Telstra will be required to file all its tariff charges with what will become the ACCC. It has to be done at least seven days before imposing a new charge or varying a charge or ceasing to impose a charge. Telstra must give the commission, in a form approved in writing by the commission, a written statement setting out such information about Telstra's intentions as the commission requires.

Telstra is still the major dominant telecommunications organisation in Australia. It dominates the market in many areas, though so far, because of competition, it is now no longer seen as the dominant carrier in international areas and I think in some areas of what was called STD. Certainly in many other areas it is still the dominant carrier and has a major impact on the charging system and the pricing system. Because of its dominance in the market, it can vary tariffs from time to time that would give it a major advantage against emerging competitors, carriers and service providers, but particularly other carriers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chris, we agree with it.
—If you agree with it, you have accepted the merits of my argument. I do not know about the other parties, but we believe that it is a useful step forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 6, page 39 (before line 28), before subsection (1), insert:

(1A) If the Commission makes a decision under section 151AL to issue a competition notice in relation to a carrier or carriage service provider, the carrier or provider may apply to the Tribunal for a review of the decision.
(2) Schedule 1, item 6, page 41 (after line 5), after section 151CK, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 151CKA Review of decision to issue a competition notice—suspension of notice

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If an application is made under subsection 151CI(1A) for a review of a decision of the Commission to issue a competition notice, the Tribunal may, by writing, suspend the operation of the competition notice if the Tribunal thinks it appropriate to do so in order to secure the effectiveness of the determination of the review.
(2) In making a decision under subsection (1), the Tribunal must have regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the balance of convenience; and
(b) whether any undertakings have been given under subsection (3); and
(c) such other matters (if any) as the Tribunal considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) A person (the first person ) may give the Tribunal a written undertaking that, in the event that another person (the second person ) suffers any loss or damage as a result of a suspension under subsection (1), the first person will pay the second person such reasonable amount of compensation as is:

PARA.TAB: (a) agreed between them; or
(b) failing agreement—determined by the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) An undertaking under subsection (3) is enforceable in the same manner as an undertaking given to the Federal Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 151CKB Review of decision to issue a competition notice—exemption from the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 has effect as if the following decisions were set out in Schedule 1 to that Act:

PARA.TAB: (a) a decision of the Commission under section 151AL;
(b) a decision of the Tribunal under section 151CJ that relates to a decision of the Commission under section 151AL;
(c) a decision of the Tribunal under section 151CKA.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, this amendment would not attract much interest in one form from the large number of telecommunications consumers in Australia. We believe that a competition notice should be dealt with by the Australian Competition Tribunal rather than by the ACCC itself. The reason we do this is that we believe that, on issues of competition, there are broader economic interests to be considered, not just narrow competition issues that the ACCC itself would deal with.

You cannot ignore the fact that Telstra and the issues surrounding telecommunications have a major economic impact on the provision of those services in Australia. We believe, therefore, that by putting it to the tribunal, which is a more balanced tribunal and has interests other than just a straight competition, it will be a better outcome in the balance for telecommunications.
Secondly, we have tried to limit the ongoing legal costs and the propensity of the major carriers to sue each other at the drop of a hat. That is why we have the following words in our amendment:
Review of decision to issue a competition notice—exemption from the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977
Someone will point out that common law still exists and people will—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as well, my friend.

—Common law has developed over the last 600 or 700 years. When common law started on these precedents in Great Britain they did not have a printing press, let alone a telephone. We will not get into a philosophic argument about the advantages and disadvantages of common law.

SPEECH.PARA: If you do not have a limit, we believe that both sides will sue each other endlessly to try to get a win on issues that will have a major economic advantage for a particular carrier. The real winners will not be the carriers; they will be the legal profession—QCs, silks, juniors and all those other solicitors, et cetera. Major law firms will keep advising their clients—the carriers—to keep suing each other right through to the High Court and back again. All that will do is make the legal profession richer and will not automatically mean that we get a better telecommunications system that is economically providing the best to Australia.

We believe that, on balance, this is the best way to go in this area. As I said, I certainly acknowledge that this is not an issue that in the broad community is a matter that people are fighting in the streets over, like untimed calls or directory assistance. We think, on balance, that it does put some restriction on the ability of carriers to endlessly waste the ACCC's time and the time of the legal system by endlessly suing each other to get a financial advantage.

One reason the minister should consider supporting this in the process of the partial privatisation of Telstra is that this will mean that Telstra will spend a lot less money on legal fees and being taken to court by the other carriers at the drop of a hat. Therefore, we believe that the amendment is useful in a balance between competition and the economic interests of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This will play precisely into the hands of the lawyers because you cannot remove the common law rights to take action on an administrative law basis. In other words, prerogative writs, as they are called, enable you to go right through the range of the courts. AD(JR) is simply a statutory form of administrative review. If you take away the statutory entitlement, they revert to common law and you achieve nothing.

BREAK.PARA: But all you would achieve would be the adding of an additional layer of complexity, and I am sure that the industry has pointed this out to you. A competition notice is simply a technical document that establishes a prima facie case; in other words, you do not have to get out there and prove that it is anti-competitive before then going along and having your big argument in court. Competition notice means that the ACCC has expressed its view, and then you go along to the AAT and have your argument.

If you want to allow that administrative decision, if you like, to be appealed on a merits basis, then you are introducing a merits argument on a non-substantive issue. That is quite contrary to any principles of law. You can review something on a point of law. But to have a merits review means that you would start to have the argument about whether or not they are acting anti-competitively in the AAT, which is not where that discussion ought to take place at all. The ACCC issues a competition notice, which is a prima facie view, and then you have the argument. It is just to get thing off the ground.

But you want to have that very act of issuing a notice then referred off to a tribunal where you will have, presumably, if the carriers want to contest it, a lawyers' picnic. You can argue for weeks on whether or not they are acting anti-competitively—and all in aid of simply establishing the validity of a competition notice. It is going in very much the wrong direction.

I would be very surprised if anyone with any legal competence has told you that this makes sense. I also would be amazed if the industry itself thinks that this does anything other than play into the hands of those who want to make the whole system much more complex and create layers which are simply designed to keep the lawyers well fed. I do not object to that in principle. But I thought you did; I thought you were always carrying on about how you thought we should take lawyers out of the system. You are going in precisely the opposite direction. This is a denial of all you have ever stood for, and you ought to be absolutely ashamed of yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to having a Melbourne barrister tell me that I ought to be ashamed of myself on these issues, all I can say is that in the end the legal profession will always look after itself. Time is getting on. I think we want to try to finish this bill by 9 o'clock tonight, and we have a short break coming up for dinner.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do want to point out that, on page 149 of the opposition's minority report, we did explain why we have moved this process of competition notices. In particular, 127 states:

Opposition senators believe that the receipt of a competition notice will have the potential to substantially restrict the ability of a carrier or carriage service provider to engage its business activities. Where this restriction limits anti-competitive behaviour it is appropriate. However, failing to provide a competition notice recipient with the opportunity to challenge the notice's merit will create business and regulatory uncertainty and may dampen the very competition that this legislative package seeks to promote.
That is why we therefore refer to—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quoting yourself in support of yourself.
—I just want to put this on the record.
—I was going to ask whether anyone else supported you.
—Whether or not other people support us, Minister, I have to say that on a range of things we have moved—
—It is always nice to know if you have the comfort of people in authority or experience in the industry.

—As I have said to the minister, Mr Chairman, I would have thought that this was, if anything, a favourable position for Telstra. Telstra will never make any public declaration supporting an opposition—
—I would not rely on them. This is playing into their hands. Talk to our people and they will tell you.

—I believe that Telstra would have seen this as being something that would be useful. But, of course, they are not able to express that view unless it accords with the view of the government. So I am sure that there is a restriction in this area. Nevertheless, we believe it is a useful area. I have said very openly that I accept this is not an issue that the large number of telecommunications consumers—
—That does not mean that you are on the right track.

—No—would find an issue on the other issues we have argued in here. But we believe that it is a way in which the broader issues dealing with the economics in the telecommunications industry can be dealt with rather than just on a narrow competition basis. Nevertheless, I will commend the amendment.
—The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At three minutes to seven, to save time, I will not call a division. We have put our reasons why we have supported this amendment. To save two minutes of time, I will not call a division on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not proceed with the next amendments on the running sheet, unless there is support by the government. I would be happy either to move them without speaking if the government is in support, or just simply to withdraw them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are opposed to those two amendments of the Democrats, so I am indebted to Senator Allison for withdrawing them. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, item 6, page 47 (line 20), at the end of the definition of content service , add ", and includes a proposed content service".

I think government amendment No. 4, which I have just moved, comes before the two amendments which have been withdrawn by Senator Allison. The government amendment is uncontroversial and gives effect to recommendation 5.1 of the committee and makes the definition of `content service' consistent with the definition of `carriage service'.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, you will not proceed with both of those amendments. Is that right?
—That is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 1, item 6, page 95 (line 8), omit "5 years", substitute "12 months".
This amendment is concerned with criminal penalties, and I think it is purely technical.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

PARA.TAB: . The ACA must establish a committee to be known as the Consumer Consultative Forum.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING CHARGES) BILL 1996
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only amendments to this bill, I think, are Democrat amendments. If I could indicate the government's position it might be helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: The government supports Democrat amendments Nos. 1 and 4, subject to the qualifications that the word `geographic' should be inserted before `number' in both amendments, and clause 5 of the bill should be amended to include the following definition after numbering plan:
. . . standard telephone service has the same meaning as in the Telecommunications Act 1996.

The government considers there should be no charge on geographic numbers, which are allocated to a carrier or service provider for the purposes of providing a standard telephone service to a customer. That, as I understand it, is the Democrats' intention. We simply want to ensure that that intention is given full purpose and effect by those amendments. We will oppose Democrat amendment Nos. 2 and 3, but support Democrat amendment Nos. 1 and 4, on the basis of those two refinements that I indicated. That would mean that the requests circulated in our name should replace Democrat amendments Nos. 1 and 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —The changes the minister proposes are acceptable to the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(1) Clause 5, page 2 (after line 25), after the definition of numbering plan , insert:
standard telephone service has the same meaning as in the Telecommunications Act 1996 .
(2) Clause 15, page 6 (after line 1), before subclause (1), insert:
(1A) A number is exempt from charge if the number is a geographic number allocated to a carriage service provider for the purposes of providing a standard telephone service to a customer.
(3) Clause 22, page 8 (after line 17), before subclause (1), insert:
(1A) A number is exempt from charge if the number is a geographic number allocated to a carriage service provider for the purposes of providing a standard telephone service to a customer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obviously happy to support that arrangement. I do not have any particular amendments, but I think this bill was introduced as a budget bill to raise $30 million in revenue for the government. I have had some brief discussions with the government advisers about the numbering charges.

SPEECH.PARA: I wondered whether the minister is able to give any more information—this is actually a budget bill, so it is part of a package—about the $30 million set as a figure for the charging of the provision of telephone numbers. Once a determination is made to charge for a certain package of telephone numbers, how long will those charges last for before the government re‐auctions them or they are up for resale? I do not believe that they are sold for an infinite period of time. What sort of view does the government have about that? When you buy the numbers in an auction or bid for them, how long do you purchase the numbers for?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is yet to be determined, but the method of payment will be by way of annual tax. So obviously the amount that you are able to set on an annual basis will depend upon the length of time that you can guarantee access to the number.
—So the $30 million is raised every year?
—Yes.
—Though that is a tax on the numbers per annum, when the person purchases them, they have to accept that they have to pay for it. Is there a termination period that the—
—That is to be determined.

—There will be a limit. It is like getting a licence for five years or for 10 years. Has any consideration been given as to what the time span will be for these? Is it really a five‐year or a 10‐year period? Clearly, that is going to affect the value of the numbers quite substantially.
—It is going to be an auction system, so that will all be part of the process.
—It is an auction system.
—It has not been decided what the term of the licence ought to be. When it is, the amount people pay by way of the—

—I see this bill not so much as part of a reform package in one sense but as a budget bill raising revenue. I am not trying to delay the Senate, but I think it is not unreasonable to get some information on a budget bill about how long the arrangement would be. For example, say it is five years until an auction. Say you win the auction for a batch of numbers, and it is for five years. The purchaser, by auction, is aware that at the end of that time they have no guaranteed right that they will continue with those numbers and they are up for re‐auction. Is that going to be the process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the options. It is not unusual to decide in principle to go ahead and auction numbers—or, indeed, parts of the spectrum—and then you decide whether it is a five‐year, 10‐year or 15‐year licence. You decide the method of payment and, depending upon what term you give, presumably will determine how much you get.

SPEECH.PARA: The charge that the government levies is on the carrier. So the carrier is obligated to pay that amount per year for that batch of numbers. It is then a matter for the carrier on how it allocates those numbers and what amount it charges. I suppose in theory it could not recoup the $30 million, but it has to pay that up‐front to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is something I had not picked up before—the fact that the carrier is levied a proportion of the—
—No, a lump sum.

—This is what I want. How do you allocate the batches of numbers to start off with between, say, three carriers? How do you allocate the numbers for the three carriers? If they have to pay the levy, do they have to pay it up-front?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that there is competition for a particular set of numbers, they will be auctioned. Otherwise it will simply be—
—Auctioned by the carriers to the service—
—No, by the government to the carriers.

—So a carrier, subject to their own commercial decision, will bid in an open auction—for example, if Optus wants to buy more numbers and so on. The next question is: if a carrier buys certain groups of numbers, are they obligated within a period of time to actually use them, or can they withhold them from the marketplace? Even though they cannot use them and do not have market demand for them, by keeping good numbers reserved for themselves, they stop a competitor from getting hold of those numbers and using them in the marketplace.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would assume that the rules would say that you cannot sit on them. It seems to me that it would be rather silly behaviour on the part of the carrier to hoard a number and not get anything for the privilege. So, in practice, you would expect them to buy only the numbers that they want and then to allocate them accordingly.

—In the rules of the auction—obviously it would be silly for them to pay for numbers they would not use—would you have to start using the numbers and allocating them within a period of time, say, three months, six months?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, that has not been decided. But it does not seem to me to make a great deal of difference—
—Not to your revenue.
—No, to the market. It does not make much difference whether you have anti-hoarding provisions, because there is an economic disincentive for a carrier to sit on a bunch of numbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not unknown in other areas of commercial activity for people to pay money to a competitor to stop them getting access to a service. For example, I understand that in an area of media, two or three years ago, the Nine Network paid Jana Wendt a retainer to not be available to get a contract on any other network. That lasted a couple of years, or one year, until she got sick of it, or it was up for renegotiation. So it is not unknown for someone to say, `We can't actually use them. But if we can't use them it is better that no-one else can use them. If they use them, it strengthens their position in the marketplace.' It is a bit like buying a small business, a restaurant: the restaurant owner would be told, `You cannot start a new restaurant within 15 kilometres of this one for a period of five years.'

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what I want to get to. As to those rules which you say are still to be determined, Minister, are they to be determined by the government or the ACCC under competition policy?
—They would be determined by the ACA, and it is a disallowable instrument.

—The ACA will determine the rules and those rules will be a disallowable instrument—the rules for auction, access to them and when they have to sell them by? That is clear, is it? That is all a disallowable instrument? I would have thought that maybe Treasury would rather have this locked away simply by administrative process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is presuming they are paid up‐front. The ACA will set the rules for both systems, and the rules for the carriers will be determined by the ACA. It will not be a disallowable instrument, but there will also be rules—
—The rules will not be a disallowable instrument?

—No, but there will be numbering plan rules which will be, and that will determine the shape of the auction or other process that the carriers will be required to follow in allocating those numbers to their customers.

—Clause 22 of the bill, relating to exemption from charge, says that the ACA may by determination exempt a specified number from charge. What sort of area are we getting into? Is it that the general White Pages numbers cannot be charged?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be, for example, numbers that charities might require. But I suppose flexibility is built into the system. So if there is a need to reserve certain numbers or take them out of the system altogether, then there is the capacity to do so.
—It is clear, Minister, that the numbers being charged do not include the normal domestic telephone numbers.
—That is the whole purpose of the Democrats' amendment.

—Minister, I wonder whether it is possible that, once those rules of the ACA are drawn up—I realise that they have a pretty heavy workload over the next three months in a number of areas, and we have probably given them more things to do as a result of amendments and reviews in the consideration of this bill—the ACA would report annually in their annual report to parliament on the administration and the revenue raised from the numbering charge?
—Yes.
—Will they issue a separate report on the numbers that have been auctioned?
—No, they will not give details.

—So they would not say, `Optus got these numbers and Telstra got these numbers'. Having some transparency in the blocks of numbers so other competitors might say in the future, `We would not mind bidding for those,' would be good for revenue for Treasury, I would have thought.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 13, page 5 (line 17), omit "ACA", substitute "Minister".
(3) Clause 20, page 8 (line 10), omit "ACA", substitute "Minister".
Could the minister explain why the government is not prepared to support these amendments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —In simple terms, rather than the minister having a discretion to determine those matters, it is the government's view that the ACA is best placed, because it has knowledge about the administration of the numbering functions and it can determine the appropriate charge. It is the appropriate body rather than the minister.

—The reason we put those amendments forward was that in our view these charges are akin to a tax and therefore we would have thought it was appropriate for them to be a subject of primary legislation determined by the minister rather than the regulator. That was the basis on which we put forward those amendments.
—Can the minister explain what his objection is to the Democrat amendments to substitute `Austel' for `minister'?

—Because the independent regulator is better placed to make those sorts of decisions. It has the expertise. The minister is not well placed to make those sorts of judgments and we would rather have it done at arm's length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that it would not be awfully controversial to put `minister' rather than `Austel'. It is not a matter of great balance and dramatic change one way or the other. We are talking about, in these areas, a budget bill about fees. Both of these bills are related to each other. They are about raising revenue for the government. By and large, if you are raising revenue, a government minister ought to be responsible for answering to the parliament about that—even though this is about the administration of it; you might say that is more appropriate for Austel. But, overall, we are talking about a budget bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a sort of add‐on to the package. The opposition does not object to it being in the package and we support the right to charge carriers for these numbers. But these two bills are a revenue raising measure and $30 million a year is not an inconsiderable amount of money. The minister ought to have a more hands‐on approach about this to be responsible to parliament about the revenue. By and large, that is the best place for a minister to be responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of the day, if you impose the obligation on the minister, he will simply give the ACA written directions. So I do not know what you really achieve by going down this path.

—It might be helpful if I indicate the source of these amendments. They came from advice from the Alert Digest on this bill. It was their recommendation. I am sorry I cannot give you a reference number, but that is the source of the amendments.

—I accept the fact that the minister will just give a direction to Austel. The minister is then responsible for that direction and will be held accountable in the scrutiny of budget matters on a revenue raising measure. This is not an inconsiderable sum. Even if the minister directs it to the ACA, that is fine. We have not shifted your view on this, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are basically just saying, `Be reasonable; do it our way.' It does not seem to me that that is a necessarily persuasive argument. At the end of the day, I do not know whether it matters greatly; but I would have thought it is much tidier to have the body that has to administer this setting the amount of the charges. I will not die in a ditch on it. But, rather than go on and on, I can see what is going to happen: we will not finish by nine o'clock, and you know what that means—we will all be in big trouble.
—We will finish.
—I suggest that the question be put and it be won or lost on the voices and then we move on.

SPEECH.PARA: Requests negatived.
Bill agreed to, subject to requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

I seek leave to move government amendments Nos 1 to 27 together with part of amendment No. 23.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: This was a major issue at the Senate committee. It was dealt with at some length. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity at the end of the committee stage, which is now being reached—believe it or not—to place on record a few comments from the opposition about this process and about this monumental package of bills that I think goes back probably 2½ years in preparation by the previous government through into the new government.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that probably some—the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and maybe even the Leader of the Opposition—think that this process of the last week and a bit in committee stage went on far too long, particularly as there was a legislative committee reference. I believe that if we had not had the legislative committee reference, we would have been here for weeks in the committee stage.

I think that the committee stage of the Senate as a whole was very responsible. The range of amendments, I think, were well focused, whether they came from the opposition, the Greens or the Democrats. I also have to say that it gave an opportunity for the government to table significant numbers of amendments in response to the predominantly unanimous recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts.

I believe that, in future, when we have complicated pieces of legislation or packages of bills, we should attempt to replicate that process. It would have been extremely messy in here without that process. I think that, although Senator Hill and others might think that this went on for far too long and it should have been much shorter, it was a very reasonable process.

First of all I want to record my appreciation of the Senate Procedure Office for the preparation of the running sheet, without which we would never have got through this package of bills. To Rosemary Laing and her staff—thank you. On behalf of the opposition, I want to thank the government for making available access to Mr Keith Byles to help draft the amendments that we moved so that they were technically correct even if in policy terms we still had some disagreements on them. I think that process facilitated this debate. I also want to thank Frank Nugent from the ERCA secretariat and the other staff for the work that they did to get this bill through the parliament.

It is not often that I mention members of the government, but I certainly want to thank David Kennedy and Paul Fletcher from the minister's staff for the regular consultation and so on. I do this genuinely, because, again, there was a lot of give and take. We reached agreement on a lot of amendments, which I think were useful in the final outcome of the bill. I also want to thank Tony Shaw and all staff from DOCA—there are far too many of them to mention. Tony, you can pass on my thanks on behalf of the opposition for the work that you did, turning up to those Senate committee hearings when you were often the meat in the sandwich at the table explaining things. I think that was a very worthwhile process and it was very much appreciated.

I also want to thank Victor Franco from the Democrats, who has done a lot of the work for Senator Allison. I want to thank the other senators for their contributions. The give and take across the chamber, Minister, I think has been useful. This is a package that we probably 90 per cent agreed on before we started. The issues, I think, were worth debating. I think that the minister, Senator Allison, Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine all contributed to an improvement in the package. We will be back here, I suspect, at some stage in the next year or so with further amendments as this telecommunications industry and regulatory authority regime is being updated as technology continues to rip apart the best laid plans of all of us about what we think is going to happen.

Finally, I would like to thank my own personal staff, Jenny Fox, Cassandra Gelade and Alison Wood‐Pottle in particular, for putting up with me over the last six to eight months as we worked our way through the several hundred pages of this package. I want to place on record that I believe this has been a pretty constructive process which reflects well on the parliamentary process in Australia.

RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1997 RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how far I will get in this contribution. I did not get very far in the couple of minutes that were available to me before lunch and now I see that the clock is against me again.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying before lunch that the essence of this legislation is not, as those on the other side would have us believe, to take away rights from workers; the whole purpose of this legislation is to provide a framework which allows more choice. There are those on the other side who see choice as a bad thing. I disagree. The reason why choice is important in these matters of retirement savings is that it would be wilfully reckless of this parliament were we to merely say, `Every worker in this country must have their retirement savings locked up in a superannuation account with an industry superannuation fund.'

The point I was making before lunch is quite simply this. We know that stock markets go up and stock markets go down. Industry superannuation funds have large portions of their savings held in the form of shares on the stock market. You do not have to be a genius to know that, if the market goes down, as everybody expects the market could well do either some time tomorrow or some time towards the end of the year, the value of people's superannuation goes down as well.

So to say to people `We are not going to give you the benefit of a retirement savings account where the value of the savings is certain, where the value of the savings is secure' could be to condemn hundreds of thousands of Australians who are expecting to retire in the very near future to having less money than they would otherwise have had. That would be reckless of this parliament. That is why the legislation to pass these retirement savings accounts is very significant and should not be opposed.

More fundamentally, I think there is another issue—which is that the previous government created this vast superannuation industry, which is in many senses very inefficient in terms of the allocation of resources, and it exists simply because government legislation says it must exist. Those on the other side say, `Because government legislation says it must exist, it has to be a good thing.'

All that we on this side say is that there is a place for superannuation funds like the industry superannuation funds, but there is also a place for us to provide another mechanism to workers in this country to secure their savings and to secure their retirement income when it comes time for them to retire. That is the point of this legislation. We were prompted to go down this route when we saw the collapse of the ABC aggressive growth fund in the early nineties which grew by an aggressive negative 69 per cent in 12 months. That is what we are trying to protect against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before appointing the tellers, I wish to indicate that I intend to vote against the bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I can scarcely believe that so few empowered senators so painlessly will move to disempower so many citizens so painfully. What we are seeing is the process of voting for euthanasia and against voluntary euthanasia. In this committee we have to look at the specifics that that process involves.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading speech, when referring to the contention that Australian doctors perform voluntary euthanasia, Senator Herron, who is hosting this bill, said, `I have never seen it. I would ask those who propound such a statement to produce the evidence. It does not exist. I know it does not exist. It does not occur.' I ask Senator Herron, through you, Mr Chairman: is that still the case?

I ask him: has he not been acquainted with the evidence in the Medical Journal of Australia in February this year, the survey which indicates that some 4,400 Australians a year are helped to an early death because of the consideration of their doctors—without their request, without a dialogue and, because of the illegality of it, without the ability to be the arbiter of the way in which they will die? It is being left to the doctor. That is what is being voted for here tonight: a denial of the individual's rights. As one other doctor said, death has become the prerogative of the priests and the doctors in our society, and what they are worried about with voluntary euthanasia is the patient wanting to muscle in on that territory. I submit that the citizen ought to be able to not only muscle in but also be arbiter of that process.

I ask Senator Herron: are you not acquainted with the asseveration known around the country, published in Victoria in 1995 by seven doctors—including an oncologist, a cancer specialist—that they do perform acts which are effectively euthanasia in helping their patients to avoid the pain, the indignity and the suffering that does come before many deaths that Australians endure, despite the best availability of palliative care?

I ask you: do you stick to those words of yours, that euthanasia is venal and dangerous, and yet vote to support euthanasia remaining rampant in this country compared to jurisdictions like the Netherlands because it is not codified, because nationally we do not have the gumption of the Northern Territory legislators? They have codified what is commonplace practice and in doing so have returned from the doctors to the patient the right to be arbiter, to be the determinant, to make up their own minds for themselves in the matter of dying. I ask you: do you stick by those ugly comparisons you made, in respect of the thousands of doctors around this country who, in the absence of a codified law, do help their patients to an easier death—that there is an analogy between them and doctors convicted in the Nuremberg trials? It is those sorts of ugly and dastardly comparisons that have blighted this debate and left the popular will in this country unrepresented so far in the deliberations of the majority of both houses of this parliament.

Finally, I ask Senator Herron: do you not accept the clear evidence there now is that the rate of euthanasia—not voluntary but performed by doctors without patient consultation—is much higher in Australia than it is in the Netherlands, where the voluntary option is readily available?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. My point of order is under standing order 193. I have listened in as tolerant a way as I can to Senator Brown's contribution. However, on three occasions he has made absolutely clear reflections on a vote of this Senate. I think that, if we are going to conduct a debate here tonight in a rational, level‐headed way on a very important issue, we should at least abide by the rules of debate, and I think 193 is a very important standing order. We should respect the decisions of the Senate, whether we like those decisions or not.

—On the point of order, Mr Chairman, I would point out that I was referring to votes that are forthcoming. We have not finished with this matter yet; there is potentially a third reading vote. I have been talking about the way in which this Senate will move, but the reality is that we cannot freely debate in this Senate the circumstances of voluntary euthanasia if we are not able to refer to the disparity there is between the public feeling and the votes we are seeing in this parliament.
—There is no point of order, but I thank Senator Campbell for raising that matter and I think we can consider it during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I just heard an interjection saying, `Good,' and that is the reason I rise now. The reason I am rising is that Senator Brown has circulated some important amendments which I know people have got very mixed feelings about in this chamber. I may be wrong about this but I really fear that the longer Senator Brown talks, if he wants to be combative, the less support those amendments are going to get. I thought I had divined the mood of the chamber on that fairly well. That is the reason I am rising now.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be supporting Senator Brown's transitional amendments, as opposed as I am to euthanasia, and there is a very good reason for this. Can I tell you that I understand fully the arguments of people—and I have had discussions with a number of them today—who say that this is a matter that is either right or wrong. I fully respect the views of people who hold that position, that if it is wrong it is wrong. If the will of the Senate is that the Andrews bill should prevail and that this act which is currently lawful in the Northern Territory should as a result become unlawful, then for those people, as someone said to me earlier today, there is no middle ground on this.

I wish to God that issues like this were as black and white for me as they are for other people. I am sincere about that—they are not with me. I have to say this: there are two people in the Northern Territory who have availed themselves of all the requirements of this act, as opposed to it as I am. They have done that to this current point in time and, as we speak, lawfully. They are lawfully able to take that horrendous decision, from my perspective, of taking their own lives. Those two people are terminally ill. There is no question about that. They are not in that middle ground of patients that concerns me—aged patients, for example. They are terminally ill patients. They and their families have no doubt been through personally horrendous processes in coming to this decision.

They do not want to take that act now or in the next 24 hours or even in the next week. They have availed themselves of the currently lawful processes of this act so that, at a time of their choosing, they may end their own lives. I say `may', because there is no absolute guarantee, of course, that at the last minute they will. But I must say something which should, I think, occupy the minds of everybody in here: if we vote this transitional clause down and if the third reading vote reflects the second reading vote we have just had—it may not, but I am not going to run that risk—those people, in my view, will possibly choose to take their lives earlier than they would have otherwise. I think it is probable, considering the agony of decision they have been through already. I think there is a high probability that they may choose, even by one minute, to advance the time of their death.

That is something about which I can assure you, whatever my views, I am not comfortable at all. I certainly do not want to walk out of here tonight knowing that two people will kill themselves tomorrow as a result of the Senate vote. For that reason, I will be supporting the transitional clauses that Senator Brown is moving. I urge all other senators, whatever their views on this issue, to do the same.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing first with the amendment that Senator Brown has moved in relation to what we would call a `sunset clause', might I bring to the committee's attention a matter which the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee touched on in its hearings. It can be found on page 37 of its report. It dealt with the question of the Euthanasia Laws Bill and how it affected the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the questions raised was: was the Commonwealth, in effect, repealing a law of the Northern Territory or was it simply suppressing the law, as such, so that whilst the Andrews bill—as this bill has come to be known—was in force the territory law would be suppressed? Paragraph 4.58 states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The result of the enactment of the Bill would therefore seem to be to leave the RTI Act lying dormant on the NT statute book. It would revive if the Bill were to be repealed. It might also revive were the Northern Territory to become a State.

SPEECH.PARA: As I see it this sunset clause is saying, `Well, this bill would have a life of two years.' As I understand it, it is clause 2 that Senator Brown wants to amend to say that this will only be effective for two years unless repealed sooner. That would mean in accordance with those paragraphs from the committee's report that this bill would effectively suppress the Northern Territory legislation for that period of time, and then that legislation in the Northern Territory would revive of its own motion—of its own will, if you like—when this piece of federal legislation expires.

That, I believe, is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs. There are a couple of things that arise from that. Were the second amendment to be passed with this it would mean that someone could obtain a certificate in the Northern Territory allowing them to use the provisions of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. They could then sit on it for two years until that act was revived and the life of this piece of legislation had been extinguished. That would be an entirely unsatisfactory state of affairs. But, even without that second amendment, you still have a situation where the legislation in the territory could revive itself. I believe that this is a cynical exercise. It is not a desirable one. You either allow it to continue or you do not. You do not have a suppression for a period of time before it automatically revives.

In relation to the second amendment, I believe that there are problems with a person obtaining a certificate allowing them to use the provisions of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, but then sitting on that certificate if they so wish. That is an absurd result; one which I think is quite unsatisfactory in a legal sense. I reserve other remarks in relation to the second amendment to a later time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, it might be helpful for the committee if we know what amendment we are talking to. I would suggest that Senator Brown might like to move his amendments formally.
—Despite what was said a moment ago, the amendments have not been moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 2, after "doubt", insert "but subject to item 3,".
(3) Schedule 1, page 2, at the end of the Schedule, add:

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of anything in this Act, the provisions of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 continue to apply in respect of a patient who has signed, or on whose behalf a person acting in accordance with section 9 of that Act has signed, the certificate of request pursuant to paragraph 7(1)(i) of that Act on or before the date of commencement of this Act. This Act does not affect the lawfulness or validity of anything done in accordance with the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 after the commencement of this Act in respect of such a patient.

I will come back to those amendments shortly but, in brief, let me put it to the committee that Senator Collins is right. If the second reading vote is reflected in the third reading vote, we have an essential overriding of the Northern Territory laws. Everybody understands that. There are two patients, as is on the public record, who have gone through the whole process of the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 provisions for voluntary euthanasia.

These two people are both territorians. Both are dying. Indeed, they are close to death. Both are suffering enormously. Both have—after a long process with their medical attendants, after consultation with their loved ones, after deep consideration and reflection, as is required by the Northern Territory legislation—completed all the formalities which enable them to end their suffering at a time that they are best able to contemplate. That is their wish.

We know, from the short-term workings of this legislation, that it has worked properly. For those patients who have taken the option of voluntary euthanasia, it has been something which has relieved them enormously in their time of dying. It is something that their spouses, their partners, their next of kin, have subsequently endorsed and called for as a measure available to other people in that state.

Let me put to the committee this factor: there has been a strong argument from those in favour of the Andrews legislation, overriding the Northern Territory legislation, that we ought not be codifying voluntary euthanasia, that we ought be leaving it to the current common law practice—illegal as it might be for doctors to make the determination—and that the law in some way ought not intervene on the doctor-patient relationship.

Here we have very clearly—if my amendment is not put through—this committee, this Senate, this parliament, intervening very directly into the doctor-patient relationship. That will rupture a decision made at the behest of the patient with her/his doctors, including the medical specialists involved, if we say, `Retrospectively that agreement is null and void. We will not allow you this option of a dignified death, an end to your pain, as you want. We are going to intervene specifically as far as you two people are concerned. We are going to intervene on your doctor-patient relationship. We are going to countermand your wish, and the wish of your loved ones, that you be unable to put an end to your suffering in your own good time. We know better in this place. We ordain. That option is taken from you and you will suffer. You will suffer because we say so.'

I plead with this committee to recognise the gravity of that situation. I plead with members who have voted for this legislation not to tie these people, as they have already suffered, into more suffering because you vote for it. I plead with you to think of the specific circumstances of these good folk who have made their own determination.

I ask you to consider this: how could we say, `You can't make that decision. We are voting to end your option to end your own suffering. We are voting that you must suffer—as you do not want to—the indignity, the pain, the unacceptability of your dying days.' I plead with members to not allow that to be on the conscience of this Senate. I plead with members that, at least with these two people, we have the decency and the integrity to respect their wishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what Senator Brown has said, and there is no doubt that he speaks with great sincerity and in terms that must worry anybody who has to make a decision here tonight, because there is no doubt that what we are talking about tonight determines how people will face death—in many circumstances, a very cruel death. What we have debated in the period that we have debated this Euthanasia Laws Bill is that very question.

SPEECH.PARA: People like Senator Coonan have shown how we have to balance good public policy against the fact that people suffer and will suffer if we pass this bill tonight. It seems to me that that decision has been made and has been voted upon. What Senator Brown has said about the two people referred to here applies not only to them but to many other people as well. If we do it for those two people, it would be only fair that we do it for everybody who is in that situation. If we do it for everybody who is in that situation, then we will reverse the vote that we have made on the second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—Senator Collins interjects. Senator Collins, you have put your position as Senator Brown has put his, and we heard you put it very passionately. But you must look at the issue of public policy. You must look at what happens to anybody who is in this situation. If we vote for the amendments sincerely put forward by Senator Brown, who is a sincere man and a very compassionate man, we will leave people in terrible uncertainty. As Senator Ellison has said, do the two years mean that the bill finishes—
—We're dealing with 2 and 3.
—Hold on. I understand that. Just have some patience, Senator Schacht.
—I was trying to be helpful.

—Thank you for being helpful—and you have been helpful. Thanks everybody for being helpful. The point that I want to illustrate is that the amendments leave some uncertainty. Amendment 3 leaves uncertainty because it posits the consideration of whether or not we extend this further and further. We have debated this for some time now. We have to make our decisions. We must all look at our conscience. Everybody whom I have heard debate this has looked at their conscience and has made their decisions based on their conscience.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brown, this transitional provision has been proposed from the compassion of your heart, and I understand that. But, if it goes through, then, because of what I said before, the whole thrust of what has happened so far tonight is defeated. What you are saying is that there are exceptions, that there are some people who it is all right—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two.
—Two, Senator Kernot. But, then, if you do it for these two, why do you not do it for others?
—Because you can't.

—Hold on. You create a culture, you create an ethos and you create a way of thinking which is quite against the bill. You say that it is retrospective. It is not retrospective. These two people have not yet suffered death, and that is what would make it retrospective.
—They legally can do it tonight, Barney, after the vote.

—Senator Collins, they are legally not dead tonight, and that is the issue. If this bill is passed, they will not be. That is the point. You cannot do this. If you have compassion for two people, you should have compassion for all. You have to make the decision. If public policy demands that this bill get through, it demands that this transitional provision be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I am sorry, but I think you are wrong. Look very carefully at the wording of amendment 3, under the heading `Transitional'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of anything in this Act, the provisions of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 continue to apply in respect of a patient who has signed—
who has already signed—
or on whose behalf a person acting in accordance with section 9 of that Act has signed—
already—
the certificate of request . . .

To the best of our knowledge, there are two people in the Northern Territory who meet those qualifications. That is all—two people. We are not seeking to extend this widely and indefinitely. This is about two people who legally began the due processes of this particular piece of Northern Territory legislation.

It is callous and wrong for the 76 of us—a not particularly representative group, who happen to be elected as members of this Senate—to take away the choice that they exercised legally. They have begun the processes. In my view, it would be wrong of us to take away their last previously lawful hope. This would have been the hardest decision of their lives.

Through no fault of their own—because of the timing and the toing‐and‐froing of the bill; it was before the chamber, back out again, before this chamber and the other chamber—we decided by a vote a half an hour ago, or whenever it was, that suddenly the choice they exercised legally is no longer their choice. I think we should pay due respect to these two people. That is all it is—two people who are caught up by the timing of this vote of the Senate. I make the same entreaty as you, Senator Brown: consider these two individuals and support Senator Brown's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a comment about the conduct of the chamber in the second reading debate of the Euthanasia Laws Bill. It was lengthy. Many senators spoke on it. For the vast majority of the time, there were no interjections around the chamber. That was not the case when my colleague Senator Cooney spoke a short moment ago. I would hope that we do not degenerate this debate by catcalling across the chamber. It is a very important moment in the debate on this important bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I hold a different view from that of my colleague Senator Cooney. As somebody who participated on the losing side just very recently, in three votes, I actually started to have some hope when Senator Cooney was speaking. While he was speaking, I was able to read the amendment that Senator Brown has moved now. Before I was able to get to my feet, Senator Kernot made the very point that I was going to make. I will not repeat them, because they are already on the record. I do not want to unduly delay the processes.

But I do want to make this point: I have not met the two people in question. I do understand that these two people have made decisions for themselves. As Senator Cooney said a few moments ago, they are not dead yet, but they are the ones that have made the decisions. Hopefully, through the conduct of the committee stage of the bill, some questions about the definitions of the bill will be able to be answered by somebody who has responsibility for the bill. Hopefully that will be the case. I do not know whether it is going to be the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Senator Ellison); I do not know whether it is going to be Senator Herron. But I do hope that, before the endorsement of the matter before the committee—that the bill stand as printed—those uncertainties that certainly were evident through the deliberations of the Senate legal and constitutional committee and those questions will be cleared up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments first of all about the cessation of the operation of the act—the first amendment suggested by Senator Brown. Let me simply say from a public policy point of view: I would have thought that, if we are going to revisit this whole question, then it ought be in the context of a community debate again and not in a situation where, just due to the effluxion of time, a certain course of events is going to take place.
—He hasn't moved that amendment. He moved 2 and 3, not 1.

—I have just had indicated to me that he has not moved amendment No. 1, so allow me to move on to that area I was going to spend most of my time on, and that was amendments Nos 2 and 3. We have been given a very impassioned plea this evening for, as I understand it, two residents of the Northern Territory. The fact is that this amendment does not refer to two persons. It is completely open‐ended.
—They have signed.

—Senator Kernot says that they have signed. You have said in your commentary, Senator Kernot, `to the best of our knowledge'. How do we know that there are only two? It might be a dozen; it might be two dozen. We simply do not know. There is no public register of these people. We do not know whether or not this is genuine. I ask those who are genuinely interested to turn to section 7(1)(i) of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, to which Senator Brown's amendment refers. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The patient or person acting on the patient's behalf, in accordance with section 9, has, not earlier than seven days after the patient has indicated to his or her medical practitioner, as referred to in paragraph (f), signed that part of the certificate of request required to be completed by or on behalf of the patient.

That is only one of a whole lot of steps under the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act that have to be effected prior to somebody being able to avail themselves of the provisions of this act. Senator Brown's amendment, as I read it, does not even require the doctor's witnessing signature to it. Those of us who have an intimate knowledge of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act should look at, for example, section 8 subsection (2), which says:

Where a patient has requested assistance under this act and has subsequently been provided with palliative care that brings about the remission of the patient's pain or suffering, the medical practitioner shall not—
and it goes on. But it then says:

If subsequently the palliative care ceases to alleviate the patient's pain and suffering to levels acceptable to the patient, the medical practitioner may continue to assist the patient under this act only if the patient indicates to the medical practitioner the patient's wish to proceed.

There is no formal requirement with this intention to proceed after they have gone into remission or palliative care has assisted. So we have a circumstance which could apply, under Senator Brown's proposal, to an unknown number of people. In fact one of the people possibly could last with complete remission for three, four or five years. That is a possibility. That possibility is countenanced in the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. It is countenanced that that might happen. If that happens, despite us having said that we as a Senate are opposed to euthanasia, somebody might still be able to access the provisions of this legislation two or three years down the track.

Whilst I understand the emotional arguments—I do not dismiss them just because they are emotional; I understand them, Senator Brown and Senator Collins—I would ask honourable senators to look at the detailed provision of Senator Brown's amendment and then see what its implications are in real life and in practice. I have to say to honourable senators that the impact of this amendment is a lot, lot wider than has been put to us by those supporting the amendment.

I simply indicate that the Andrews' bill has been on the public agenda now for how long—six months or more? I think it was introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Andrews on 9 September 1996. It got carried in the House of Representatives on 9 December 1996. It has been around for a substantial period of time and I think those who are intimately interested in the provisions of this legislation were alerted to the fact that there may be a change in the law some sixth months or earlier. Given that, I think this legislation falls into a different category than if we were to spring it on the Australian community without warning. That needs to be kept in mind when considering amendments 2 and 3 moved by Senator Brown.

I repeat that the amendment for transitional provisions moved by Senator Brown does not state the number of people. Although we are being told it is only two people, there is no proof, no guarantee, of that. In fact, many others could sign up prior to royal assent, so I am not convinced that we are dealing with only two people. It may be any number of people. There might be people signed up with doctors other than Dr Nitschke who, for whatever reason, do not wish to go public on this issue.
Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before—and this is a very important aspect—Senator Brown's amendment relies on only those people who have signed the certificate in section 7(1)(i). The very small section of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act which Senator Brown refers to does not require the witnessing by a doctor.

BREAK.PARA: I also draw honourable senators' attention to section 17 of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, which states:
Certificate of request is evidence. A document purporting to be a certificate of request is, in any proceedings before a court, admissible in evidence and is prima facie evidence of the request.

So it is a `document purporting to be'. It does not actually have to be the document referred to in the schedule of the legislation, which I would have thought would be another cause for concern for those who have supported the second reading of the Andrews bill.

The amendment has been put to the Senate in a relatively simplistic way which does not highlight the very wide scope that this amendment will have and the potential to include many other people in its wake. Indeed, it could allow the terms of or regime under the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act to be accessed by people literally in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak again in this debate after this brief contribution on the matter of royal assent. It is an important issue. This is a bill unlike any other. That is a fact. We all know that this so-called private member's bill is, in real terms, nothing of the sort for the simple reason that no private member's bill in the history of this parliament has been given the priority that this bill has—over, in fact, significant parts of the government's own legislation. That is also a matter of fact. I know, because it is a matter of public record—the frontbench has complained of this in here; it is in the Hansard —that a number of ministers have in fact been agitated about the difficulty they are having in getting their own legislation on the calendar of this parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is here only because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave it the support that he did and ensured that it had priority over government legislation. For that reason I appeal to the Prime Minister, rightly or wrongly, about this bill's royal assent. Because this bill is unlike any other, if this bill passes unamended through the Senate it is technically possible for the government to take this bill to the Governor-General for his immediate signature provided that the Governor-General is available or has not gone to bed.

I think few people in this chamber would not agree that this is one of those matters where, if it is going to be done, it is best that it be done quickly, for the reasons that senators on both sides have enunciated. I notice that government senators, whichever side of the debate they are on, are in fact agreeing with that proposition, are supporting it, for all those reasons.

I apologise to the committee for not making it clear earlier that I would not be supporting amendment 1 of Senator Brown's amendments—I explained that to him earlier this evening when I asked him whether he would be splitting them—because the two years does not make any sense to me. It is 2 and 3 that I am supporting.

I appeal to the Prime Minister that, whatever the result in the Senate tonight, for everyone's sake this legislation goes to Yarralumla as quickly as possible so that the Governor-General can, whatever the result is, sign into law what passes the Senate here tonight. If these amendments are carried, I hope the bill goes back to the House of Representatives as speedily as it possibly can and then to the Governor-General for his assent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to just briefly countermand part of the contribution from Senator Abetz and reiterate to the committee that there are two people dying tonight in the Northern Territory who have completed a request form and signed it, having waited the necessary seven days, and who have asked that they be given the right to determine when they will, through voluntary euthanasia, end their suffering, as four other people before them have done.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Abetz may be able to say there might be 10 or 12, but the reality is there are two. There is no way we can end that disputation. I say there are two—and, as Senator Crowley said by way of interjection, so what if there are five? The question is: what if? But the fact is there are two.

From what Senator Collins has said, the passage of the bill, with or without this amendment, is going to see it enacted within a couple of days, if not less. Those two folk in those tragic circumstances in the Northern Territory have had the necessary consultations with their doctors and specialists in order to comply with the law to give them that option.

I say again: how can we as individuals or as a committee interpolate ourselves into that doctor-patient relationship, into the heart-rending circumstances of those people who are dying and suffering, and say, `No. We know better down here in Canberra, on this late night sitting, about your circumstances. We know better than you do, than your doctors do, than your loved ones do, and we say you should continue to suffer because we think that is a reasonable outcome.' Well, I don't think it is. I think that is a heartless outcome.

We can listen to legal intricacies and doubt being sown by Senator Abetz, but it does not alter the circumstances of those two people. We can hear the offer that they go to the Sisters of Charity or somewhere else, but these are people who have had palliative care options available to them and they do not want to be shunted off somewhere else by the suggestion of a senator in here. They want to die with their loved ones, where they are, under the circumstances they have worked out. Unlike most of us, they are dying tonight. They are suffering tonight. They have made their determinations in the last few days or weeks about how they want to handle their suffering and their indignity.

I make that plea again to some of you who have voted for the generality that there be no voluntary euthanasia available to the citizens of the Northern Territory, even though their legislature has accorded them that right. Do not move into the homes, the bedrooms and the dying circumstances of these two people and their families and say retrospectively, `We are going to override your signature on that certificate and turndown the request you have made.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My earlier remarks were largely addressed to amendment No. 1. In relation to amendments Nos 2 and 3, might I just point out a practical fact; that is, if these two amendments are passed, this bill then has to go back to the other place and be considered.
—It has to anyway.

—It has to be debated, Senator Murphy, and that could take some time. What I am telling you now is that the question of royal assent could take some time because of what might happen in the other place. You cannot deny the fact that the other place would want to debate these amendments, because they are proving to be quite controversial tonight and no doubt would prove controversial in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no guarantee that these amendments will not pass through or be dealt with by the other place until the budget sittings in May. That would mean an intervening period of up to six weeks, during which time other people could have certificates signed and then come under the amendment here. You would have possibly many more than two people bringing themselves within the time frame.

So it is not just two. If there were that intervening period of some six weeks, other people could bring themselves within the provisions of this amendment. We cannot guarantee what will happen in the other place. We cannot guarantee that royal assent might not happen for some weeks hence. That is the dilemma.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Just one small point. I do believe that Senator Ellison is not correct in his understanding here. Even if this bill is defeated tonight, and even if the transitional arrangements are defeated tonight, people in the Northern Territory, or anywhere in Australia who go to the Northern Territory, will be under the law until royal assent signs this bill into effect. So it does not matter whether we have the transitional amendments or not.

SPEECH.PARA: For people who want to actually choose the right under law in the Northern Territory to die, they can do so legally until royal assent. They are legally able to do that at the moment. The transitional arrangements would simply make it beyond doubt. They are not necessary for these people, unless these people are then bound to hasten their time of departure. But under the law now, even if everything is defeated tonight, until the time of royal assent people are within the law.

If the Andrews bill is successful and all the transitional amendments are defeated, still anybody who wishes to, until the time of royal assent, can avail themselves of what is currently legal in the territory. Just a small point, Senator Ellison, but you need to have it clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard much tonight about retrospectivity. I think what Senator Bob Collins pointed out tonight is right. In a sense, without the transitional arrangements as proposed by Senator Brown, under the law of the Northern Territory as it exists, having been democratically decided by that parliament, people who have indicated that at some stage in the near to intermediate future they want to die, to save themselves the pain, will quite simply have their choice retrospectively changed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always been interested that in this chamber the one thing that will get most Liberal members of parliament absolutely excited is any effort to retrospectively change the law, particularly on tax matters. I had a very minor amendment on retrospectivity to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. From the screaming and the shouting from Liberal members, you would have thought that I had brought the whole palace down on top of me! This was changing the rules after people had already claimed the diesel fuel rebate—even though it was clearly being rorted—and making sure that three companies could not go back and claim $80 million worth of diesel fuel rebate back to 1987.

This is what the government, when I was customs minister, proposed. It was vigorously opposed by every member of the Liberal Party and the National Party as something terrible.
