They said, `This is retrospectivity. How dare you tax and take money off people when they thought they were acting under the customs bill at that time.' Now, when two people's lives are at stake and they have made a choice, retrospectively we are saying here, `Stiff, you can't do it. We are interposing in the meantime. Retrospectively we're changing your choice.' They knowingly made that decision under a democratically elected parliament of the Northern Territory.

I have to say that I deplore the humbug about retrospectivity from people opposite. I am more than happy to point it out. You are quite willing to argue to save a tax bill. You say, `It's awful that a company may have to pay more tax retrospectively,' but you assert that two people who have made a decision under the law cannot choose to have that decision flow through. I find that humbug appalling.

I think that what Senator Brown has proposed is quite a reasonable transitional arrangement. Senator Abetz and Senator Ellison have issues such as: `We are not sure whether people have filled in the right papers,' or `It may take a few days to get royal assent,' or `Other sneaky people who are dying may rush to the Northern Territory and take the decision capriciously to end their lives.' That really is putting ordinary people in Australia down. To say that capriciously, and because there might be a gap of a few days, people will rush to the Northern Territory and say, `Hallelujah! I'm saved. I'm going to die before royal assent is given' is a joke. It demeans this debate on euthanasia.

I make no bones about the fact that I strongly support the right of voluntary euthanasia, not just in the Northern Territory but in Australia, full stop. I can imagine the media in the next few days if this bill goes through without this transitional arrangement. Can you imagine what will be in the media? Photographs of these two people. They will be there in some awful interview saying, `Why wouldn't they let me have my choice? Thirty‐eight senators want me to die in agony.'

BREAK.PARA: I understand the moral dimension and the argument, but that is what they will be saying. People in the community will say, `What is going on in this parliament of Australia? Two people who genuinely made a decision under the law as it existed have had that right retrospectively taken away from them.' I have to say that that will do no good to the standing of the Australian parliament. Retrospectivity in respect of the diesel fuel rebate is nothing compared to the image of retrospectively removing the choice from these two people. I say to Senator Abetz and Senator Ellison that, if a couple more people actually use it before the royal assent takes place, they made a knowing choice. I do not think it is going to damage the fabric of society.

I conclude on this point: we should not be governed overwhelmingly by public opinion polls. On the issue of capital punishment, probably 50 per cent or 60 per cent of people in Australia are in favour of the re-introduction of capital punishment. I certainly strongly oppose capital punishment. But I have seen very few issues in my 30 years in public life where 80 per cent of ordinary citizens are in favour. Eighty per cent of Australians are in favour of voluntary euthanasia. I wish we could get that vote for the Labor Party. I wish we could get 80 per cent for any issue. I cannot recollect any issue of controversy having such genuine support across the community, across party boundaries, across ethnic and religious divides, across geographic and socioeconomic boundaries. It really is extraordinary. Seventy per cent to 80 per cent of Australians think it is not unreasonable that, if you are experiencing great suffering, you have a right to die with some dignity.

Two people have made a choice, under the law as it stands now, and this parliament is going to dishonour that choice. That will be an extraordinary record for this parliament, particularly for this Senate. I support amendments Nos 2 and 3 moved by Senator Brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I rise to my feet because of the previous contribution to the debate. I suppose I have been against the death penalty for far more years than Senator Schacht. I am not going to argue the case again. We have dealt with that in the second reading stage. I just remind you that if, after Port Arthur, there had been a public opinion poll taken in my state of Tasmania—
—Anywhere else in Australia.

—Yes, as Senator Collins says, or anywhere else in Australia, about the death penalty, there would have been a vote in favour of it. Do you think that we should respond to that by taking action to restore the death penalty? Certainly not. I acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: But in respect of the matters that we are talking about, let me just put it to you this way. In respect of retrospectivity, if, for example there is a contract made between a worker and an employer and that contract is legal at a particular time and it is absolutely substandard and is, in effect, slave labour—it could happen, to be quite frank, under—

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the current government's laws.

—I was going to say under current industrial relations law and then there was a change of government and that was removed, do you think it would be appropriate to say it would be retrospective to cover those sorts of slave labour situations? Of course, it would not.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, if there were a situation where there was slavery, let me make this point to you: two rights under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights—and there are more rights—are inalienable; that is, the right to life and the right to liberty. As to the latter, that means that, even though you do sell yourself into slavery, that cannot be recognised in law. The same with the inalienable right to life.

Those things ought to be considered because it is important that society and individuals recognise that. You talk about the public opinion polls; if the public were asked, `Do you agree that a doctor should be able to intentionally take the life of a patient who has requested it?' then the result, I believe, would be different.

Finally, in respect of these amendments, there is a problem. There is no register of who has decided to make requests under the Northern Territory legislation. There would be no way to ascertain the effect of these amendments if they were adopted. There could be a situation where certificates are backdated and it would be very difficult without a register to combat the backdating of certificates of request. This would be particularly so when you have a doctor like Dr Nitschke who says, `I do not care about the law. I am going ahead anyhow. I am prepared to break the law.' That is his view; that is his publicly stated position.

Under the Northern Territory legislation, the coroner has no jurisdiction to investigate any deaths as long as the paperwork is in order and no other matter which has come to his attention makes him suspect that the act has not been complied with. I believe that these amendments now before the chamber would be totally unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish to move an amendment.
—You said you would not speak again.

—I said I was not going to speak again to Senator Brown's amendment—I am not; I am going to change it. I wish to move an amendment to Senator Brown's amendment. I apologise; there was no discourtesy intended, Senator Brown. I just did not have time to come to talk to you about it.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment at least partially addresses the concerns of Senator Abetz, who would not vote for this in any case, as we all know—no-one in the Lyons Forum would—and the concerns that Senator Harradine has raised and it gets right away from the royal assent. The transitional clause currently reads:

In spite of anything in this Act, the provisions of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 continue to apply in respect of a patient who has signed, or on whose behalf a person acting in accordance with section 9 of that Act has signed, the certificate of request pursuant to paragraph 7(1)(i) of that Act on or before the date of commencement of this Act.

I wish to remove the words `the date of commencement of this Act' and replace them with the words `the 23.03.97'. That is yesterday's date, not today's date, so there will not be a rush of people thundering up to the Northern Territory, which I might add there has not been to this point in time when it is legal. It is yesterday's date, not today's date. It closes the book as of yesterday. We all know that there are not any doctors other than Dr Nitschke involved in this question of euthanasia.

I was interested to hear Senator Harradine mention in his contribution, with which I do not argue, that the two inalienable rights guaranteed by international covenants are life and liberty. The reason I note that is that if that is the case then it would be absolutely lawful for this parliament to pass a bill. If Senator Harradine, as he is doing, is extending that inalienable right to life, guaranteed by international covenant on which this parliament relies for its laws for its constitutional validity, if that is true and does apply to euthanasia, it would be absolutely open to this parliament to do precisely what my amendment suggested and pass a law that would apply to the whole of Australia and not simply to the Northern Territory.
My amendment simply takes the date of the commencement of this act out of the amendments of Senator Brown and replaces it with yesterday's date. Accordingly, I move:
Amendment No. 2, omit "the date of commencement of this Act", substitute "23 March 1997".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Bob Collins is doing. From the point of view that has been put so eloquently by Senator Brown and Senator Schacht, it would be right. I do not think it gets over the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: When you talk about retrospectivity, what you talk about is making something illegal that was lawful at the time when it was made. This bill we are passing does not make illegal anything that has happened until now. The signing of the certificate, the making of the choice, the discussion that the patient may have had with the doctor—all that remains legal. So the process is all legal till now. What is made illegal is the process from now on, which includes the actual killing.

BREAK.PARA: So it is not retrospective in the sense that nothing that has happened so far becomes illegal. Everything is legal, everything is lawful, until now.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what about the two people?

—I will come to the two people. Senator Schacht raised the issue of capital punishment. Let us say that a territory passed a law making capital punishment legal and that we passed a law such as the one tonight saying that from now on capital punishment is illegal. Would people get up and say, `Because the process has been put into operation, the consequences of that process should follow?' What we are making illegal is the consequences of what has been lawful until now. This is not a retrospective provision. It might be a harsh provision.
—What if it provokes someone into killing themselves before their time?

—It might be a harsh provision; I am not disagreeing with you there at all. But, if it is a harsh provision, then everything that we have done, including the decision that we have made tonight to overturn the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act in the Northern Territory, is harsh. If we let this through, what would we be doing? We would be allowing two people rights that nobody else had. I concede that those two people are suffering and that they suffer terribly, but why should they have a right which nobody else in a similar position has—
—Because they might exercise that right while they still can.
—Because they have made a decision and they have signed a piece of paper prior to this bill being put through tonight.

BREAK.PARA: It seems to me that what you are doing when talking about these two people is talking about the anguish which everybody has experienced, which everybody has suffered in debating this bill. This has not been an easy decision, and these two people illustrate how hard a decision it has been. If you are against euthanasia, then you are against it for everyone.

The other point I want to make is that, when you talk about two people, you talk about them as only two people. In my view, every life is important. Two people's lives, if you take the point of view that we do, are very important. We do not say, `It is good to kill two people, it is good to kill one person but it is bad to kill 20 or 30 or 40 people.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying that.
—I know you are not saying that, Senator Collins. Do not get upset, because I know that you are anguishing more than most.
—It is a difficult debate.

—Of course it is a difficult debate. What I am saying is that when you talk about these things in emotional terms—which you must do and which you are entitled to do—remember that they are not the only two people suffering. I do not want in any way to belittle the suffering that they have gone through so far and what they will go through, but they are symbolic of lots and lots of people who now are suffering and who in the future will suffer. We as a parliament have had to struggle with this issue, and we have come to the decision that we have made tonight. Having made that decision, I think we have to include everybody, not everybody but two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not make a habit of jumping up after each intervention by Senator Cooney. This time I will not seek to defend him either. I am going to slightly disagree with what he has to say without taking him directly or head on. I also want to make some comments about what Senator Harradine had to say on public opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: If the committee does not pass the amendment that we are now debating, we will be effectively depriving two individuals who are competent to make decisions for themselves of the right to have a good death or a gentle death or an easy death. That is what we will be denying them. We will be making that decision. We will be taking away from them the right to have a good death, a gentle death or an easy death. Irrespective of how long we debate the matter, we will not be depriving them of their right to take their own life.

Senator Cooney has argued that the provision should apply to everybody. I do not know how we would include everybody, other than going back and revisiting earlier votes. Despite my personal wishes, I do not believe that the committee will do that. We are not going to do that.

I do not know the two people that we are talking about. However, we know that there are at least two people who want to take advantage of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act of the Northern Territory. We know that they are in existence. I certainly believe that they have made their own conscience decision to do it. I do not know what physical condition those people are in or whether they were able to take their own lives. I certainly know, from reading the last note of the late Bob Dent, that he was not in a position to take his own life. He could not even write his own death note; that very moving note that was published just after he passed away last year. He had to get his wife to do it. It was a very descriptive and moving note. It certainly had a huge impact on me.

Another matter that moved me—that actually shocked me—was the figures that Mr Marshall Perron gave to the Senate committee when it took evidence in Darwin of the number of suicides that occurred by people who were aged 75 years and older in the five-year period 1990 to 1994. Those figures shocked me. There were 672 people officially recorded as having suicided. These were elderly Australians who had probably made enormous contributions to Australian life and who ended it by the following means: 171 of them hanged themselves, 17 of them used agricultural chemicals to end their lives, two people used corrosive or caustic substances, 130 used firearms on themselves, 14 of them using cutting and piercing instruments, and the list goes on.

There were 672 people aged 75 years and older who ended their lives like that. Of those 672, 137 were aged 85 or older. They are shocking figures. They really are shocking figures that ought to shame Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The two people we are talking about are nameless as far as I am concerned; I have not met them. Are we going to condemn them to the same end as those 672 others? At least can we not have some compassion in our hearts at this time to give those two people their stated wish to have an easy and gentle death, one that they choose for themselves and in the manner in which they choose. We have certainly condemned a whole number of others to dramatic deaths, as shown from the figures that I illustrated before.

I said I wanted to make some comments about the matter of public opinion which Senator Harradine addressed. I have not been one of the people through this debate who has formulated in my mind what I thought public opinion was. I have not to the best of my knowledge in any of the public hearings, in any of the conversations I have had or in any of the letters that I wrote—there have certainly been over 1,000—used the stated public opinion polls of who is in favour or who is not in favour. I am not sure what the figures are.

Like most politicians, I have an inherent distrust of public opinion polls because I know that the questions can be framed in different ways. For that reason, earlier this evening I supported the proposition that this bill ought to be the subject of a properly constituted referendum of the people of Australia. I supported that. I was defeated in that move. The majority of the Senate voted the other way.

We have deprived ourselves of finding out what public opinion is on this bill. Certainly, the number of submissions to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee were overwhelmingly in support of the Andrews bill but they, in turn, need some analysis. I have not done the analysis; I do not think it is up to me. I do not have the time to do that analysis. Certainly the hardworking team of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, under the stewardship of Neil Bessell, does not have the time or, indeed, the resources to do the analysis.

What I did do and what I indicated in my speech on the second reading was some of my own analysis as my responsibility as a politi cian and as a representative of the electors of Western Australia. Some of those people—not everyone—who wrote to me, including the author of the one-page letter I read out during the second reading debate, I did ring back. Some of them gave me a phone number. I also phoned some of the others who did not leave a phone number. I did some checking through the phone book and found the numbers of some of them. I talked to them, not to convince them against the view that they had put to me, but to recognise at first‐hand—I do this reasonably frequently—that I had received their letter and I understood their concerns but I wanted to find out where they were coming from.

On that latter point, I was bitterly disappointed. Most of the people—I must say, it was not in the hundreds—that I spoke to did not understand what the Andrews bill was about. They knew it was called the Andrews bill but they did not understand what the Andrews bill was about. Most of the people thought that the parliament of Australia, through the Senate, was bringing in a bill to make the killing of older people unlawful. That is what they thought. I tried to reassure them on that. In most cases I was not able to; they had it set in their minds.

In my speech on the second reading I condemned the people who misled the public in that way. I still stand by that condemnation. Now is not the time to further that debate. We have very important matters to debate in the committee stage of the bill. In talking about public opinion on the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act and the Euthanasia Laws Bill, I felt it important enough to again make a contribution to the debate in order to attempt to put some of the record straight on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I rise to support Senator Collins's amendment. I do so to reiterate the basis on which it is made—not to recanvass the issue of the euthanasia debate but to say that, in the absence of the carriage of this amendment, what we may do would be to cause the two people that we know of who have signed an authority under the Northern Territory legislation to bring forward their decision to end their lives. I support the amendment to prevent that, and not for the purpose of, in some way, by the back door, authorising the Northern Territory legislation or ratifying it in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: I fear, however, that that amendment will be lost. To use Senator Cooney's words, there are those in this debate who take the view that if we show compassion for these two, we have to show it for all. I am afraid that that will be the basis on which this amendment is defeated, but I hope that it is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to accept the amendment that Senator Bob Collins has made to my amendment.
—Senator Brown, it is before the committee. It has been moved by Senator Collins and it will be put in accordance with the standing orders.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bob Collins's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I can scarcely believe the circumstances that I find myself in tonight in this chamber. You opposite call it a stunt, but I have my right to feel compassion for those people you have almost voted into a painful finish tonight and will vote into if you continue the way you are going. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, after clause 2, insert:
This Act, unless sooner repealed, ceases to be in force at the end of 2 years after the date of commencement.

That amendment is meant to at least allow the apparent majority in this parliament, which is overriding the preponderant majority of citizens of Australia, to think again, because this amendment, in effect, would say that, two years from now, this Euthanasia Laws Bill would cease to have effect unless another similar bill is put through this parliament. In other words, two years down the line, let you who have voted for this legislation reflect on what you have done tonight. If you are confident that the actions of this parliament against the feelings of this nation are correct, let you have the confidence to do it again in front of the people of Australia that you are set to represent two years down the line.

How could you, majority, if that is the vote that is coming, say, `Not only do we override the elected representatives of the Northern Territory; we also override the 75 per cent or more of Australians who in every opinion poll say, "We want the option of voluntary euthanasia for ourselves"'? Those polls specifically say that, `at a patient's request, a doctor gives a lethal dose to end the person's suffering'. How could you say to two individuals whom you do not know about, but whom you ought to have the compassion to relate to, that, notwithstanding their wish, after reflection and after having signed the necessary documentation, to die with some peace and to avoid some of the terrible suffering they are facing: `We will not let you do it. We intervene. We know better than you do. Notwithstanding your pain, your suffering and your indignity, we—as people in this chamber in Canberra elected to represent you—override your fundamental wish in this, your dying hour'?

It is a moment of shame on this Senate and this parliament. It is a moment of failure to connect with the compassion of the Australian people. It is a moment of great indignity—an abrogation of the democratic process as I see it. I have heard the arguments and I have listened to the debate. But, at the end of the day, if the majority continues to prevail we are not only voting here to fail miserably in our obligation of compassion to two adults who know their own minds and who are dying, we are also failing to connect in a compassionate way with the 18 million people that we represent and to say to them, `You have a right to determine matters of great importance, not least the mode of your dying when the hour is nigh, you have no alternative and you are suffering for yourself.' There is in this an arrogance and a disdain and a failure of compassion which I think is probably unprecedented in this parliament. However, that may be. I now want to test this committee and this Senate to face the people, to face the reaction of this decision two years hence.

If you are confident you are doing the right thing tonight, then show that confidence and that self‐assuredness by saying, `We'll accept the sunset clause for this legislation. Let it run for two years and then we'll put it through again to show that we were right back in 1997.' I submit you are wrong. I submit you ought to listen to the Australian people's reaction to this behaviour tonight. I submit you should at least support this amendment to the euthanasia laws bill which tramples that courageous legislation in the Northern Territory. Two years hence test your courage again after people have been able to react to tonight's decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is amendment No. 1 on the running sheet. Page 1, after clause 2, insert: `2A Cessation of operation of Act. This Act, unless sooner repealed, ceases to be in force at the end of two years after the date of commencement.' Those of that opinion say aye to Senator Brown's amendment, those against say no. I think the noes have it. Division required? Two voices? We only heard one up here, Senator Brown. The noes have it.
—The question now is that the bill be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, those against say no.
—Before that happens, I would like to put some questions to the senator about some specific matters which I think need to be cleared up.
—To Senator Herron? To whom?

—Yes, to Senator Herron, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I asked him a series of questions earlier in the night. He has totally failed to answer those. But it is very important, I think, that we clear up some particular difficulties with this legislation, and that the host of this legislation explain to the committee in particular why there is no definition given in this legislation of what is meant by the words `intentional killing', `euthanasia', `mercy killing' or `the assisting of another person to terminate his or her life'. I ask if Senator Herron would give a definition of those important words, in particular `intentional killing'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known what those terms are. They have been debated for a long time. I think it is futile to prolong the debate in this regard. It has been well known all along what those terms relate to. They have been spelled out in the legislation. They are a result of common law—
—And they are in the report.
—And they are in the report.

—(11.13 p.m.)—For the benefit of the committee, it is not good enough to say `well known'. I am asking the host of this bill to determine those two pivotal words in this legislation. It is not my legislation, but it is legislation that we are about to vote on again. They are pivotal. They will be potentially tested, and it is very important that the committee hear what that definition is.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman. What Senator Herron might or might not think would properly define intentional killing is utterly irrelevant. They are the words that will be contained in the bill and, if necessary, they will be interpreted by a court. But it makes no difference at all whether Senator Herron defines them in one way or another. It cannot possibly assist the Senate in making a decision on the matter.
—There is no point of order. The senator is entitled to ask questions of the minister who has the carriage of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered those questions.

—I wonder if Senator Herron could point out to me in the committee's report where the clarity of the definition of the words `intentional killing' occurs or can he, from the uncertainty that was raised in the committee's report, point the committee in a direction where that uncertainty has been cleared up?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —They are matters of common law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee, during its deliberations, was very grateful for the assistance given to it by Mr Geoffrey Dabb from the Attorney-General's Department. It certainly is worth while directing the committee to the comments of Mr Dabb that appeared in the committee's report. There is obviously a much more extensive elicitation of what Mr Dabb had to say in the transcript of the Senate committee hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: There is uncertainty that was clearly enunciated not only by Mr Dabb but by the Attorney-General for the ACT, who also appeared before the committee. That uncertainty is there, and I think there are some obligations on behalf of the sponsors of the bill to clear up the uncertainty. It is not fair enough, Senator Herron, just to say that it is a matter of common law and that the definitions are there in common law. It just is not good enough. There needs to be some greater clarity than what has been given so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, unfortunately, we are on broadcast. There are people in the gallery, and I would not want them to go away from this debate thinking that the term `intentional killing' and other terms have not been looked at with a great degree of thought by the Senate committee, which Senator Ellison chaired and then, at the latter stages, I chaired.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of intentional killing was discussed at some considerable length. There were two basic views that could be adopted: one was the narrow meaning; the other was the broader meaning. Some people postulated that the broader meaning might be adopted, but not a single person argued for the proposition that, as a matter of good public policy, the broader meaning, in fact, ought be adopted.

Indeed, I do not want to delay the committee any longer, because these issues have been dealt with at length. For those who are genuinely interested, it is all here in the report. But, at the end of the day, what did Mr Dabb say about the bill? He said:
The bill has to me all the signs of being drafted with a high degree of professional competence and I would assume that expert legal advice has gone into the drafting of this bill.
And this is the important bit:
It seems to strike the right balance between simplicity and not becoming overcomplicated in trying to deal with every situation.

As I said in the second reading debate, the situation is very clear that, even if there were no uncertainty, with due respect to my profession, lawyers would create some uncertainty somewhere. Even our constitution is being argued about every single day in the High Court after—what?—96 years. You will never get it absolutely certain until such time as there is judicial interpretation of it.

With respect to those who take the view that the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act ought be supported, it also has a lot of uncertain terminology in it which was explored at great length in the Northern Territory, which was that part of the hearing which Senator Brown, in fact, did not attend. At the end of the day, according to Mr Dabb, it struck `the right balance between simplicity and not becoming overcomplicated in trying to deal with every situation'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree, in part, with what Senator Abetz had to say about the contributions that people made to the committee deliberations, but I do have to differ with him that the uncertainty has been cleared up. In the committee report, which was presented to this chamber very recently, collectively we had this to say. Point 4.33, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: However, any attempt to state exactly what actions are justified leads back to the general uncertainties in this area of the law that have already been referred to.
We are talking about intentional killing. Point 4.34 states:

Analysis of whether the Bill would affect the operation of the Northern Territory's Natural Death Act and the ACT's Medical Treatment Act brought to light uncertainties in the meaning of both Acts. It is not proposed to traverse the uncertainties here.
The committee said that. It continues:

It is sufficient to state that the effect of them is to render it impossible to give an unequivocal answer to the question whether enactment of the Bill would affect the operation of either or both of these two Acts.

I put it to you, Mr Temporary Chairman Watson, and to the committee that the uncertainty remains. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has done its job. They have traversed the evidence. They have listened to opinion coming from eminent individuals, and they have reported back to the Senate. They have indicated to the Senate in this report that there are uncertainties.

I put it to you, Senator Herron, if you have carriage of this bill, that there is an obligation upon you to find out and examine those uncertainties and put the committee at ease as to what the uncertainties are. Let us have some clarity in the bill before it finally is enacted into law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to put on record the situation a little bit more broadly because of possible legal ramifications later on. I would like to indicate to the committee that it is the view of those who support this measure—though they can reject that if they wish—that there are only two views you can take about the word `intentional': one is the broad view and one is the narrow view. That has been made perfectly clear by those others who have contributed to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, the court will be strongly guided in interpreting the legislation by what the explanatory memorandum says and what we are saying about it. During the hearings, in response to a question by Senator Abetz, Mr Dabb said:

I think a court would probably approach this by saying, `I have to get at the intention of the Commonwealth parliament in saying this. What really was the intention of the Commonwealth parliament?' If every speaker who had spoken in support of the bill said, `Our clear understanding and purpose is that intentional killing has a narrow meaning so it only catches an act for the purpose of killing,' then I think that is likely to be a decisive consideration on how a court interpreted it.

I think that is perfectly clear. Therefore, there is no problem of uncertainty. Senators who are supporting the bill need only to continue to confirm in the debate—as I am doing, and as I believe those speakers who are supporting the bill in this particular response to Senator Brown are doing—what should be obvious anyhow.

It should be obvious that we intend the word `intention' to have its narrow meaning, and that is what we consider the bill to say. If Mr Dabb is correct—I am sure he is—that what is said in this debate will be taken into account by any judge, then they would take into account that the word `intention' is to have its narrow meaning.

If this is leading to a possible amendment to the bill, I do not believe that there is any need to amend the bill. The law traditionally uses the word `intention' rather than `purpose' in criminal law. Provided it is given the narrow meaning, the word is as clear as you can get it. Bringing the word `purpose' into this area would simply open up new uncertainties, if that is what people are thinking about doing. Senator Herron and others have spoken. I hope that my clarification will be seen by Senator Brown as responding to his question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —How extraordinary that Senator Harradine should take the narrow view. The fact is that we do not have a viewpoint being put by this committee. We are told that it can be the broad or the narrow.
—I guess we will have to leave it up to the judges again to make the law. I thought the government was opposed to that.

—Exactly. Legislation that does not make it clear what it intends is bad legislation. Mr Dabb has been quoted, but he made it clear in his evidence that there were significant potential problems for the law if this bill passed as is. There was a line of eminent legal opinion to say that the lack of definition of the terms in this legislation would create problematic uncertainty as to the legal situation in the territories surrounding end of life medical decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opinions included David Bennett QC; Rex Wild QC; Tom Pauling QC; Mr Gary Humphries, the ACT Attorney‐General; Dr Margaret Otlowski, senior lecturer in law at the University of Tasmania; and Miss Meg Wallace. The fact is that the bill, by failing to have definition, may very well cut across the Natural Death Act 1988 of the Northern Territory and the consent to medical treatment act of the ACT. It may invalidate these pieces of legislation because it does not define what intentional killing means.

BREAK.PARA: We are not going to get that definition here. It is significant that the mover of this legislation in this place has failed to come forward with any clarification. There are other matters that I would put to Senator Herron, but I fear he is going to serially refuse to come up with any definition, any explanation, any justification or any clear response at all on the matter.

One matter is the problem of double effect. That is, if a doctor in palliative care is increasing the dose of medication that is required to allay a person's suffering, and knows that by increasing it further it will lead to the person's early death, what is the situation as far as that doctor is concerned? Is it acceptable that that doctor is leading to the early death of the patient through increasing that dose? Where does the law separate these things out?

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on whether the judge has a narrow view or a broad view.

—Let us not leave it to the judge. Let us leave it to the host of this legislation and hear what Senator Herron, himself a doctor, has to say about the definition of double effect and how it should be handled with respect to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Harradine's contribution and am grateful to him for reminding us of the contribution that Mr Dabb made before the Senate committee when he gave evidence. I listened to it at the time and thought there was something strange about it. I am still uncertain in my mind, and now direct my question specifically to the minister. It is my understanding that the Acts Interpretation Act is the act that gives the power to refer to the second reading speech. It gives a power, as I understand it—I may be wrong; I am asking a genuine question here—to refer to the minister's second reading speech, not the speeches of the 30, 40 or 50 backbenchers speaking in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully you can come up with an answer to this one. If there is no interpretation contained within the act, do the courts, when challenged for an interpretation on the meaning of the law, then refer to the minister's second reading speech or do they refer to all the second reading speeches? And, in referring to all the second reading speeches, do they then take account of who mentioned intentional killing in this instance, and do they count the numbers on that? It is a very serious question, and I hope the committee can get clarity on the matter before we do finally vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am wondering what the legal situation is for nurses under this legislation. I want to make it clear that on Friday morning I predicted that we would get to the situation before very long where there would be people complaining about a proper debate on this matter tonight. I am not going to hold this committee up, but there are some matters of very great importance about the impact of this law on the Australian people. I want to make it clear that I will at least have a brief essay into those matters, even if we get no response whatever from Senator Herron on it, because they are important. I am not going to bow to the pressure of those opposite who want to go home to bed because they have been able to have their wishes met as far as this critical legislation is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask, through you, Chair: how do you respond, Senator Herron, to the concerns raised by those who spoke before the committee on behalf of Australian nurses as to the legal effect of the Andrews bill, as expressed to the committee by Ms Meg Wallace on behalf of the Royal College of Nursing in Australia? You will be aware that the legal position of nurses is different from that of doctors in this situation, given that Australian law does not view them as merely an agent or instrument for implementing doctors' orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just make a couple of comments in respect of the issue of the meaning or the definition of the term `intentional killing'. Firstly, I do agree with the remarks of Senator Harradine, and certainly he speaks for those people who have voted in favour of the Euthanasia Laws Bill when he says that it is clearly intended that the words have their narrow meaning. Some people thought it was a rather jocular comment that we could talk about narrow meanings and wide meanings, but people who have some knowledge of the law know that they are terms that clearly have a meaning in terms of statutory interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is this: we have got to look at this legislation before the Senate and how it relates to the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, and how the Northern Territory legislation relates to the criminal code. The position is that the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act created an exemption—as it were, created a defence—to what would otherwise have been—provided it was proved, of course, in a court of law—a criminal offence, that is, the criminal offence of intentional killing pursuant to the relevant crimes act or criminal code. That is the same throughout the rest of the country, if you look at any crimes act in the states. The term `intentional killing' has been defined over years and years of operation of the common law, as well as through the application of specific statutes such as the Crimes Act or criminal codes.

The terminology `intentional killing' has a clearly understood meaning with respect to the operation of the Crimes Act. What the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act did was to create this defence to what would otherwise, as I said, have been the application of the Crimes Act and potentially prosecution and conviction for murder or intentional killing. The defence was that available under the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, the defence of euthanasia.

What has happened is that the bill that is before the Senate and has been voted on and supported removes the operation of that defence. It removes the existence of an exemption to the criminal law that was created in the first place by the Northern Territory. So the end result—excuse the pun, but there have been a few of those here tonight—is that you go back to the application of the Northern Territory criminal law. That is a position that is consistent with what will exist in the rest of the country. On that basis, we can sit here all night and Senator Brown and Senator McKiernan can stand up and ask questions of senators about what is the meaning of `intentional killing'. If you want to do that, you may as well go ahead and debate what is the meaning of `intentional killing' pursuant to the Crimes Act. And that is clear—crystal clear.

I make this further point: at the end of the day the issue arises—and can arise—only if somebody is prosecuted pursuant to the Crimes Act, the criminal code of the Northern Territory, and they raise the defence of euthanasia, which would no longer be available to them because that act would be overridden. However, the criminal law will still continue to operate and whether or not they would ever be convicted would depend on all of the issues that would be raised in any criminal prosecution for murder, manslaughter or whatever; that is, it would depend upon the facts of the case, upon the intention of the person who committed the act and upon all of the other issues. I have tried to at least clarify that issue, and I do not think the question needs to be asked again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a bit of a concern here as well and it arises from the fact that we do have uncertainty in the legislation. Also, we do not have any clarification by the sponsor of the bill as to where that uncertainty should go. I think Senator McKiernan touched upon a very critical point when he referred to the Acts Interpretation Act. That point essentially was that, where you do not have clarity and you do have uncertainty and vagueness in legislation, then under the law of this country the courts look to second reading speeches, to the words of the sponsor, I suppose, of the legislation—the minister in most cases, and of course to the private member, who has initiated the legislation—to get some clarification of what is intended. They look to the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: But how often in the committee stage do we ask ministers to clarify what particular words in legislation mean? How often do we go away satisfied with the undertakings that ministers give us as to what the government's interpretation of such words amount to? It happens every day here. That is the practice of the place.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately in this case we do not have Senator Herron telling us what his view of the legislation is and what is the sponsor's view of the words in doubt. That is an important gap and one we should focus on for a little while. Senator Forshaw made mention of the fact that under criminal law there is uncertainty with respect to some of these words anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I did not say that. If you are going to quote me, quote me correctly, Nick.
—I will clarify it. Senator Forshaw made the point, I think—and if I have got it wrong, he can clarify it—that in the normal criminal law there is debate as to the meaning of some of the terms used.
—I did not say that.

—If you did not, then that was a point that was made earlier in the debate; I am sorry I have attributed it to you. That is a starting point that I think was put to the committee and it is canvassed in the committee's report. What is also clear here is that the wording of the legislation before us is loaded with uncertainty. The advice of officials of the Attorney-General's Department confirms and compounds that uncertainty.
—That is not true.

—If you go to Mr Dabb's advice, you see that during questioning by Senator Coonan and others there was debate as to whether we should use the term `purpose', or `sole purpose' or `main purpose'. Father Frank Brennan also had suggestions in terms of how we could clarify this particular legislation. I do not need to go over all those arguments again at this particular stage. I think it is sufficient to say that there is dispute about the precise meaning of the legislation. Given that, as Senator Abetz has said, there is a broad view or there is a narrow view, it is important for us in this place to try to come to some assessment.
—Why is it?
—`Why,' he asks. Because the direct impact of the broader view leads to unintended consequences.
—If you're in doubt, vote against it.

—They are documented. I can go through the report, if you like. They are documented in the report. The direct impact of the broad view is that there are some indirect, unintended consequences. That is set out here. The committee says, `The Attorney-General's Department did not consider the meaning was clear.' I do not need to go on and on in terms of this, but it is listed here—
—I think he is speaking as a shadow minister.

—No, I am speaking as someone who has had some interest in this. So you have uncertainty and you have unintended consequences. What you have not got here is what you normally have in these sorts of circumstances. You would normally have a minister or a sponsor who was prepared to go on the record to give some clarification.

BREAK.PARA: You do not have it here for two reasons. You do not have it here because Senator Herron has basically tossed this bill into the parliament and has gone walkabout. We have not seen him with respect to this debate. You also do not have it here because the only other advice you can look to is the advice from the Attorney‐General's Department. Although Senator Abetz says that it is a balance and so on, that advice consistently makes it clear that it is not clear. So we are bereft here of the normal aids to interpretation that would be available to the parliament.

My concern is that Senator Herron—not being inclined to contribute to this debate, to help clarify it and to adduce further legal advice that may give clearer meaning to the words in the legislation—has left that uncertainty to ride into the courts. I do not think that it is wise for us in an issue such as this—and I have taken it seriously—to leave such a big question mark hanging over the impact of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you're in doubt, vote against it.
—I will, Senator Alston.
—This makes not a skerrick of difference.

—Everyone has argued on the basis of tolerance in this debate, Senator Alston, and we have been having discussions across the table, in committee and so on. Debate in this parliament is about trying to get your point across and trying to get others to maybe look at it and to understand it in the interest of better legislation at the end of the day. If you think it is just good enough to come in here and say, `This is what I think; I will put my hand up and walk away,' good for you. But this debate has been going on in these issues for quite some time and these issues are not, as yet, resolved.

BREAK.PARA: It is the eleventh hour with respect to this legislation, and we have not had from the sponsor of this legislation any clarification of very critical issues—issues that will be decided by the court and issues which, I must say, have some pretty direct consequences in the passing of this legislation. Senator Herron, I ask you to reconsider your position. I ask you to try to answer the questions raised by Senator Brown and Senator McKiernan and, in doing so, try to give some certainty in an area which is uncertain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bolkus fails to go the whole way with Mr Dabb's evidence before the committee. Mr Dabb alluded to some uncertainty, but then he went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: There are many areas in legislation where fairly vague and imprecise expressions are used and the courts are left to apply them in a sensible way.
He later commented:

. . . there may be advantage in trying to make the language more precise—that might improve it—but it would be an exercise of some difficulty and you would need to be precise about the result you wanted to achieve and confident that you were improving the language. If the answer is that the proposer of the bill or the draftsperson does not really think they can do much better than this, then maybe they stop at a point where there is a certain amount of uncertainty, and it is a matter for people who consider the bill whether they are prepared to pass the bill on that basis.

The common law has, over a period of years, distilled the question of what is unlawful killing and what might constitute intentional killing. The majority of the committee, at the conclusion of this report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, preferred the view as expressed by Mr Santamaria QC and Mr Hughes QC that the phrase `intentional killing' was of the narrow meaning.

I put it to the Senate that that is what is intended here. I put it to the Senate that a court would have great difficulty getting much assistance from this committee stage in that it is a conscience vote and in that Senator Herron is not the original mover of this bill—it is a private member's bill. Normally when a court looks at legislation and what is intended, it goes to the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech. In this case, the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum are relying on established principles of law—principles of law that were described by gentlemen such as Messrs Hughes and Santamaria.

It just depends on whether or not you disagree with that, but I put it to you that the fact is that the proponents of this bill are accepting the advice of Messrs Santamaria and Hughes that the narrow meaning is intended and that the narrow meaning does apply. For the record, I reject the legal evidence as to the broader interpretation of `intentional killing'. I think that answers your question. If you persist in inquiring any further, then I would say to you that you can only go back to the committee report and read it. There is nothing I can say other than that: the narrow meaning is that which applies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison for explaining, in his usual clear and cogent way, something which we wanted to know. I asked the simple question: why couldn't the person who actually has the carriage of this legislation in the Senate be someone who is actually capable of defending the legislation and explaining it?
—I am happy to—if you give me a chance.

—I want to put a simple question to you, Minister. I do thank Senator Ellison for his answer. I have only risen to my feet because of my anger at Senator Alston's intervention and his constant interjections across the chamber to Senator Bolkus, `If you don't like it, vote against it.'
—That is precisely what Senator Ellison just said.
—No, he did not, with great respect, Minister. Senator Ellison actually gave a very cogent explanation of the difference between broad and narrow.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, I understand the utter contempt of senators from other states about the fact that this is not simply a bill—
—Don't change the subject, Bob.

—With respect to the non-stop interventions of Senator Alston across the chamber, I point out to him that this is the committee stage of the bill. I have been here for only 10 years. Others may know Senate practices that I am not aware of, but I always thought the committee stage of a bill was where senators could ask questions about the bill. I am dreadfully sorry if that is not the case, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of not getting to the point, I am getting precisely to the point. I was about to point out to you, Senator Alston from Victoria, and various other senators from Tasmania—a state that I point out again here tonight has slightly more than double the population of the Northern Territory but five times its representation in the House of Representatives and six times its representation here because of its good fortune to be a founding state; they still have not made half a million in Tasmania yet—before you intervened, that this is not simply a bill on the issue of euthanasia, although that of course is a vitally important part of it. It is also a bill which, for the first time since self-government in the Northern Territory, amends the constitution of the Northern Territory, takes away a power from the Northern Territory which was given to the Northern Territory on self-government—and I hope you do not want me to quote again your conservative colleague the then minister for the territories, who intro duced our constitution—our constitution, Senator Alston; the territory's constitution—into the House of Representatives, when he said that it was not only the right but the obligation of territorians to govern for themselves.

The Supreme Court of the Northern Territory—I think lawyers would agree it is a court that is held in as good a standing in terms of its legal expertise as any other court in Australia—has already ruled that the heads of power under which that law was made are in fact legal. So you will forgive me, Senator Alston, in terms of your Victorian frustration, in having some interest in hearing put down—and I thank Senator Ellison, your colleague, again for it—in this chamber an important matter for me as a territorian and others. I thank him for saying categorically that his view is that it is the narrow interpretation and not the broad interpretation. I want some assurance in here that it will not be interpreted so as to affect the so-called right to die laws of the Northern Territory. Thank you, Senator Harradine, for your assent to the fact that this is a legitimate question to pursue in here. Thank you, Senator Ellison, for saying that in your view it is not.

The simple, common question I want to put to the minister who has the carriage of this bill, and it is not a legal question, is this: as the person who has got the carriage of this bill, rightly or wrongly, through this Senate, will you go on the public record and say—on behalf of those votes that you lead here in this debate, and you do; they clearly constitute a majority here tonight—that it is not the intent of the bill, that it is not the intention of the supporters of this legislation in the Senate, for `intentional killing' to be interpreted in the broadest interpretation? Will you say that it is not the intention of the bill to interfere with the right to die laws? That is, as you know, Minister, the right of territorians to simply ask for extraordinary measures to be removed in order to sustain life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on a point of order: is Senator Collins seriously suggesting that Senator Herron is empowered to speak on behalf of all those who support the legislation?
—That is not a point of order.
—It certainly is. You were just suggesting that he is able to say what my intention is in voting for the bill. Is that seriously what you are saying?

—On the point of order. It is a nonsense point of order, but to clarify it: no. I am not suggesting that, Senator Alston. But Senator Ellison has been kind enough to give that clarification, as a supporter of the bill. I thought it may be of some interest to a court at some future time. Senator Alston, again with the greatest respect, it is of great interest to me as a territorian whose constitution is being amended here tonight, after 18 years of self-government, by arrogant senators from other states who place not the slightest value on the territory parliament. We have heard Senator Abetz's views expressed before about the territory parliament and where it stands in the firmament of parliaments around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps, Senator Alston, if you would stop interjecting you would actually conclude the debate a little bit earlier tonight. I am saying that it is helpful for me as a territorian to have a member of the government's frontbench reply. Can't you see the distinction, Senator—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you are withdrawing that now.

—I am withdrawing nothing, Senator Alston. And the sooner you stop interjecting, the sooner I will sit down and the sooner this debate will be concluded. If you want to debate it all night, I am quite happy to, Senator Alston. I am sure that a combination of Senator Schacht, Senator Bolkus and me could, just the three of us, keep going all night, if that is the result you want.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be helpful and reassuring to territorians—I know that Senator Tambling would agree with this—to have a member of the government's frontbench, and I suggest that the appropriate person is the minister with the carriage of the bill, say clearly on the record, along with his colleagues, that this is not the intention, so far as he is concerned, as the minister responsible for the bill in the Senate and as a member of the frontbench. Why is it such a contentious matter, Senator Alston? Senator Ellison has just done it clearly. Why can't Senator Herron?

TALK.START.PARA: —You want him to do it on behalf of everyone else. He can't do that.

—I will stay here all night, Senator Alston, if you want to. I will debate this until the sun rises. I will debate it right through until we stop the third reading, if you wish. I am quite happy to. Senator Herron, will you please tell the Senate, despite the constant interjections of Senator Alston, whether it is your view that this `intentional killing' phrase in the bill should be interpreted so broadly as to affect the right to die legislation in the Northern Territory?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Bob Collins, welcome the contribution Senator Ellison made to the committee stage debate. He helped the process along. There is still a little way to go. I do not know to whom it is proper to address the question I asked earlier. I have not experienced a debate such as this in the period of time I have been in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I have addressed a question relating to when a court is looking at the meaning of a particular piece of legislation and uses the Acts Interpretation Act to develop a meaning from that. It is usual, as Senator Ellison said, to go back to the explanatory memorandum, to go back to the second reading speech. The question I ask is: do they go back to the minister's second reading speech?

I do not profess to be an expert; I am asking a genuine question for myself, but there are a number of others who are concerned with this. This is a matter that was raised during the committee deliberation, and everybody agrees with that. We have not had satisfactory answers to it yet. Does the Acts Interpretation Act refer to the minister's second reading speech? It is my understanding that it does. I think section 15 is the relevant section. I do not pretend to be an expert in all these things. My colleagues here recognise that immediately.

BREAK.PARA: The other matter is that we are in new proceedings, as far as I am aware, certainly in my time in the parliament. We are dealing with a private member's bill. As Senator Alston through his interjections is saying, there is no carriage for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a government bill.

—I know it is not a government bill. We all know it is not a government bill. We thank Senator Campbell for that very timely intervention. Senator Collins a moment ago made the point to Senator Alston that if he had kept quiet the debate might have moved along a little bit quicker. I make the same point to you. Keep quiet and we might get it moving a little bit quicker than it is at the moment.

BREAK.PARA: I believe there are some very genuine questions being put to the committee. Senator Harradine, from his position, from his involvement in the committee stage of this bill, has given what he understands is his interpretation of it. Senator Ellison as a private senator in this place, also from the state of Western Australia, has given his interpretation on it. Senator Forshaw, my good colleague from New South Wales, has given an interpretation. We have in the chamber tonight a senator who is the sponsor of this bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —He's said nothing.
—He doesn't have to.
—I am happy to, when you have finished.
—Where is the precedent dealing with a private member's bill? Is it the sponsor's words that the courts will refer back to?
—Mr Dabb tells us on pages 202 and 203 what the courts will do.
—Fine.
—Have a look at it.
—Order! Senator McKiernan has the call.
—I think Senator McKiernan is sitting down to allow me to try to explain to him—
—But you have not had the call.
—I haven't. May I have the call, please?
—You may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. In relation to the Acts Interpretation Act, what its wording is or is not, I am not sure. But if it does only refer to ministers' second reading speeches as opposed to just second reading speeches—Senator McKiernan tells me that it does—we do not have, if you like, a minister's second reading speech, because Mr Andrews delivered the official second reading speech in the other place. Therefore, the court will not be assisted in any shape or form by what the Acts Interpretation Act says.

SPEECH.PARA: We therefore move on. In fact, it was in response to a question that I posed to Mr Dabb. On pages 202 and 203 of the Hansard, Mr Dabb said—I understand that Senator Harradine has already read this out this evening, but I will repeat it:
I think a court would probably approach this by saying, `I have to get at the intention of the Commonwealth parliament in saying this. What really was the intention of the Commonwealth parliament?'

TALK.START.PARA: —That's where we started!
—Right.
—Correct.
—Yes. Mr Dabb continued:

SPEECH.PARA: If every speaker who had spoken in support of the bill said, `Our clear understanding and purpose is that intentional killing has a narrow meaning so it only catches an act for the purpose of killing,' then I think that is likely to be a decisive consideration on how a court interpreted it.

I want to simply throw this challenge to those who oppose the Andrews bill. Are you really suggesting that the Andrews bill ought be interpreted with a broader interpretation? Of course you are not. Not a single person—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are saying the reverse.
—Exactly, Senator Collins. Not a single person in this debate in either house has asserted that good public policy would be served by the broad interpretation—not a single speaker.
—Correct. That is why it is helpful to have this brought about.

—That is right. Any court revisiting this debate would say, `What was the intention of the Commonwealth parliament?' That is absolutely clear. I am sure that Senator Brown would not argue for the broader view. I am sure Senator McKiernan and Senator Collins would not.
—That's correct.

—Right. I hope that interjection is in the Hansard , Senator Collins. That will mean that when the court comes to interpret this, there is one more senator on the public record supporting the narrow view. I cannot see what the debate is about. There is not a single person in this place—
—It is about getting that on the record, Senator.
—All you have to do is all of you get up and say within five seconds, `I support the narrow interpretation.' Why don't you all do it and be done with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Chairman, and thank you for your cooperation in allowing Senator Abetz to speak. That was my contribution to the flow of the debate. I had hoped that he would have been a bit more constructive than he was but I did pick up an interjection, just before Senator Abetz got to his feet, that Senator Herron is going to actually say something on this. Was I correct in—
—I was waiting for everybody to finish; that's what you do in a committee.

—No, no. With all due respect, Senator Herron, you were given the opportunity on a number of occasions and you sat stock‐still in your seat. The previous chairman, Senator Watson, in actual fact—you can check the record—had called the question before the chairman. You not on one occasion—
—Because he gave the answer and you didn't like it.

—Do you want to keep interjecting, Senator Campbell? You can do it if you want. You can keep interjecting if you want, but I will not be shouted down—and most certainly will not be shouted down by you. It is on your head if you keep doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, the question was put, and it was put for genuine reasons. You have had, previously, an opportunity to answer the question. I understand you are willing to now. I am most certainly willing to sit down and listen to your answer, and if your answer satisfies me, I shall not jump on this issue again. However, if your answer does not satisfy me, I shall exercise my right to jump and ask the question again. I have to. I have obligations to do it on behalf of my constituents and I have obligations on behalf of those people who appeared before the committee who expressed their concerns on this issue to get it teased out, to bring clarity to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly—I would do this in other circumstances under standing order 191, but I do not need to in the committee stage—as a point of explanation on something that I think was misunderstood by Senator Collins. It may not have been. I do not know. But what I said about this matter is on all fours with what Senator Ellison—
—I agree with that, Senator Harradine, and I thank you for it.
—I see. I refer to page 117 to 120 of the report. Thank you.

—I also want to raise the issue of the situation that the ACT, the Australian Capital Territory, finds itself in. With respect to my colleague Senator Collins's comments, like the Northern Territory's Natural Death Act 1988, the ACT's Medical Treatment Act 1994, permitting doctors to withdraw treatment in some circumstances, is affected by the ambiguity of this particular interpretation. On behalf of the ACT, in relation to the laws that are currently in existence in the ACT, I would like to say to the minister with the carriage of this bill that it is necessary for this to be clarified at this point in time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth once again looking at this fundamental issue. I know that Senator Ellison has tried to answer it, but the committee, I think, made it clear in 4.7 of its report. It is worth stating on the record in this committee stage:

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the issue was whether "intentional killing" includes cases where a doctor takes action with the best of intentions (to avoid futile treatment or to optimise pain relief) but knows that the action will cause (or accelerate) the death of the patient.
We are specifically looking at the application of this legislation on the Northern Territory's Natural Death Act 1988 and the ACT's Medical Treatment Act of 1988—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 1988 in this report—both of which permit doctors to withdraw treatment in some circumstances even though the doctor knows that death will result. The report goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the Medical Treatment Act creates a right for patients to receive relief from pain and suffering to the maximum extent reasonable under the circumstances. This may include cases where the drugs given for pain relief may also hasten death.
That is the nub of the issue that we are concerned about. We are concerned about what the ACT government said when it gave evidence to the committee. It said:

We believe that the legislation is sufficiently ambiguous as to create uncertainty about the operation of our Medical Treatment Act in the ACT. That is an act designed to reinforce the protocols of the palliative care practices in the territory. Doctors and nurses involved in this area would undoubtedly be uncertain about the application of the law as a result of this legislation and would be, I think, much more likely to be involved in litigation of some sort as a result of the passing of this federal act.

So you have got the ACT government saying very clearly that it is concerned about the impact of the broader definition on their Medical Treatment Act. The Northern Terri tory government's submission had four Queen's Counsel confirming the same sort of concern. Its submission noted that expert views differed in respect of the provisions of the territory's Natural Death Act, but it had four QCs also expressing concern about the broader definition of `intentional killing' in the bill.

We are told to look at the advice of the Attorney‐General's Department. It is important to do that and it is quite illustrative to do that. For instance, there is uncertainty as to which criminal law would apply even if criminal law were to apply in interpreting the word `intentional' in this Andrews' bill. The Attorney‐General's Department noted that the bill is a part of constitutive law not criminal statute so there is no presumption that `intentional' should be interpreted narrowly. That is the first point.

The department distinguishes the Andrews' law because it is more constitutional law than criminal law. Its view is that there is no presumption that `intentional' should be interpreted narrowly. That is when the warning bells should start to ring. The committee goes on to say that the next question is, even if you were to look at criminal law, which jurisdiction's law of homicide would apply? Mr Dabb says once again:
I think the only fair answer is that it is uncertain.
So uncertainty compounding uncertainty. He goes on to say:

But I would think the mere fact that the law of homicide varies considerably as between the jurisdictions concerned is a reasonably strong argument against saying that you simply go to what it means in the law of homicide.

So he says go back to the constitutive law, and basically makes it clear that, under constitutive law, you are looking at a broad interpretation of `intentional'. If you have got that broad interpretation of `intentional', that is where the Northern Territory's legislation and the ACT's legislation have got problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm glad you're not the Attorney-General.

—I am sorry, Senator Harradine. That is a comment that does not normally come from you. What I am doing here is reciting the advice of the Attorney‐ General's Department. It is on the record here in the context of the committee expressing concern—
—The top of page 119.

—I will go through one part and I am sure you can come up with others, but you cannot dispute the fact that on the public record there is concern by not just the Commonwealth Attorney‐General's Department but also the ACT Attorney-General's Department and the Northern Territory government with its bevy of QCs as to the direct impact of the word `intentional'. That has got to be of concern here. You just cannot skate over it.

SPEECH.PARA: The first bit of advice is that you have to look at constitutive law. The second bit is, even if you were to look at the law of homicide, you are not sure as to which jurisdiction you go to. It is extremely important that we clarify this as to the impact of this legislation on the ACT and the Northern Territory legislation. There is some concern there. It is worth even putting this on the record, Senator Harradine, since you raised it. The report says at 4.19:

The question of possible differences between the law on "intentional killing" in the different jurisdictions largely reflects the fact that the law in all Australian jurisdictions is uncertain in the context of end-of-life medical decision-making. Mr Dabb of the Attorney‐General's Department told the Committee: "in our view there is already a large amount of uncertainty in the law in this area, because cases simply are not brought".
So I think there is a real concern here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quote him from the top of page 119. Quote that.

—Why don't you look at all of it. If you were to look at all of it, Senator Harradine, you would find that there is a real cause for concern here as to the uncertainty of this legislation—not just the actual interpretation of the words but even what area of law they should be interpreted under.

SPEECH.PARA: I could go on here, but I think I will leave it at this particular stage. There is a concern and the concern is further expressed in 4.23 of the report, which states that the Attorney‐General's Department also raised further concerns as to what factors are taken into account if one were to look at the intention of the person who is in charge of the process. As I said earlier on, there was discussion about whether it should be sole purpose, main purpose or whatever.

We really have a responsibility here to ensure that the words are right. If you were to look at the concerns expressed in the report, the advice of three Attorney-General's departments, you have to say that there is a real concern about the uncertainty in this legislation. It will not be good enough some months down the track when some poor doctor or nurse may be stung by the indirect consequences of this legislation to say, `Senator Herron did not give us any clarification. Okay, we had the advice of the AG's Department and that basically led us to believe it was uncertain, but we closed our eyes to all these concerns and moved on in our haste to get the legislation through.' That will not be a good enough defence for any innocent nurse or doctor who is caught by this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to say something about this. The question is whether or not this is as clear as it could be. The very presence of courts in the land and the presence of the legal profession, which so beautifully serves those courts, show that, clearly when laws are made, there is apt to be discussions about them. There are a couple of points I want to make. Senator Alston was taken to task, but the point he made that it is for the courts to interpret the laws is absolutely correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposition I want to put is that the concept of intent is a concept that is very familiar to the courts, whether it is an intention to kill, an intention to steal or an intention to do grievous bodily harm. That concept of intent is very familiar to the courts. The language that is used, whether or not it will be subject to interpretation later, is language that the courts are familiar with. Therefore, it is probably the best language that can be used.

As to whether or not a narrow or a broad meaning ought to be taken in so far as the criminal law is concerned—and I have heard the argument that Senator Bolkus has put about this also being a constitutional issue—it is a well worn phrase that the narrow interpretation must be taken where a criminal offence is involved.
