If a criminal offence is going to arise under this bill, in respect of that criminal offence it is the narrow meaning that must be taken.

I think we are getting ourselves a bit disturbed here. The terms of this legislation are terms that the courts will be familiar with. I cannot see their having any occasion to go to a second reading speech. If they do, there is no speech that they can really go to because all that people will be doing is expressing their own private opinions. The point of reading a minister's second reading speech is to see what the government that sponsored the legislation thought about it; what cabinet wanted to do. That is why you would go to the second reading speech. It is not so much the minister's second reading speech but the thinking of the government of the day whose legislation it is about which you want to find out.

People have threatened to debate this bill all night. So be it. We can debate it all night but in the end, with great respect to you, Senator Herron, whatever you say, whatever Senator Brownhill says, whatever Senator Campbell says—and no doubt he would prefer to be watching the cricket—it will be absolutely irrelevant to the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —South Africa won the cricket.
—On that announcement, Senator Brownhill, I will take my seat.

—I want to make a couple of comments. I took a point of order earlier which I accept was taken at the wrong time. I think my colleague Senator Bolkus misinterpreted what I said in respect of the meaning of intentional killing so far as it existed as an offence under criminal law. It is pretty well settled as to what that means and how the Crimes Act is interpreted. As to whether or not an offence is committed, that is another matter altogether. That is a matter for a court to decide having regard to the facts and the operation of the law.

BREAK.PARA: I want to comment on the arguments put about whether or not the Euthanasia Laws Bill would override or place at risk the operation of other legislation in territories, such as the Natural Death Act. I do not think it would. I have read the report, and I have read the evidence before the committee on this issue. I appreciate that people have suggested that there could be some questions about this issue. I believe that there is no real question about that when the legislation is considered properly and interpreted properly—that is, that intentional killing does have the narrow meaning as would be understood under the law.

Secondly, the specific purpose and the only purpose of the so‐called Andrews bill is to enact legislation which overrides the operation of the Northern Territory legislation and thereby returns the situation to what was the position prior to the enactment of the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. If you want any further support for that, you would go to the legislation: that is, the Euthanasia Laws Bill. You would look at clause 50A(2) of the bill, which states:
The Legislative Assembly does have power to make laws with respect to:
(a) the withdrawal or withholding of medical or surgical measures for prolonging the life of a patient but not so as to permit the intentional killing of the patient; and
(b) medical treatment in the provision of palliative care to a dying patient, but not so as to permit the intentional killing of the patient; and
(c) the appointment of an agent by a patient who is authorised to make decisions about the withdrawal or withholding of treatment; and
(d) the repealing of legal sanctions against attempted suicide.

The fact that those provisions are in the bill is a very clear signal as to the intention of this bill. The intention of this bill is not to interfere in any way with the right of the territory to pass laws such as the Natural Death Act, which, for instance, would legitimise an action which involved the withdrawal or withholding of medical treatment.

It is a simple matter of statutory interpretation in accordance with the normal rules of statutory interpretation. I believe that some questions being raised here tonight and some arguments being advanced are nice esoteric debating points—

TALK.START.PARA: —A little less than esoteric, with respect, when you come from where I come from.
—I appreciate that, Senator Collins.
—It doesn't affect your state.

—I do not actually agree with that interpretation. I believe that the debate on this issue affects every state in the country. As I argued in my speech at the second reading stage, the support brought forward by many people for the Northern Territory legislation related to what they claimed was a fundamental individual right that all humans had: a right to end their own life or to have assistance to do that. In the broader context, I think the issue goes beyond the Northern Territory, but I do concede that we are only dealing with the Northern Territory legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The legislation does make it clear that it is not intended to override any of those specific laws, such as the Natural Death Act. I make this final point: if there is a challenge to this legislation, the court will decide that issue, just as it has decided on many occasions cases where challenges have been made by states, individuals or corporations to the operation of Commonwealth law as it interacts with state or territory law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —To expedite things, I would like to make my comments now so that if, or when, Senator Herron rises to make some response to the points made, he might also take up the point that I want to make. Although it is slightly aside from the one that is being debated here, it is something I want to hear his comment on.

SPEECH.PARA: The three words that really have been associated with this bill have been intention, intent and tolerance. I certainly have appreciated the tolerance with which senators have been able to put their point of view in this place and accept a wide range of debating points or arguments as people arrived at their conclusions.

One of the points that I particularly wanted to pick up on is the one that Senator Herron made in his opening speech, which was understood by a lot of people to be the carriage of the bill in this place. I deliberated about whether or not to say this, and now I have decided that I will. Senator Herron, you made reference to doctors who would be participating in these kinds of practices as being related very closely to doctors who practised the same sorts of things in Nazi Germany.

For the record, I want to say that I personally, and on behalf of thousands of citizens, take considerable offence at any kind of reference that anybody deliberating in this place on how best to deal with this matter should in any way be associated with the practices of doctors, let alone anybody else in Nazi Germany. It is a most surprising comment from you, Senator Herron. You are not known to me as a person of that kind of intolerance or smear comment. I would like you to have the opportunity to apologise or make clear what you intended.

I do believe that the matters here are matters of greatest importance. They are matters of fine line and hair‐splitting interpretation. If you have ever—and I suspect you might have, as I have—had to watch as you accept the decision to turn off the blood transfusion, which has no effect other than killing a person or bringing to an end the life of that person, how can you be clear that that is an accepted, justifiable and legal thing to do, as was part of what the Northern Territory was allowing to happen in its territory under its legislation? That is a very fine line. A lot of it has gone to the intent and what might happen if that intent ran amuck.

I think it has been a very useful discussion in the committee stage of this bill to get clear what is meant by another use of intent, as in intentional killing. Intent has a variety of meanings in this debate. I hope that the intent of all of us in this debate is taken to be an intention of goodwill and serious deliberations on matters of great importance and that we are accepted in our different points of view with considerable tolerance, though some of us are finding it a little harder rather than easier this evening because none of us are other than passionate about this matter.

I would hope that that tolerance also extends outside this parliament to everybody in the community. But I would have to say, as I said in my speech on the second reading, that the community is way ahead of its parliamentarians in matters of law. I think they are also largely way ahead of us in matters of tolerance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contribution to the debate. I have listened with considerable interest to the various concerns that were raised and deliberately did not stand at any earlier stage, despite an attempt at provocation.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the point of Senator Crowley first of all. I do accept the good intent of everybody who has spoken or voted on this bill. It was a matter of conscience. I stand not as a minister but as a person with carriage of the bill, very willingly. I was very proud to have the carriage of this bill in the Senate. I do not resile from that. But I should explain to Senator Crowley that my reference to the very specific matter that she referred to was made because people can believe that they have higher motives in pursuing something that is to the detriment of the population as a whole. That was the sole reason for drawing attention to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still offended, Senator, because the implication is that it applies to us.

—That was the point that I was making. In relation to the other debate about intention, that was canvassed very fully before the committee. I refer you to pages 112 and 113 of the report under the heading `Legal issues—uncertainty', where this was fully explored. I refer you particularly to the opinion of Mr Tom Hughes QC, and Mr Joseph Santamaria QC, on page 113, paragraph 9.12. I ask Senator Collins, for example: does the criminal code of the Northern Territory define the words `intention' or `intent'?
—I'd answer that I want to vote on this, Senator Herron.
—The answer is no, it does not. I should ask Senator Lundy: does the Crimes Act 1900 of the Australian Capital Territory define the words `intent' or `intention'? It does not.

BREAK.PARA: I want to get to the substantive answer to the questions that have been raised. This bill restates two clear principles about the treatment of the dying and the disabled in our society. First, the bill states:

The Assembly has no power to make laws permitting or having the effect of permitting . . . the form of intentional killing of another called euthanasia (which includes mercy killing) or the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life.
Secondly, the bill confirms:
The Assembly does have power to make laws with respect to:
(a) the withdrawal or withholding of medical or surgical measures for prolonging the life of a patient . . . and
(b) medical treatment in the provision of palliative care to a dying patient, but not so as to permit the intentional killing of the patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to end the committee stage of this bill without defining `intentional killing'. It is not defined in the jurisdictions of either the ACT or the Northern Territory, as Senator Herron has just said. It ought to be defined in this legislation because it specifically applies to those jurisdictions.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day, there are as many definitions as there are senators. At least one senator who voted for this legislation has said that, to him, the other definitions do not apply. There is no way that anybody reading the proceedings of this committee can determine what was thought by the majority or minority. References to officer Dabb of the Attorney-General's Department are just that; they are selective from both sides of the committee. He even referred to extremely broad meanings of the term `intentional killing'. There is no limit to the breadth or narrowness of this definition.

Appearing before the committee were other eminent legal people who gave different definitions and expressed other concerns. In any case, the proceedings of the committee are not of themselves a definition under this law, nor are they binding on this Senate committee. So there is no direction as to what such terms as `mercy killing', `intentional killing' and `euthanasia' mean under this legislation.

It is incumbent upon those who draw up such legislation to make such matters clear. But from the debate we have heard in this committee there can be no clarification, there is no definition. There is no way that a court, from the proceedings of this committee, can determine what was meant by the committee, by the Senate, in terms of definition of those words. The problem here comes at the outset from those who drafted the law and brought it before this parliament.

Senator Herron's responsibilities are no more or less than those of a minister at the table, hosting this legislation. The standing orders of the Senate do not define that there should be a minister there at any time; they simply talk about the committee as a whole looking at the question that has been put to it.

There has been a complete failure on the matter of these critical definitions. It does leave the law under great question in the jurisdictions of both the ACT and the Northern Territory and there is no way, from the debate we have heard tonight, of fixing that.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "now", substitute "this day six months".

I recognise that the die is cast, but I feel so strongly about the measure that I make a final appeal to senators that we should relent for these six months for the sake of those people who are going to be so greatly affected by what we are doing here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be voting in support of Senator Brown's amendment for the simple reason that I will be voting against the third reading itself, and I do not see the point.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some interest during the committee stage to the debate on the Acts Interpretation Act and what regard judges could pay to the debate in terms of any concern they had afterwards about the meaning of the bill. My recollection of that act—I could be wrong, because I am not a lawyer—is that it does not simply apply to the mover of the bill, a minister as it normally is: the courts can have regard to the whole debate. I am pleased indeed that it is not simply the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, in concluding the debate on this bill, I want to remind all honourable senators of the words with which this debate was started by the mover of the bill. I want to ask honourable senators who disagree with me to at least understand the position of people like me from the Northern Territory who do not support euthanasia. The reason I make that statement is—I recall this for honourable senators, because it may not have had this impact on you as you do not come from the Northern Territory—that these were almost the very opening words in the first paragraph or two that were uttered in the House of Representatives by Kevin Andrews in moving the bill. Mr Andrews said, `Territorians have no rights, only obligations.'

I have to tell you that, as I actually served 10 years of my political career in the Northern Territory's parliament, it has been a matter of great anger for me to listen, not the views of people who disagree with me on euthanasia—because I do understand the arguments on all sides—but to the vilification that I have heard from many members and senators about the Northern Territory and its parliament.

I referred to Senator Abetz earlier—and I do not need to look it up in Hansard; it is all burnt on my brain. He said, `The Northern Territory parliament exists only by the grace and favour of the Commonwealth parliament. What the Commonwealth parliament gives, it can also take away.' This is from a senator from a state with about twice the population of the Northern Territory's, and five times its representation in the House of Representatives and six times its representation here in the Senate. When is that important? On conscience votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly right.

—Yes. He is a senator, of course, who violently objected to the federal parliament's vote in respect of privacy laws that struck down anti-homosexual laws in Tasmania. I have found states rights to be a very convenient argument.

SPEECH.PARA: As someone who served in that parliament for a decade, it is with some degree of anger that I have listened to those totally dismissive and contemptible comments, not about euthanasia but about the Territory's legislature. The reason is this: from my experience of a decade in the Territory's parliament, and from my experience of 10 years in this parliament, and from my considerable experience with the members of parliaments from other states around Australia, the facts are that the Territory parliament has no more dills, idiots or cowboys proportionally than any other parliament in Australia. It has just as many members of parliament who actually concern themselves about legislation.

The difference is—and I concede it—its small size. It is much smaller than any other parliament. Therefore, I guess to that extent it is concentrated. But the reason I make that point is this: I have heard again and again in here—Senator Calvert from Tasmania, you and your 11 colleagues in here—about the fact that, `Isn't it shocking that this vote was cast by a handful of votes in the Northern Territory?' That is a bit cute coming from a senator. There are 76 senators in here. We know that because of the balance of power on major issues affecting a lot of Australians—not me, I might add—as strongly as euthanasia, despite our 76 votes in here the Telstra issue was decided on two votes. One is Senator Harradine and the other is Senator Colston. Two votes determined that issue in here. Does that mean that that legislation has no validity and it should be struck down because it was passed by a handful of votes?

The Queensland parliament is currently having its legislation determined on a daily basis by one vote, as it happens, despite all of its numbers. Does that mean that that legisla tion, therefore, has no validity? I must say that these two votes are the main reason I rise tonight. But there are major issues like Telstra. Who can ever forget—I will never forget—in that debate the sight of the minister for Telstra leading Senator Colston by the elbow, physically, across the floor of this Senate chamber to make sure that he voted the right way when he had forgotten that he was on the wrong side?

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Bob. Wind it up.

—It is easy for you to say, `Wind it up.' It is not your constitution that is being amended here tonight. So you let me have my final say. If we cannot have the vote, if we cannot get the result, I will at least exercise the rights I have as a Territorian senator to stand up for the Northern Territory in this parliament. Do not deny me that.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just say—and this is the main reason I got up to speak tonight, because I know that a lot of people on the government side agreed with this—

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—If you want me to speak for the whole 15 minutes, keep interjecting. I do thank the people who have opposed this bill—the majority of whom, the lion's share of them, are members of the ALP, the Greens and the Democrats; in other words, non-government members—
—None of the Lyons Forum.

—None of the Lyons Forum, and a handful of government members as well. As the vote indicates, out of the 39 votes cast against this legislation in the House of Representatives, only 13 came from the government side. Who could be surprised at that? The edict was delivered right on day one by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of Australia. Again, how dare people continue to say this is a private member's bill. If it were a private member's bill, it would still be languishing at the bottom of the Notice Paper , not having the facilities of this entire federal parliament made available to it. That is because the Prime Minister, in fact, dictated that should be done.
—And the Leader of the Opposition—in both places.

—Oh, the Leader of the Opposition—I hate to point this out to you, Senator Campbell—does not have the numbers to organise that in the House of Representatives, or hadn't you noticed? It was in all the papers, Senator. You won the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to see the government get this bill to the Governor-General quickly. There is a problem—a real problem. The transitional legislation has not been carried. I am deeply sorry about that. I am deeply sorry that people who voted in favour of this bill could not bring themselves at least to vote for that—for the two people, in fact, who may now take a decision to end their lives prematurely.

What I would like, for everyone's sake, is for the government to expedite the passage of this legislation. Is it the case that it will have to go back to the House of Representatives because of the amendment that was passed at the second reading stage? I am advised by the clerk that it does not. I thank him for his confirmation of that fact. I hope, therefore, that they get it to the Governor-General tomorrow so that certainty will be placed in this debate—even though it is the wrong way as far as I am concerned. At least there will not be a period of weeks, which normally happens, until the next Executive Council meeting, where people may want to avail themselves of this Northern Territory law in some interregnum period. Frankly, I think that would be a tragedy for both sides of the debate.

I just want to conclude as I started. I take enormous offence, as a Territorian, about having this bill brought into this parliament. The person who sponsored this bill introduced it into the parliament with the words, `Territorians have no rights, only obligations.' I hope, in conclusion, that even those members who voted for the bill would not concur with those words of the mover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not the proponent of this legislation. I was not one of the driving forces of it. I did not particularly want to be involved in it. Certainly, at the beginning of it, I did not have any set views, unlike some people, surrounding the debate. I opposed the reference of the bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Nonetheless, it was referred and I participated—and I think I participated well—in the deliberations of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I learned a tremendous amount through the passage of the legislation, through the committee hearings and also through the various debates that occurred here, even though we were not present during all of the second reading speeches. It has been a fruitful experience. I do not believe it has been a rewarding experience. It is a very sad conclusion to a very intensive debate. But I do not think that this is the end of the matter.

This morning we are closing a chapter of the debate. We are closing a chapter of the debate because the legislation we are overruling by the passage of this legislation is a territory legislation. I have hopes, and, indeed, I am encouraged in certain quarters, that some of our states will enact legislation similar to, maybe even better than, what is now in existence in the Northern Territory to give individual human beings some control over their lives and their deaths. I am hopeful that some states will do it. When that happens, this chamber and the other place will just have to live with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very strong and powerful debate in this parliament. In the House of Representatives, the vote was 88 to 35. In this Senate, the margin is very close, and we have yet to see the vote on the third reading of the Euthanasia Laws Bill. I think I can safely predict that the issue that has been raised and addressed by this parliament will continue to be a moral issue for the future, especially when the states, as they almost certainly will and should, introduce their own legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation ought to have been properly debated, sponsored and conducted in the state parliaments of Australia. The fact that the Northern Territory parliament, also when it first addressed this legislation at the second reading stage, voted 13 votes to 12 and subsequently, at the third reading of that bill in the Northern Territory, voted 15 to 10 shows the very special consideration that this legislation was given by a group of very representative, democratically elected territorians.

With no disrespect to the special committee of this Senate, which I consider has done a very good job in the time constraints it worked under, the Northern Territory select committee was much more comprehensive both in time and in scope and in consultation with the affected communities. In that regard it was very special.

I appreciate the dilemma experienced by many of my colleagues in this chamber from the deep‐seated opposition on the moral and social implications of voluntary euthanasia. As I said at the outset, it is timely that that debate continue to be canvassed because over 70 per cent of Australians are very clearly clamouring for this type of legislation to be properly initiated and properly considered.

Like Senator Bob Collins, I share the concerns that territory rights for the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island have been trampled on by the process of this legislation, both in the House of Representatives and here. I acknowledge and thank the number of senators who have obviously shifted ground in the course of this debate to more properly reflect the views that are taken in the community. The fact that it was two to one—88 to 35—in the House of Representatives, and our vote earlier this evening on the second reading was 38 to 34, shows the extreme movement that took place.

The members of this place are no different on moral issues from our colleagues in the House of Representatives. There were manipulative forces that played a role in marginal seats in the House of Representatives, and far too many of our colleagues sycophantically played follow the leader. That is something that we need to look at very carefully in our considerations.

There has been a very strong and active campaign right throughout the community. This is an appropriate piece of legislation for proper consideration. As I have said, I believe that in the future the leadership will now fall on the states. Once it is in place in one of the states, and this Senate has no power to override that state, then it will again be a time for a territory, hopefully the Northern Territory, to get to that point.

I would challenge the Senate to look very carefully at the other issues that were at stake in this debate, particularly statehood and self-government for the Northern Territory. The Senate and the House of Representatives will need to restore the confidence of territorians that the rhetoric that has been offered by so many of our colleagues in the last decade is in fact properly reinforced and underpinned for self-government. Similarly, we will have to address very seriously in the near future the outcomes of the issues relating to Wik and native title, and, in the Northern Territory's case, perhaps amendments to the Aboriginal land rights legislation of the Northern Territory.

We do have exciting challenges in front of us with regard to these goals, whether they be native title, whether they be Commonwealth funding for the territories and, in the long term, securing territory by the turn of the century. I would hope that those results will be evident in this Senate in the very near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to add my comments with respect to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. They, too, are directly affected by the passage of this Euthanasia Laws Bill. At the moment, there are amendments before the assembly that were deferred until later this year to allow this debate to take place. That debate will now not occur in the ACT assembly as a result of the passage of this bill. So, like the Northern Territory, the passage of this bill will directly impinge upon our ability as territorians to make laws with regard to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The ambiguity of the definition of intentional killing has not yet been resolved. We have seen from the evidence put before us that that will be subject to legal challenge. The ACT government and representatives thereof have stated their intention to proceed with that.

I agree with Senator Tambling when he says that this is not where the debate ends; it just enters a different phase. The people of the ACT have clearly stated their intention as to which path they intend to proceed along, and their elected representatives in the assembly of the Australian Capital Territory will no doubt proceed with their own views on this matter. While this bill is on the books, it is impinging directly upon the rights of the people of the ACT and their elected representatives to pursue a legislative course that they deem fit and appropriate for the people that they represent.

Statehood is not the answer for the Australian Capital Territory; we cannot even look forward to that as a way of excluding ourselves from the imposition of the Andrews bill. The only solution for the people of the ACT is the removal—the repeal—of this bill.

I say to everyone who supported the Andrews bill: you have knowingly influenced and impacted upon the ability of the people of the ACT to make laws in this regard. The people of the ACT have quite clearly stated their intent in this matter. Regardless of what the outcome may have been in the ACT Assembly with respect to the proposed amendments to the Medical Treatment Act 1994, they will now not have the choice or the option of even debating them in the first instance.

In my view it is a very sad day for the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. I concur completely with the comments made by my colleague Senator Bob Collins when he said that this law is discriminatory against the people of the territories. On that basis it is an unacceptable position to have taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Pacific Teal's only previous Pacific voyage carrying toxic nuclear materials ended in near engine failure with all 4 cylinders cracked and the real threat of a maritime calamity.

(2) Why does the Government rest easy with the fact that the Pacific Teal's cargo does not have liability cover, even though a major accident would need a multi‐billion dollar salvage and clean up effort.
(3) What is the exact route to be taken by the Pacific Teal in the Southern and South Pacific Oceans; if the exact route is not known, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. Due to the nature of the question, information had to be sought from our missions in London and Paris, resulting in an unavoidable delay in providing the answer:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has been advised by British Nuclear Fuels Limited that during a voyage from Europe to Japan and back completed in 1990, there was a slight loss of coolant in one of the two engines of the Pacific Teal. The post‐voyage inspection identified hairline cracks in the cylinder blocks. These had not interrupted the completed voyage or affected the ship's safe performance. The damaged cylinder blocks of both engines were immediately replaced by new cylinder blocks of a different design.

(2) The high‐level radioactive waste being carried by the Pacific Teal is in a vitrified form, which has a low solubility in water. An environmental impact assessment performed at the request of the Science and Technology Agency in Japan prior to the 1995 high‐level waste shipment, which adopted the extreme scenario that a high‐level waste package sank, vitrified wastes were exposed to seawater and radionuclides leached into the sea, found that the dose equivalent of radiation exposure to the public would be much lower than the dose limit recommended by the International Commission on Radiolological Protection. The Government has been advised that in case of an emergency, the shippers have well‐developed emergency response arrangements and comprehensive salvage plans, including a team of experts on 24‐hour standby.

Nevertheless the Government does not "rest easy" over liability arrangements such as those covering the Pacific Teal. Australia has been participating actively in international negotiations since 1990 in the International Atomic Energy Agency Standing Committee on Nuclear Liability, for the establishment of a world‐wide liability regime to supplement and enhance the measures in the Paris, Vienna and Brussels Conventions (to which Australia is not party). By increasing compensation for transboundary harm, and providing compensation for environmental damage, such an international regime will enhance existing measures.

In the unlikely event that an accident involving the Pacific Teal did occur resulting in the release of radioactivity and causing economic damage, Australian interests affected would have several options for seeking compensation. Japanese and French authorities have advised the Government that there is liability coverage on the shipment, under an agreement between the French reprocessing company Cogema, and the Japanese Government. However, the Australian Government has not been provided with any detailed information on the content of that agreement, and is continuing to press the Japanese and French authorities on the issue. Depending on the applicability of this agreement, Australian interests affected by an accident could also seek recourse to remedies through private international law. Failing this, once all such remedies have been exhausted, Australia could also seek to bring an action on behalf of the affected parties in the International Court of Justice, under customary international law. In order to bring such an action, all parties would have to agree to the Court hearing the dispute.

(3) The general route taken by the Pacific Teal in its voyage from France to Japan was via the Cape of Good Hope, south of Australia, through the Tasman Sea and into the Southwest Pacific. The exact route was determined by the ship's captain, who regularly advised our maritime authorities of his position when the ship was in the Australian search and rescue area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Of the $0.5 million set aside for the radiofrequency electromagnetic radiation (RFEMR) research and information program for the 1996‐97 financial year, can details be provided of proposed expenditure on:
(a) Australian research
(b) the World Health Organisation International Electromagnetic Field Project; and
(c) public dissemination of information.
(2) What expenditure has been committed to date.
(3) Of the remaining $4 million for RFEMR research and information for the years 1997 to 2000, can details or estimates of proposed expenditure be provided on:
(a) Australian research
(b) the World Health Organisation International Electromagnetic Field Project; and
(c) public dissemination of information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) The research component is allocated $350,000 for 1996/97.

(b) The World Health Organisation International Electromagnetic Field (WHO) Project is allocated $75,000 for 1996/97 for contribution and travel. The amount payable to participate in the Project is US$50,000 per year. The actual amount paid in A$ is dependent upon the exchange rate at the time of payment, but is expected to be around $64,000. The balance will be used for representation at meetings.
(c) The information program is allocated $75,000 for 1996/97.

(2) To date, expenditure for the program totals $23,062.15—$6,780.25 for the research program and $16,281.90 for the information program. To date, there has been no expenditure from the program on the WHO component.
(3)(a) The research component will be allocated a minimum of $700,000 per year.
(b) The World Health Organisation International Electromagnetic Field Project will be allocated up to $100,000 per year.
(c) The information program will be allocated up to $200,000 per year.
Expenditure on the WHO Project and the information program will be assessed annually with any unused/surplus funds being allocated to the research component.

hereby grant BORAL TIMBER TASMANIA LIMITED a licence to export HARDWOOD WOODCHIPS during the period commencing on DATE OF SIGNATURE and ending on 31 DECEMBER 1997
Under Regulation 9 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, this licence is subject to the conditions and restrictions specified below.

TAB.TAB: Signed by Minister

PARA.TAB: Signature of Minister Date

BREAK.PARA: DEFINITIONS
1. In this licence—
"Department" means the Department which is responsible for advising the Minister in respect of administration of the Export Control Act 1982;

"exporter" means Boral Timber Tasmania Limited the registered office of which is at Long Reach East Tamar, or any other person or company acting by, or on behalf of, or under the authority of, Boral Timber Tasmania Limited:

"Minister" means the Minister responsible for administration of the Export Control Act 1982; and
"tonnes" means green metric tonnes.
QUANTITY
2. The quantity of hardwood wood chips exported under this licence shall not exceed 40,000 tonnes.
SOURCE MATERIAL
3. Material for export under this licence is limited to hardwood woodchips sourced from hardwood plantations on private property in Tasmania.

4. The exporter shall not export under this licence hardwood woodchips harvested in any area (including an area on the Register of the National Estate or the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate), except with prior written approval of the Minister.
COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS, ETC
5. The exporter shall comply with all Commonwealth, State and Local government laws including those concerning protection of the environment.
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION

6. All operations of the exporter associated with the production and export of woodchips under this licence shall be conducted by the exporter in accordance with the statement entitled "Environmental Impact Statement on Tasmanian wood chip exports beyond 1988" and the supplement to that statement in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding and the Appendix to the Memorandum.

7. The exporter shall ensure that any of its operations conducted in association with activities approved under this licence do not threaten with extinction, or significantly impede the recovery of, a species listed in Schedule 1 or an ecological community listed in Schedule 2 of the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.
PRICING
8. The exporter shall not export hardwood wood chips except with the prior written approval of the Minister or the Department of:
(a) an agreed price; or
(b) an interim or provisional price, and arrangements concerning the retrospective application of a price to be negotiated by the exporter.
DOMESTIC PROCESSING

9. The exporter shall give priority to domestic processors who seek to purchase the hardwood woodchips at a price that is equivalent to the export price net of export handlinq costs and charges, unless otherwise approved by the Minister.
INSPECTION

10. The exporter shall take all steps within its power to facilitate the inspection by officers of the Department, and of the Government of Tasmania of any area where the exporter is carrying out operations connected with the export of hardwood wood chips under this licence.
REPORTING

11. The exporter shall provide the Department with a report in respect of the six months ending on 30 June 1997, as soon as possible after 30 June 1997 and no later than 30 September 1997, and a report in respect of the six months ending on 31 December 1997, as soon as possible after 31 December 1997, and no later than 31 March 1998, in relation to:
(a) compliance with the conditions and restrictions of this licence;
(b) the quantities of hardwood woodchips exported under this licence and the prices received for those wood chips.
Note:

Failure to comply with the conditions or restrictions in an export licence is an offence under the Export Control Act 1982. Under the Regulations the Minister may also suspend or revoke the licence in certain circumstances.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Women in Science, Engineering and Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology upon notice, on 3 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was an Advisory Group set up in May 1993 to develop strategies to improve women's participa tion in careers and education in science, engineering and technology.
(2) Did this Advisory Group submit a report, known as the Wiset Report, in December 1994.
(3) What has happened to the report and what actions has the government taken to implement the recommendations of the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. In May 1993, the then Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science and Minister for Science and Small Business established the Women in Science, Engineering and Technology (WISET) Advisory Group to advise on strategies to improve women's participation in science, engineering and technology careers and education.
(2) The WISET Advisory Group prepared a discussion paper, Women in Science, Engineering and Technology, which was published in May 1995.

(3) The previous Government did not respond to the WISET paper before the change of Government. While this Government recognises that the WISET paper has provided a valuable analysis of issues facing women in science, engineering and technology (SET), the paper's recommendations are more relevant to the outlook of the previous Government.

Consequently, this Government will not prepare a written response to the detailed recommendations of the WISET paper. Our approach to improving the participation of women in SET‐based careers and education is to create a broad, positive environment in which all Australians have the maximum opportunity to achieve their potential. We do this against the background that the numbers of women undertaking education and careers in science, engineering and technology is increasing, although there is still some way to go.

In addition to our broad, positive policies and programs in employment, higher education, vocational education and training, primary and secondary education and communications, we will continue our efforts to improve the effectiveness of monitoring and reporting on ministerial and departmental accountability for the impact of programs on women clients, including the existing range of programs to achieve gender equity in SET educational and employment contexts.

We will continue our efforts to include women equitably in the educational and employment contexts of SET through programs in all relevant agencies. These include, for example, a new system of merit‐based scholarships to assist members of equity target groups, including women in non‐traditional areas of study, to participate in higher education, and the introduction of part‐time traineeships and other flexible arrangements provided in the new apprenticeship scheme.
We are committed to support for a reconstituted science, engineering and technology awareness program which has women and girls among its targets.

We are committed to ensuring that women make a substantial contribution to, and gain the benefits from, participation in science, engineering and technology education, training and employment, including at the most senior levels of management, in both the public and private sectors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applications have been lodged to obtain patents for genes(s) or gene sequences with: (a) unknown function; and (b) known function.
(2) How many patents have been granted for gene(s) or gene sequences with: (a) unknown function; and (b) known function.

(3) How many applications have been lodged to obtain patents for gene(s) or gene sequences with: (a) unknown function as a component part of a claim; and (b) known function as a component part of a claim.
(4) How many patents have been granted for gene(s) or gene sequences with: (a) unknown function as a component part of a claim; and (b) known function as a component part of a claim.
(5) How many applications has the Patent Office refused for gene(s) or gene sequences with: (a) unknown function; and (b) known function.
(6) Would the Patent Office grant patents for an identical sequence of bases (A, T, G and C) obtained from different organisms; if not, why not.

(7) Would the Patent Office grant patents for a short sequence of bases within the immediate regulatory region 5' of a start codon where: (a) the sequence has been shown to have regulatory action; (b) the sequence is presumed to have regulatory significance; and (c) the sequence has no regulatory significance.
(8) What does the Patent Office define as a `gene'.
(9) At what stage does a gene or a gene sequence from a human cease to be human so that it can be patented.

(10) With reference to subsection 18(2) of the Patents Act 1990, which provides that `Human beings, and the biological processes for their generation, are not patentable inventions': are human genes `human beings' or `the biological processes for their generation' for the purposes of subsection 18(2).
(11) What proportion of patent applications relate to or include a gene or gene sequence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Patent Office estimates that a total of around 8,100 patent applications concerning genes or gene sequences have been made. Data on the individual claims of these applications are not collected. However, it should be noted that the Patent Office does not grant patents for genes and gene sequences where no use is known.

(2) The Patent Office estimates that a total of around 2,100 patent applications concerning genes or gene sequences have been granted. Data on the individual claims of these applications are not collected. However, it should be noted again that the Patent Office does not grant patents for genes and gene sequences where no use is known.
(3) The Patent Office does not collate the data to answer this question beyond that provided to question 1.
(4) The Patent Office does not collate the data to answer this question beyond that provided to question 2.
(5) As stated in answer to questions 1 and 2 above, an estimated 8,100 patent applications concerning genes or gene sequences have been made with a total of approximately 2,100 having been granted.
(6) The Patent Office would most likely consider that the gene was already known and therefore not novel and not patentable.
(7) (a) Yes, provided all the usual criteria for patentability (ie. novelty, inventive step and, in particular, industrial use) have been met.
(b) Yes, provided all the usual criteria for patentability (ie. novelty, inventive step and, in particular, industrial use) have been met.
(c) No, unless the applicant can show some other industrial use for the particular sequence.

(8) The Patent Office uses the normal scientific definition for a gene, which can be found in many biological dictionaries e.g. Henderson's Biological Dictionary defines a gene as `the basic unit of inheritance, by which hereditary characteristics are transmitted from parent to offspring'.

(9) An isolated single gene or gene sequence from a human is not considered a human. Provided a human gene or gene sequence meets the usual criteria as stated in the Patents Act 1990, it is patentable.
(11) The Patent Office estimates that since 1975, about 1.8% of patent applications filed in Australia have concerned genes or gene sequences.
